headline: Ilana Glazer Event at Synagogue Is Canceled After Anti-Semitic Graffiti Is Found
abstract: A political event at the Union Temple of Brooklyn in Prospect Heights was called off after hateful messages, including “Die Jew Rats,” were discovered on the temple’s walls.
lead_paragraph: A get-out-the-vote event at a Brooklyn synagogue featuring the comedian Ilana Glazer was canceled on Thursday night after anti-Semitic graffiti, including the words “Die Jew Rats,” was discovered scrawled on the temple’s walls, the police and officials at the synagogue said.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Tejal Rao has a delightful recipe for pickled roasted mushrooms, perfect for toast. Or make a white Bolognese pasta or a feed for Sunday night’s game.

Tejal Rao delivered a paean to mushrooms in her “Eat” column in The New York Times Magazine this week, and it’s a delight to read, down to her imagining of a “20th-century food writer, rain boots caked with mud,” emerging from the woods with baskets full of wild varieties identified by sight amid the fallen leaves.

headline: The Favorite in the New York City Marathon Has a Secret Weapon
abstract: Geoffrey Kamworor will try to defend his title in New York on Sunday. Easier said than done, but he trains in Kenya with Eliud Kipchoge, the greatest marathoner ever.
lead_paragraph: Winning any title in sports twice in a row is a challenge. The element of surprise is gone. Expectations rise. The rest of the field is out to topple the champion. It’s one reason so few men have won back-to-back titles at the New York City Marathon.

headline: The Perversion of Fiscal Policy (Slightly Wonkish)
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Recession and Depression', 'Unemployment', 'Quantitative Easing']
abstract: Austerity in a slump, stimulus in a boom.
lead_paragraph: As many people have pointed out, the Trump tax represented a total break with the normal principles of fiscal policy. Historically, we’ve tended to run big deficits when the economy is weak, smaller deficits or surpluses when it’s strong. But now the deficit is soaring even in the face of low unemployment. This is irresponsible, and shows that Republican handwringing over deficits was always phony – which some of us pointed out at the time.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Jerusalem,’ ‘Leonardo da Vinci’

headline: How Ignacio Mattos, the Chef at Estela, Balances His 14-Hour Days

lead_paragraph: Ignacio Mattos, 38, a chef from Uruguay, is on a roll. As the owner of Estela and Flora Bar, two critically acclaimed restaurants in New York, he was named Esquire’s chef of the year in 2017. This month, he is publishing his first book, “The Estela Cookbook.” Here’s how he manages his grueling 14-hour workdays.

headline: The Democrats’ Next Job: Bury Supply-Side Economics
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Income Inequality', 'Liberalism (US Politics)']
abstract: Voters don’t like Republican policies, but conservatives win by spinning a good story about economics. Liberals need to do the same.
lead_paragraph: Win, lose or draw on Tuesday, the Democratic Party will almost immediately turn its focus to the next presidential election and the fight between the establishment center and the left wing. But while the Democrats have that argument, they must also undertake the far more important task of thinking about what they agree on, and how they can construct a story about how the economy works and grows and spreads prosperity, a story that competes with — and defeats — the Republicans’ own narrative.

headline: Cruz Might Win the Senate, but the Democrats Are Winning Texas

headline: The 2018 New York Times/New York Public Library Best Illustrated Children’s Books
abstract: We invite you to take a look at this year’s winners ...
lead_paragraph: Since 1952, we’ve convened a rotating annual panel of three expert judges, who consider every illustrated children’s book published that year in the United States. They select the winners purely on the basis of artistic merit. The judges this time were Leonard Marcus, a children’s literature historian and critic; Jenny Rosenoff, a children’s librarian at the New York Public Library; and Bryan Collier, the author and illustrator of many acclaimed picture books and a past winner of the award.

headline: Pakistan Makes Concessions to Protesters in Blasphemy Case
abstract: The government and Islamist leaders enraged over the acquittal of a woman accused of blasphemy struck a deal that allows further appeals and bars her from leaving the country.

lead_paragraph: The United States was the only country to leave the multilateral nuclear deal with Iran. The Trump administration quickly moved to snap back crippling sanctions on Iran. We spoke with the country’s top diplomat and young Iranians to see how these moves have affected their lives.

headline: Think Your Vote Doesn’t Matter?

Liuba Grechen Shirley, Antonio Delgado and Tom Malinowski, endorsed by the Times editorial board, will be campaigning tirelessly from now until Election Day. They hope to be part of the wave that will help Democrats regain control of the House of Representatives.

headline: What Happened to Lindsey Graham? He’s Become a Conservative ‘Rock Star’

headline: Because We All Have to Eat!
abstract: Let us help you do it efficiently and deliciously, with spaghetti and meatballs, chickpea stew and a quick glazed roasted salmon.
lead_paragraph: Hi again, and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes, delicious food for busy people. As it happens, I spoke on a panel this week about the challenges women face, both personal and structural, in work, parenting and life, and how food enters into the equation. Food, of course, is culture and comfort. But it is also a requirement: Everyone has to eat. I explained what we’re trying to do with this newsletter — for everyone, not just women or parents of young(ish) kids — which is to tell you about something great you can make for dinner, fairly quickly and healthfully, with fresh ideas and exciting flavors.

headline: God’s Red Army

abstract: The Republican Party hopes to beat back the Democrats on Tuesday with a big push from the Christian right.

Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Pakistani Religious Leader Known as ‘Father of the Taliban’ Is Killed

headline: Review: New Works Designed With a Daring Trumpeter in Mind

He likes brash fields of finely textured noise, as well as contemplative pieces generously dotted with silence. He has played jazz. He has played classical. And he particularly relishes the zone where no one is sorting music into any categories at all.

headline: The Artist Critiquing Feminine Clichés With Ceramic Heels and Cigarette Butts
abstract: Genesis Belanger’s porcelain sculptures playfully send up the advertising campaigns she once helped create as a prop stylist.
lead_paragraph: The artist Genesis Belanger’s sun-filled Williamsburg studio could easily be mistaken for a sort of strange, surrealist kitchen. There is a large, stainless-steel kiln in one corner and next to it, a rolling cart stacked with small rectangles of stoneware, like so many cookies fresh from the oven. A mint-green KitchenAid mixer, which Belanger uses to incorporate pigment into porcelain, stands nearby. Otherworldly objects — a bouquet of flowers and fingers, a champagne bottle stopped with the end of a hot dog, supersize cigarettes stubbed out in a ashtray as big as a dinner plate, all pale as raw dough — dry on a shelf, resembling cakes waiting to be baked.

headline: Robyn, Pop’s Reluctant Pacesetter
abstract: With “Honey,” the Swedish star returns to a landscape she’s quietly shaped for over 20 years.
lead_paragraph: In the eight years since Robyn released her last full-length album, she put out a few low-profile collaborative EPs, experienced turmoil in her personal life and underwent intensive psychoanalysis.

headline: I Was Never an Athlete. Then I Found Running.
abstract: The sport can be solitary. But you can also find incredible camaraderie racing with a pack.
lead_paragraph: More than 50,000 runners are expected to take part in the New York City Marathon this Sunday. Some of them will be elite runners chasing glory; the rest will be looking for a personal record or a Boston Marathon qualifying time, or just looking to finish. I won't be doing the marathon this year, but I will be there to cheer the runners on, cowbell in hand. And while I take in this remarkable spectacle, I will also be looking forward to my next race — and reflecting on how grateful I am to have found a sport like this.

headline: Preserving the Wealth That Conservation Built
keywords: ['Conservation of Resources', 'Water Pollution', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Rivers', 'Federal Lands', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: Business and conservation needn’t be opposed to one another. Government regulation to preserve the environment can unlock private sector wealth.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration views conservation and the environment primarily through the lens of conflict — of business versus government.

headline: Sewing That Ends Up in Orbit
abstract: In 1975, Hue Nguyen fled by boat from South Vietnam, where she had learned to sew. Now her finished work soars into space with NASA astronauts.
lead_paragraph: Hue Nguyen, 64, is a seamstress at Leidos in Webster, Tex.

keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'News and News Media']

lead_paragraph: In an effort to shed more light on how we work, The Times is running a series of short posts explaining some of our journalistic practices. Read more of this series here.

headline: Alec Baldwin Is Arrested After Dispute Over Parking Space in Manhattan
abstract: The police said that someone was apparently holding a parking space for Mr. Baldwin, but another car pulled into the space and an altercation ensued.
lead_paragraph: The actor Alec Baldwin, who won an Emmy for mocking President Trump on “Saturday Night Live,” was taken into custody outside his Manhattan apartment building on Friday after getting into a dispute about a parking space, the police said.

headline: Idaho Isn’t Turning Blue, but One Democrat Is Turning Heads
abstract: Paulette Jordan, a long-shot candidate for governor in a deep-red state, would be the first female governor there and the first Native American governor anywhere.
lead_paragraph: EMMETT, Idaho — This state is indisputably Trump country, what with the president’s 32-point victory margin in 2016 and the Republican state leadership and congressional delegation. Still, in storefront windows like at the Possumtrot Traders pawnshop in this deeply conservative town of 6,800, you see it: a large Paulette Jordan sign displayed next to a Trump sign.

headline: Sunny Suljic of ‘Mid90s’ Checks Out His Favorite Skate Shop
abstract: The 13-year-old actor is a star of Jonah Hill’s coming-of-age skateboarding movie.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It was the golden hour here when Sunny Suljic tumbled out of a black S.U.V. and onto Sawtelle Boulevard, a commercial strip just west of Route 405 lined with Japanese noodle joints and third-wave coffee shops. His mother was in tow, carrying his skateboard.

headline: Judge Orders Evidence to Be Gathered in Emoluments Case Against Trump
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Constitution (US)', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: The ruling came in a lawsuit accusing the president of illegally maintaining a financial interest in his company’s hotel near the White House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge in Maryland on Friday ordered evidence-gathering to begin in a lawsuit accusing President Trump of violating the Constitution by maintaining a financial interest in his company’s Washington hotel.

headline: Missouri Senate Race: Claire McCaskill and Josh Hawley
abstract: Senator Claire McCaskill, a moderate, has supported more Trump administration moves than her fellow Democrats have. But will it be enough to hold off a Republican in an increasingly conservative state?
lead_paragraph: Two-term Senator Claire McCaskill is in the fight of her political life. Her challenger, Josh Hawley, is the state’s Republican attorney general. He’s a political newcomer closely aligned with President Trump, who carried Missouri by 18 points in 2016.

headline: Texas Senate Race: Beto O’Rourke and Ted Cruz
abstract: A Democrat hasn’t been elected to a statewide position in Texas since 1994. Ahead of this year’s midterm election, a Senate race between an unflinching liberal and a religious conservative is unexpectedly close.
lead_paragraph: But this year, Beto O’ Rourke turned a Senate race into a surprisingly close contest by raising over $60 million — far outpacing his opponent, the 2016 Republican presidential candidate, Ted Cruz.

headline: Florida Governor’s Race: Andrew Gillum and Ron DeSantis
abstract: What will a heated race in Florida tell us about America’s future?
lead_paragraph: After an upset victory in a crowded primary field, the Democrat Andrew Gillum is running on an unapologetically progressive platform. Ron DeSantis, the Republican, is a strong supporter of President Trump.

headline: Beto O’Rourke in Candle Wax. Ted Cruz in Acrylic. Meet the Crafters Who Love Politics.
abstract: Some Americans show their candidate preference at the ballot box. Others use Etsy.
lead_paragraph: While some Americans have prepared for next week’s election by obsessively following the news or canvassing neighborhoods, a small minority has poured that energy into a more quirkily patriotic pastime: crafting!

headline: ‘Outlander’ Takes Manhattan
abstract: An afternoon spent tagging along with the stars of the Starz drama at New York Comic Con demonstrated the uncommon bond the show shares with its fans.
lead_paragraph: There are many Claires. There is World War II Claire, bloody in her military nurse’s apron. There is Scottish Claire, back in 1743, snug in warm woolens and riding clothes. And then there’s the most photogenic one of all: French Claire, stylish in a Dior-inspired bar suit and black platter hat, with basket panniers and pads underneath the silk skirt to give her that 18th-century look.

headline: What Is It With the Jets and Their False and Slow Starts?
abstract: The Jets have a lot of problems, including the most basic one in football — following the snap count.
lead_paragraph: An air horn sounded, and the Jets jumped. Eleven offensive linemen hurried to the back right corner of the practice fields to join their coach, Rick Dennison. Practice started with a focus on pre-snap stillness.

headline: Our Mental Health at Risk
keywords: ['Hate Crimes', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A reader says the president’s speech adversely affects the psyche of Americans.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Night of Partying Ended in a Grisly Murder. A Jeweler’s Surrogate Son Is Guilty.
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine']
abstract: James Rackover, accused with another man of killing Joseph Comunale and burying his body, was convicted by a jury of murder and related charges.
lead_paragraph: The men did not know each other and their meeting at a Manhattan nightclub was happenstance, but it started off a long night of revelry. By 4:30 a.m., they had met some women and moved the party four miles away to James Rackover’s luxury apartment on the East Side, where they continued to drink and snort cocaine.

headline: U.S. and Turkey Drop Dueling Sanctions Against Senior Officials
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: The tit-for-tat penalties, initiated by the continued detention of an American pastor in Turkey, were imposed in August. They were simultaneously scrubbed in a sign of warming relations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and Turkey have lifted sanctions against top officials in each other’s government in a mutual sign on Friday of warming diplomatic relations between the two NATO allies after last month’s release of an American pastor.

headline: Where ‘Yes! To Affordable Groceries’ Really Means No to a Soda Tax
abstract: Coke, PepsiCo and other big beverage companies are the unseen forces (and funders) behind ballot initiatives that would ban taxes on food sales.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Standing in a supermarket produce aisle, her face shadowed with dread, the middle-aged woman speaks directly to the camera and makes a plea for common decency.

headline: ‘Outlander’ Season 4 Is Nigh. Here’s What to Remember.
abstract: Everyone’s favorite lusty time-traveling drama is back. Fuzzy on the details? This refresher will help guide you through the stones.
lead_paragraph: The “Droughtlander” is over: Everyone’s favorite lusty time-traveling drama, “Outlander,” returns to Starz for Season 4 on Sunday, Nov. 4. But Season 3 was so jam-packed with action it may be hard to hard to remember all the details — especially since it keeps jumping back and forth in time.

headline: On the First Shabbat After Pittsburgh Attack, ‘We’re Here to Be Jewish Together’
abstract: Less than a week after the Pittsburgh shooting killed 11 people attending Shabbat services, synagogues across the country commemorated the victims.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — As the sun went down on Friday, they walked into synagogues across the country in solidarity and in grief. Some carried prayer books. Some carried their children. Others carried the memories of friends who had been slaughtered nearly a week earlier in a gunman’s hate-filled rampage at the Tree of Life synagogue.

headline: How a Taliban Assassin Got Close Enough to Kill a General
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: The attack that killed a powerful Afghan police chief and missed the top U.S. commander led to violence between allies, and the rumor that Americans were behind it all.
lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Minutes before killing one of the most important generals in Afghanistan, the infiltrator made a final call to the Taliban.

headline: Jun Ashida, Who Dressed Japanese Royalty, Is Dead at 88
abstract: Mr. Ashida, a self-effacing designer, synthesized Western styles and traditional Japanese sensibilities in creating his clothing collections.
lead_paragraph: Jun Ashida, a designer who dressed everyday women and members of the Japanese monarchy in practical, sophisticated silhouettes, died on Oct. 20 at his home in Tokyo. He was 88.

headline: Nana Kwame Adjei-Brenyah on ‘Friday Black’
abstract: “Black people being murdered is unfortunately a constant in this country. Murdered with impunity. It’s something that’s constantly on my mind,” Adjei-Brenyah says. “So some of these stories respond to that very specifically.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: When Human Relatives First Visited a Green Arabian Peninsula
abstract: Evidence of the activities of early hominins found in the Saudi desert suggests that they found an area that once was similar to the East African savanna.
lead_paragraph: Buried in the Arabian desert’s sand are clues to the peninsula’s wetter, greener past. Fossils from long-extinct elephants, antelope and jaguars paint a prehistoric scene not of a barren wasteland, but of a flourishing savanna sprinkled with watering holes.

headline: Jin Yong, 94, Lionized Author of Chinese Martial Arts Epics, Dies
abstract: He created widely popular panoramic fictional universes that inspired movies and video games and that have led some to compare him to J.R.R. Tolkien.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Jin Yong, a literary giant of the Chinese-speaking world whose fantastical epic novels inspired countless film, television and video game adaptations and were read by generations of ethnic Chinese, died on Oct. 30 in Hong Kong. He was 94.

headline: Disgraced at Olympics Over Marijuana, Canadian Snowboarder Hopes to Ride to Cannabis Success
abstract: Ross Rebagliati, an athlete once infamous for briefly losing his Olympic gold medal, now hopes to cash in on his fame in the “green gold rush.”
lead_paragraph: KELOWNA, British Columbia — Ross Rebagliati, a pioneering Olympic snowboarder, keeps his gold medal hidden inside a beat-up cabinet in his modest home, next to an ashtray holding his car keys and a plastic bag of weed.

headline: Poor Disaster Oversight Imperiled Nursing Homes, Senate Report Finds
keywords: ['Weather', 'Elderly', 'Nursing Homes', 'Elder Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Hurricane Irma (2017)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hurricane Harvey (2017)', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Medicare', 'Heatstroke', 'Air Conditioning', 'Medicaid']

headline: High Demand and Short Supply in Canada’s Legal Cannabis Trade
abstract: Canada’s new legal market for marijuana is facing shortages amid higher-than-expected interest, writes Dan Bilefsky
lead_paragraph: This is Dan Bilefsky in Montreal, where the pungent smell of cannabis wafting from the long lines of people at government marijuana stores may soon compete with the more familiar street smells of poutine. I am filling in this week for Ian Austen on the Canada Letter.

headline: American Jews Know How This Story Goes
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Synagogues', 'Pittsburgh, Pa, Shooting (2018)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']

keywords: ['New York City Marathon', 'London Marathon', 'Women and Girls', 'Marathon Running']
abstract: The field is full of quality, especially in the women’s race, where Americans are among the favorites.
lead_paragraph: Imagine you’re a race organizer and you wanted to put together an incredibly memorable marathon. You might come very close to constructing the field that has been assembled for the women’s New York City Marathon on Sunday.

keywords: ['Crosses and Crucifixes', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Freedom of Religion', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: An appeals court said the cross, in Maryland, violated the First Amendment’s ban on government establishment of religion. The cross’s supporters say that logic could imperil hundreds of war memorials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to decide whether a 40-foot cross on state property in suburban Maryland violates the First Amendment’s ban on government establishment of religion.

headline: Turkey’s President Invokes NATO Solidarity in Killing of Jamal Khashoggi
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']

lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s president lashed out again at Saudi Arabia over the killing of the Saudi dissident Jamal Khashoggi, and turned up pressure on the kingdom by invoking the NATO alliance as a means to ensure the perpetrators will be punished.

headline: The Best Tips and Tools for Safer Winter Driving
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Weather', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: Winter presents unique driving dangers. Here is some advice and useful gear to keep in the trunk to stay safe on the roads.
lead_paragraph: Long before the first snowstorm hits, the onset of cool weather brings drivers a unique set of dangers and inconveniences. Tires lose pressure, sometimes becoming dangerously (and invisibly) deflated. Batteries lose power in the cold too. Shorter days mean that commutes — and emergencies — often happen in the dark.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Powerful New Opioid Despite Warnings of Likely Abuse
keywords: ['Opioids and Opiates', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: The head of a review panel predicted the drug, Dsuvia, would cause more overdose deaths. But the F.D.A. said there were adequate safeguards.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved a new form of an extremely potent opioid to manage acute pain in adults, weeks after the chairman of the advisory committee that reviewed it asked the agency to reject it on grounds that it would likely be abused.

headline: Mario Segale, Developer Who Inspired Nintendo to Name Super Mario, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Segale rented a warehouse near Seattle to Nintendo in the company’s early days, and once berated its president about unpaid rent.
lead_paragraph: Mario A. Segale, a Seattle-area real estate developer who unwittingly lent his name to perhaps the most famous video game character in history — Nintendo’s Mario — died at a local hospital on Oct. 27. He was 84.

headline: Carey Mulligan Makes a Mess in ‘Wildlife,’ and Men are Vexed
abstract: She plays a complicated mother, and some male viewers can’t seem to handle it: “They don’t like seeing a woman who’s out of line,” she says.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — As an actress, Carey Mulligan is drawn to women who are unapologetic, but as a person, she still can’t help but be a bit self-conscious. “I’m so sorry I’m late,” the 33-year-old Mulligan said as she sat down across from me at a Santa Monica coffeehouse. When told that she was only tardy by two minutes — an awfully minor infraction when it comes to celebrity interviews — Mulligan still felt compelled to apologize. Why? “I can’t help it, I’m English,” she said.

headline: Man Said to Be Pittsburgh Suspect’s Father Killed Himself Amid 1979 Rape Case
keywords: ['Pittsburgh, Pa, Shooting (2018)', 'Sex Crimes', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: According to court records, Randall G. Bowers had been charged in a sex attack that reportedly took place in the same Pittsburgh neighborhood as the synagogue massacre.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Forty years before Robert Bowers was accused of gunning down 11 people in an anti-Semitic rampage at the Tree of Life synagogue, the man believed to be his father was charged with raping a stranger and later committed suicide, according to court records unsealed on Friday.

headline: New Email Raises Questions About Cost of F.B.I. Building Project
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: The email showed the Trump administration preparing for scrutiny over the cost of its plan to build a new headquarters for the F.B.I. in downtown Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An email message released Friday shows the Trump administration bracing for scrutiny over the cost of its plan to build a new downtown headquarters for the Federal Bureau of Investigation instead of moving the agency to Maryland or Virginia.

headline: Resy Acquires Reserve, in the Fierce Tussle Over Restaurant Reservations
abstract: OpenTable is still the biggest player, but that dominance is under challenge by Resy and other rivals.
lead_paragraph: Resy, the restaurant-reservation service founded in 2014, said Friday that it had acquired its smaller competitor Reserve.

headline: Mickey Turns 90, and the Disney Marketing Machine Celebrates
abstract: To draw attention to its oldest character, Disney has revved up its cross-promotional machine to what may be its highest level yet.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A two-hour prime-time special on ABC. Cupcakes the size of cars at Disneyland Paris. Collaborations with a dozen fashion designers, including Marc Jacobs. More than 30 books, including one from Taschen so big it comes with a carrying handle.

headline: Milton Gendel, 99, Dies; Art Critic and Photographer Took Root in Rome
abstract: An American in Rome, he became a force in the art world and a photographer who captured la dolce vita Italy and Queen Elizabeth II feeding her dogs.
lead_paragraph: Milton Gendel, an art critic who left Manhattan nearly 70 years ago for Rome, where he became an advocate for postwar Italian artists and a photographer of subjects as diverse as Sicilian peasants and British royalty, died on Oct. 11 at his home there. He was 99.

headline: Racist Slur Defaces African Burial Ground Monument in Lower Manhattan
keywords: ['African Burial Ground (NYC)', 'Vandalism', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination']
abstract: A vandal scrawled “Kill,” followed by the slur, on a plaque at the monument.
lead_paragraph: The African Burial Ground Monument in Lower Manhattan, a treasured site for the nation’s black community, was defaced with a racist slur on Thursday, the authorities said.

headline: A Walk Through Manhattan With Saskia de Brauw
abstract: The artist and model, and her partner Vincent van de Wijngaard, share a new performance project.
lead_paragraph: The artist and model, and her partner Vincent van de Wijngaard, share a new performance project.

headline: T Suggests: Orchid-Inspired Handbags, a Diane Arbus Exhibition and More
abstract: A roundup of things our editors — and a few contributors — are excited about in a given week.
lead_paragraph: When the Dutch artist and fashion model Saskia de Brauw first started traveling to New York for work, eight or so years ago, she found the city “a really overwhelming place.” To calm her mind, she began to take long, slow walks around the streets of Manhattan, “to be able to take everything in,” she explains, “and then I had this desire to do that for an entire day. Almost using my pace as a clock.”

headline: Carlene Roberts Lawrence, Air Industry Pioneer, Dies at 105
abstract: In 1951, at a time when few women were being admitted into the executive suites of any industry, she became a vice president of American Airlines.
lead_paragraph: Carlene Roberts Lawrence, who worked her way up from a $150-a-month secretarial job to become, by wide acknowledgment, the first woman to break into the airline industry’s executive ranks, died on Oct. 29 at her home in Manhattan. She was 105.

headline: The Man Who Turns Back New York City’s Clocks, Hand by Hand
abstract: When daylight saving time begins and ends, it falls to Marvin Schneider, 79, New York’s official clock master, to reset some of the grandest public clocks in the city.
lead_paragraph: Marvin Schneider, 79, flashed his New York City employee identification badge — “clock repairer” — and walked into City Hall in Lower Manhattan on Friday morning.

headline: What’s on the Back of N.Y.C.’s Ballot? 3 Ways to Tweak Democracy
abstract: Voters will be asked to consider three ballot questions, one of which would change how political campaigns raise money.
lead_paragraph: If you haven’t noticed New York City’s $1 million-plus ad campaign to “Flip Your Ballot” — or if you want to know more about the ballot proposals in Tuesday’s election — you’ve come to the right place.

headline: Supreme Court Allows Trial on Census Citizenship Question to Go Forward
abstract: The order came a little over a week after the court granted the administration a partial victory in the case by temporarily blocking the deposition of Wilbur Ross, the commerce secretary.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rejecting a request from the Trump administration, the Supreme Court declined on Friday to halt a trial in a lawsuit challenging the addition of a question concerning citizenship to the 2020 census.

headline: Once Reluctant to Speak Out, an Energized Obama Now Calls Out His Successor
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: Barack Obama has re-emerged as the Democrats’ most prominent face, pitting president versus president over the future of the country.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Former President Barack Obama’s voice has a way of lifting into a high-pitched tone of astonishment when he talks about his successor, almost as if he still cannot believe that the Executive Mansion he occupied for eight years is now the home of President Trump.

headline: State Dept. Improperly Seized Passports of Americans in Yemen, Inquiry Finds
keywords: ['Passports', 'United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Inspectors General']
abstract: The passports, which consular officials said contained false or fraudulent names, were taken between December 2012 and June 2013, just as Yemen’s fragile political system began descending into chaos.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department improperly seized the passports of at least 31 American citizens trying to obtain vital records and other paperwork from the United States Embassy in Yemen, according to an inspector general’s report released on Friday.

headline: Paul Zimmerman (Dr. Z) Dies at 86; Chronicled Football’s Complexity
abstract: For almost 30 years at Sports Illustrated, he gained a national voice dissecting play-calling and writing revealing profiles of players and coaches.
lead_paragraph: Paul Zimmerman, a pro football writer whose deep understanding of the game informed his work at Sports Illustrated and influenced the way other reporters covered the sport, died on Thursday in Noblesville, Ind. Also known as Dr. Z, he was 86.

headline: A Hard-Luck Horseman Has the Chance of a Lifetime in the Breeders’ Cup Classic
abstract: Uriah St. Lewis bought Discreet Lover for $10,000. On Saturday, his horse will face 13 of the best thoroughbreds in the $6 million Breeders’ Cup Classic.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The sun had yet to rise above Churchill Downs, but pictured on a video screen towering above the track was a handsome bay horse named Discreet Lover, galloping effortlessly around the historic oval.

headline: The Harvard Trial: A Double-Edged Sword for College Admissions
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Asian-Americans', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The case has created cynicism among those who see college admissions as meritocratic, but has also revealed a school’s commitment to diversity.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — For the past three weeks, a succession of officials, students and academics have taken the witness stand in a federal trial here that has shaken the foundations of college admissions and explored what diversity means in America.

headline: Supreme Court Lets Youths’ Case Demanding Climate Action Proceed
abstract: The court said that the Trump administration had raised substantial questions about the plaintiffs’ legal theories, but that the plaintiffs should take the case back to an appeals court.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday refused to halt the trial in a lawsuit brought by 21 young people seeking to force the federal government to take action to address climate change.

headline: Common Sense on the Caravan
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Asylum, Right of', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A group of desperate migrants walking toward the Texas border is not a threat. We have laws to protect us — and them.
lead_paragraph: The caravan of people slowly making their way on blistered feet and thin hopes toward America’s southern border sometimes seems like an election gift to President Trump, giving him fresh meat to throw to his base on the eve of fateful midterm elections.

headline: The Long Struggle for America’s Soul
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Declaration of Independence (US)', 'Constitution (US)', 'Illegal Immigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Apparently, the self-evident truth that all people deserve life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness is far from settled.
lead_paragraph: Like many Americans, I’ve been following events at our southern border — the separation of children from their parents; the president’s denigration of nonwhite migrants as criminals, rapists and animals; his bluster about denying birthright citizenship to their children; and his pledge to send federal troops to intercept a dwindling caravan of frantic refugees.

headline: Trump Sweet-Talks Xi, Trying to Ease Trade Fears Before Midterms
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Midterm Elections (2018)']
abstract: President Trump’s newly soothing tone toward President Xi Jinping of China lies less in trade talks, which remain on hold, and more in domestic political calculations.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — When President Trump said Thursday he held a “long and very good conversation” on trade with President Xi Jinping of China, it kicked off a brief rally in financial markets and a flurry of questions about why the tensions between Washington and Beijing had suddenly eased.

headline: Saudi Sisters, Seeking Asylum, May Have Committed Suicide, Police Say
abstract: The police said an investigation revealed that the sisters had said they would rather kill themselves than return to Saudi Arabia.
lead_paragraph: Two months before their bodies would wash up dead on the rocky banks of the Hudson River, making them known throughout the world, two sisters from Saudi Arabia traveled from Virginia to Manhattan for reasons that are not yet clear.

headline: Why Aren’t Democrats Walking Away With the Midterms?
abstract: Democrats miss Trump’s political gifts and the real threat he represents.
lead_paragraph: The night Donald Trump was elected was supposed to be, for most liberals and a few conservatives, the beginning of the end of the world. The economy would surely implode. The U.S. would probably blunder into a catastrophic war. The new American president would be blackmailed into conducting foreign policy as Putin’s poodle.

headline: Republicans Have a Humming Economy to Tout, but Trump Rhetoric Muddies the Message
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (2017)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A glowing jobs report right before an election should be a gift to the party in power, but the president’s strident tone on immigration is drowning out the good news.
lead_paragraph: In normal political times, a glowing report on the nation’s economy just before Election Day would be a gift to the party in power and a uniform talking point for its candidates. But entering the final weekend before Tuesday’s midterm vote, President Trump’s blistering message of nativist fear has become the dominant theme of the campaign’s last days, threatening to overshadow the good economic news.

headline: University of Maryland Chaos Is Rooted in Lofty Sports Goals
abstract: The fallout from a football player’s death has created turmoil on campus six years after Maryland announced it would join the mighty Big Ten Conference.

headline: Man Shoots 6 at Florida Yoga Studio, Killing 2 and Then Himself
abstract: The police in Tallahassee said they did not know the motive for the shooting, which happened around the time a yoga class was to be held.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Nigerian Army Uses Trump’s Words to Justify Shooting of Rock-Throwers

headline: ‘Do Something Funny!’
abstract: Ryan McCarty hypnotizes us with an elegant whirligig of a puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE —  Grids at the end of the week are devised to challenge the solver, as we’re all painfully aware. But do we ever consider the poor constructor who takes on the challenge of challenging us? As we get more experienced, by finishing more grids, we can become jaded and bitter, like that picky blonde in the fable (“Too easy!” “Too hard!”).

headline: Review: A ‘Midsummer Night’s Dream’ That’s More Speedy Than Dreamy

When the party needle is in the red right from the start, there’s a high risk the only way is down.

headline: Man-Eating Tiger Is Shot Dead in India
abstract: The female tiger, which was believed to have killed at least 13 people, was the subject of one of the longest and most expensive tiger hunts in India in recent memory.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A man-eating tiger that stalked the hills of central India for more than two years and repeatedly eluded capture was shot and killed by hunters after one of the most intensive tiger hunts in recent memory, officials said.

headline: On Politics: The Biggest Stories of the Week

headline: An Operation in Niger Went Fatally Awry. Who Is the Army Punishing?

headline: Hotel Review: Modern Luxury in the Vineyards of France

Modern, design-focused lodging, however, has been much slower to develop. But two recently opened properties in the region — one a renovation, the other a new development — are changing that.

headline: Is Agnes Gund the Last Good Rich Person?

But times had changed.

headline: The Election Is on Tuesday. Here Are 15 of Our Best Reads.

headline: U.S. Law Enforcement Failed to See the Threat of White Nationalism. Now They Don’t Know How to Stop It.
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Whites', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Police', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: For two decades, domestic counterterrorism strategy has ignored the rising danger of far-right extremism. In the atmosphere of willful indifference, a virulent movement has grown and metastasized.
lead_paragraph: The first indication to Lt. Dan Stout that law enforcement’s handling of white supremacy was broken came in September 2017, as he was sitting in an emergency-operations center in Gainesville, Fla., preparing for the onslaught of Hurricane Irma and watching what felt like his thousandth YouTube video of the recent violence in Charlottesville, Va. Jesus Christ, he thought, studying the footage in which crowds of angry men, who had gathered to attend or protest the Unite the Right rally, set upon one another with sticks and flagpole spears and flame throwers and God knows what else. A black man held an aerosol can, igniting the spray, and in retaliation, a white man picked up his gun, pointed it toward the black man and fired it at the ground. The Virginia state troopers, inexplicably, stood by and watched. Stout fixated on this image, wondering what kind of organizational failure had led to the debacle. He had one month to ensure that the same thing didn’t happen in Gainesville.

headline: Leicester City Players in Thailand to Pay Their Respects at Owner’s Funeral

keywords: ['Pittsburgh, Pa, Shooting (2018)', 'Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The killings of nine parishioners at a black church in Charleston and 11 congregants at a synagogue in Pittsburgh brought people in those two communities together in an unspeakable grief.

They spread their arms wide and embraced at length, the rabbi patting the pastor rhythmically on the back as the pastor drew him close. Words were not necessary.

headline: The Psychology of Anti-Semitism
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Pittsburgh, Pa, Shooting (2018)', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Why is prejudice against Jewish people so often expressed in sudden waves of virulent, even exterminatory attacks?
lead_paragraph: After the massacre at the Tree of Life synagogue in Pittsburgh, in which a white supremacist shot to death 11 people while screaming, “All Jews must die,” a Jewish girl in New York sent an anguished note to her mother. “I know I shouldn’t feel like I don’t have an answer to this question,” she wrote in a text message that was later shared on social media. “But why do people hate us?”

headline: I Have a Green Card Now. But Am I Welcome?

abstract: I should feel safer, but the president’s anti-immigrant rhetoric doesn’t help.

This year, because the Russian River was low, we went westward from our usual spot. On our way, we drove past a house with a Confederate flag flying over it. My friends are white; I am not.

headline: Seven Easy Cold-Weather Casseroles That Won’t Fix Any of This
abstract: There’s nothing like a home-style dish to keep you from thinking about World War III.

There’s nothing like a home-style dish to deliver the quaint sensation of being filled with melted cheese and carbohydrates while falling asleep on a couch and not thinking about the next world war.

headline: The Photographs We Never See

headline: The Best Way to Protect Democracy Is to Practice It
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: So vote.
lead_paragraph: “Donald Trump winning the presidency — I feel kind of responsible for that,” said Ashenafi Hagezom, a 27-year-old from Las Vegas who hasn’t voted in any election since becoming eligible nine years ago. Not in 2012, when young and minority voters — Mr. Hagezom’s parents are Ethiopian immigrants — showed up in record numbers to re-elect President Barack Obama. Not in 2014, when not so many showed up, and Republicans took back the Senate. And not in 2016, when Mr. Trump won the White House on a platform of white grievance and anti-immigrant spite.

lead_paragraph: In less than two weeks, the three-word phrase expanded from corners of the right-wing internet onto some of the most prominent political stages in the country, days before the midterm elections.

headline: Far-Right Internet Groups Listen for Trump’s Approval, and Often Hear It
keywords: ['Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Neo Nazi Groups', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In recent weeks, extremist internet communities have cheered as their once-fringe views have found oxygen among prominent Republicans.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, minutes after President Trump posted an incendiary campaign ad falsely accusing Democrats of flooding the country with murderous illegal immigrants, virulent racists on an online message board erupted in celebration.

headline: Another Trump Scoop, a Giddy Reaction and a Reporter Under Fire
abstract: The Axios reporter Jonathan Swan has been behind several major scoops in Washington media circles but he has been criticized for favoring access over accountability.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jonathan Swan could not sleep.

headline: 4 Ways World Leaders Have Echoed Trump’s Words and Policies
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Foreign leaders are using President Trump’s statements to justify their actions, citing him directly or simply echoing his words. Here are some of the ways his words are being adopted.
lead_paragraph: The president of the United States has one of the most powerful bully pulpits in the world.

headline: ‘Bohemian Rhapsody’ Tops Box Office, Overcoming Lackluster Reviews
abstract: The Freddie Mercury biopic made about $50 million domestically this weekend, a great figure for a film that cost about $52 million to make.
lead_paragraph: In the end, the words “Freddie Mercury biopic” were all prospective ticket buyers needed to hear.

headline: Why So Many Kentuckians Are Barred From Voting on Tuesday, and for Life
keywords: ['Ex-Convicts', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Kentucky, Iowa and Florida impose lifetime voting bans for people with felony records. A ballot measure in Florida could restore some voting rights.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE — Stephon Harbin leans Democratic but says he resents being pigeonholed in one party. House Speaker Paul Ryan, for instance, strikes an intellectual chord with him despite being a Republican. For Mr. Harbin, following politics is part of a civic duty to make his city a better place.

headline: Shadow, and Support, of Government Follows Hungarian Opera
abstract: The Hungarian State Opera and its National Ballet are here for two weeks at a time when Hungary’s government is leaning in an autocratic direction.
lead_paragraph: Its commendable that the Hungarian State Opera and the Hungarian National Ballet, to make their American debuts, brought some 350 artists and technical crew members to New York to present six productions. Inevitably, they carried some political baggage as well.

headline: Brown Point Shoes Arrive, 200 Years After White Ones
abstract: Ballet dancers of color have long painted, dyed or covered point shoes in makeup to match their skin. Could this small barrier to inclusion finally be disappearing?
lead_paragraph: For nearly her whole career, Cira Robinson has — like many ballet dancers of color — performed a ritual: painting her point shoes to match her skin.

headline: Booksellers Protest Amazon Site’s Move to Drop Stores From Certain Countries
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'E-Commerce', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: A flash strike against AbeBooks, which began Monday, is a rare concerted action by vendors against any part of Amazon, which wields huge power in the book world.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — More than 450 antiquarian book dealers in at least 26 countries pulled their books off an Amazon subsidiary on Monday, an impromptu protest after the site abruptly said it would drop all sellers from several nations.

headline: The Midterm Elections in Pictures
abstract: Times photographers spread out across the country to document the final days of the campaign, from Florida to California, Arizona to Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: Months of rallying, handshaking and sign-waving reached an apex as the 2018 midterm elections came to an end on Tuesday. Democrats took control of the House of Representatives, but Republicans appeared likely to expand their majority in the Senate. Democrats also won in several governors’ races, but Republicans held on in swing states like Florida and Ohio. Several races around the country remained too close to call.

headline: Lelisa Desisa Wins the New York City Marathon in the Last Miles
abstract: The 28-year-old Ethiopian overtook the defending champion, Geoffrey Kamworor of Kenya, after a miles-long dogfight through the 26.2-mile course.
lead_paragraph: As Lelisa Desisa of Ethiopia raced through Central Park in the closing miles of the New York City Marathon on Sunday, all eyes were on Geoffrey Kamworor of Kenya, the winner of last year’s race, who was just ahead of him.

headline: The Rhine, a Lifeline of Germany, Is Crippled by Drought
abstract: One of the worst dry spells on record has left parts of the river at record-low levels, forcing freighters to reduce their cargo or just stop plying the river.
lead_paragraph: KAUB, Germany — Just after sunrise, Capt. Frank Sep turned to his ship’s radio for the defining news of his day: the water level in Kaub, the shallowest part of the middle section of the Rhine, Germany’s most important shipping route.

headline: At Mile 20, the Bronx Cheers Are All Supportive
abstract: The New York City Marathon makes only a cameo in the borough, but residents take pride in making sure those who run that far get a push toward the finish.
lead_paragraph: Cowbells rang, Matracas rattled and Elvia Negron-Perez, who has completed 12 New York City Marathons, offered runners in Sunday’s race relief at her folding table along 135th Street in the Bronx.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 5, 2018
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: Note: Our next “What’s Going On in This Picture?” live-moderated discussion will take place on Nov. 19.

headline: You ‘Approved This Message’? Seriously?
abstract: The “Stand By Your Ad” rule, created in 2002, was meant to keep candidates from airing nasty ads. In the Trump era, it seems like a quaint relic.
lead_paragraph: DELRAY BEACH, Fla. — Let me take you back to a time when Democrats and Republicans could breathe the same air without choking on it.

headline: How The Times Makes Those Addictive Election Maps
abstract: Editors in our graphics department discuss how they turn vast troves of voting data into dynamic maps that help readers understand and explore election results.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to shed more light on how we work, The Times is running a series of short posts explaining some of our journalistic practices. Read more of this series here.

headline: If You’re Sure You Know What’s Going to Happen on Tuesday, You’re Wrong
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: The rise of Trumpism has changed the shape of the electorate. We are working our way toward a new political dispensation.
lead_paragraph: With Election Day at hand, we know one thing for sure: Voter turnout is huge. In fact, it looks like we will have the highest midterm turnout since 1966. The rationale for a gigantic blue wave that would represent a repudiation of the 2016 election has been that millions of Americans are so turned off by President Trump and his agenda that they will come out en masse and hand Congress to Democrats with large majorities, proving what has been an article of faith among Trump-haters, that his election was an anomaly and that American politics would quickly revert to the mean.

headline: Mary Keitany Earns 4th New York Marathon Title, 3 Minutes Ahead of Pack
abstract: Four of the top seven finishers in the women’s race were American, including last year’s winner — Shalane Flanagan — in third place.
lead_paragraph: Mary Keitany was back where she prefers to be Sunday in the New York City Marathon — far, far ahead of everyone else. Keitany, an Olympian from Kenya, took off alone in the race’s second half and finished more than three minutes ahead of her challengers, with a time of 2 hours 22 minutes 48 seconds. It was her fourth victory here, and the second fastest race any woman has run on this course.

headline: Corrections: November 5, 2018
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, November 5, 2018.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, November 5, 2018.

headline: A Year After Her Breakthrough, Shalane Flanagan Runs On
keywords: ['New York City Marathon', 'Boston Marathon', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Flanagan drew wide admiration last year when she became the first American since the 1970s to win New York. She was supposed to retire. She didn’t.
lead_paragraph: When you are the first American to win the New York City Marathon in 40 years, you have two choices. You could go out on top. Or you could try to defend your hard-fought title.

lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — This is what it’s like being Nancy Pelosi:

headline: ‘What the Constitution Means to Me’ Is Extended
abstract: The play, which ended its run at the New York Theater Workshop, will transfer to the Greenwich House Theater beginning Nov. 27.
lead_paragraph: Heidi Schreck’s “What The Constitution Means To Me” will transfer to the Greenwich House Theater, where it will run from Nov. 27 to December 30, the New York Theater Workshop announced Sunday.

headline: Queens Museum Looks to Liverpool for New Director
abstract: Sally Tallant, a British arts professional, will start next spring as the replacement for Laura Raicovich, who resigned after clashing with the museum’s board.
lead_paragraph: After an unpleasant parting of ways with Laura Raicovich in January, the Queens Museum has named Sally Tallant, a British arts professional, as its new president and executive director, starting next spring.

lead_paragraph: One happy reality of the 2018 campaign for New Yorkers is that they are guaranteed to make history on Tuesday: They will elect the state’s first black attorney general, either Letitia James, a Democrat, or Keith Wofford, a Republican.

headline: Vote, Vote, Vote!
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Charlottesville, Va, Violence (August, 2017)']
abstract: You have to ask yourself: Do you want a Congress full of Trump puppets?
lead_paragraph: Allow me to make a few requests of you in advance of Tuesday’s elections.

headline: Trump’s America: Aggrieved and Adoring Voices From Inside the Presidential Bubble
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'News and News Media', 'Illegal Immigration', 'United States Economy']
abstract: At rallies, the president’s most fervent supporters look past his falsehoods, racially charged statements and attacks on critics. For his party to win Tuesday, he needs them to turn out in droves.
lead_paragraph: HUNTINGTON, W.Va. — In two years, President Trump has reshaped the idea of America for his supporters. They repeat his tweets. They parrot what he says in speeches. Their views on taxes, immigration and the news media are, word-for-word, his views on taxes, immigration and the news media — as endlessly repeated by Fox News.

headline: Three New York City Ballot Proposals, One Worth Supporting
abstract: Lowering campaign contribution limits could blunt the impact of large donations.
lead_paragraph: Voters in New York City will want to turn over their ballots on Tuesday. When they do, they’ll find three proposed changes to the City Charter. All three ballot measures are the result of a charter commission put together by Mayor Bill de Blasio to strengthen the city’s well-regarded campaign finance system and increase the city’s dismal voter participation rates.

headline: What We Have to Fear
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'News and News Media', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: Before the midterms, a trip to Hungary shows the dangers facing the United States.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — The technology conference held here last week could have taken place in almost any other big city in Europe or the United States. It featured executives from Google, Slack, LinkedIn, Airbnb and more. I came to talk about The New York Times’s digital strategy, and I stayed for three days to explore Budapest and interview people here.

headline: The Rohingya's Perilous Return
keywords: ['Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Sending stateless refugees back into the maw of genocide.
lead_paragraph: Two Asian countries have agreed to the repatriation of the Rohingya people displaced to Bangladesh by violent attacks on their homes. Authorities made the plan just days after the United Nations reported that genocide of the Rohingya in Myanmar hasn’t stopped.

headline: A Familiar Force Nurtures Trump’s Instincts on Immigration: Stephen Miller
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Midterm Elections (2018)']
abstract: As President Trump tries again to use immigration fears for electoral advantage, this time with control of Congress at stake, Mr. Miller, his chief policy adviser, is at his side.
lead_paragraph: When self-inflicted damage left Donald J. Trump’s poll numbers sagging shortly after the Republican National Convention in 2016, the solution was to reframe the race around an incendiary issue that has animated Mr. Trump for decades: immigration.

headline: Reimposing Iran Sanctions, Trump Places 3 Bets (One a Long Shot)
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Mr. Trump is gambling that Iran will not restart its nuclear program, that Europeans will not risk violating the sanctions, and that the Tehran government will return to the negotiating table.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the United States reimposes severe economic sanctions on Iran early Monday, President Trump is placing a series of bets that he can not only change Iran’s behavior, but also use American economic power to bludgeon reluctant allies into joining him.

headline: ‘Outlander’ Season 4 Premiere Recap: No Good Deed Unpunished
abstract: Claire and Jamie find themselves in colonial America, facing new enemies and an uncertain future.
lead_paragraph: “Outlander” ended last season with Claire and Jamie shipwrecked on the American coast, bringing with them a mess of a past and no idea of their future. More than just a shift in geography, however, Season 4 represents a new age for Claire and Jamie. Their dynamic feels settled, maybe for the first time. It’s a novel experience to watch them discuss eight-year plans and give presents they assume they’ll live long enough to use. Caitriona Balfe and Sam Heughan are well-suited to this, giving Claire and Jamie a gentle married-couple telepathy that neatly sketches the state of their relationship.

headline: Brent Taylor, Utah Mayor Killed in Afghanistan, Was on 4th Deployment
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Mayors', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Major Taylor, who died Saturday in an apparent insider attack, was helping train Afghan troops and staying in touch with his North Ogden constituents on social media.
lead_paragraph: NORTH OGDEN, Utah — The call had come again. Brent Taylor, the mayor of North Ogden and a major in the Utah National Guard, would be going to Afghanistan for his fourth deployment.

headline: Review: A ‘Waiting for Godot’ as Comically Futile as a Looney Tune
abstract: Garry Hynes’s very funny interpretation of Samuel Beckett’s best-known work finds the kinetic cartoon humor in existential futility.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever paused to consider the spiritual and physical affinities between the desolate universe of Samuel Beckett and the wacky world of vintage Warner Brothers cartoons? Me neither. Or at least not until I saw the Druid Theater’s production of Beckett’s “Waiting for Godot,” part of the White Light Festival at Lincoln Center.

headline: Review: Lenny Bruce’s Shifting Legacy, in ‘I’m Not a Comedian’
abstract: Ronnie Marmo wrote and stars in this bioplay about the groundbreaking comic, who died in 1966.
lead_paragraph: Ronnie Marmo’s new solo show opens cold with its punch line. And a tragic one it is: Mr. Marmo is sitting on a toilet, naked and motionless. It is an arresting still life of Lenny Bruce’s death, by morphine overdose, in 1966. What follows is essentially a 90-minute setup.

headline: Review: ‘American Son’ Puts Kerry Washington in a Maternal Nightmare
abstract: As a black mother with a son in danger, Ms. Washington is up against a situation she may not be able to fix.
lead_paragraph: Some great performances come with elaborate costumes or prosthetic noses attached. Some involve crackerjack timing or floods of tears.

headline: Andrew Lincoln Says Goodbye to ‘The Walking Dead.’ For Now.
abstract: In a wide-ranging interview, Lincoln, who left the AMC zombie thriller on Sunday night, discusses his time on the series, controversial twists and why “The Walking Dead” is a story of hope.
lead_paragraph: This interview includes spoilers for Sunday night’s episode of “The Walking Dead.”

headline: ‘The Deuce’ Season 2 Finale Recap: Consolation Prizes
abstract: As the bodies and tragedies piled up, the season closed with some stark reminders about who controls the bottom line.

headline: 15 False or Misleading Claims in Trump’s Georgia and Tennessee Rallies
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: The president falsely said Democrats “want to take away your health care” and misstated when he appeared on “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” among many other dubious remarks in campaign rallies on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Trump is repeating a misleading claim from Brian Kemp, the Georgia secretary of state and Republican candidate for governor running against Ms. Abrams, a Democrat. Mr. Kemp has repeatedly distorted comments Ms. Abrams made during an Oct. 9 campaign event, in which she called for the “blue wave,” which Democrats hope will sweep them into power, to be inclusive.

headline: China Seeks Allies as Trump’s Trade War Mounts. It Won’t Be Easy.
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations', 'Politics and Government', 'Foreign Investments', 'Customs (Tariff)']
abstract: President Xi Jinping kicks off a Shanghai event showing a growing Chinese appetite to buy from the rest of the world. Even critics of the U.S. have doubts.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Faced with mounting American tariffs that could slow China’s already weakened economy, President Xi Jinping is pressing the case to the rest of the world that China can be a positive force for global trade.

headline: Why Do We Destroy What Makes Us?
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Politics and Government', 'Population', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: A historic part of Cairo is being razed. Its demolition means the loss of heritage buildings — and of characters and customs.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — There is a district close to the center of downtown Cairo that extends from the banks of the Nile about one kilometer into one of the city’s most significant historic thoroughfares. Known as Maspero Triangle, it’s a wedge-shaped area of some 85 acres that has been home to 18,000 residents — until this year, when the government started forcibly evicting what residents it could by cutting off water and electricity, and then bulldozing buildings to the ground.

headline: Bare Knuckle Bouts in Madagascar? ‘It Is About More Than the Fighting’
abstract: The sport of moraingy, a brutal mixed martial arts tradition in Madagascar, has become commercialized over the years, but at heart, it remains a reflection of local culture.
lead_paragraph: SAMBAVA, Madagascar — The devoted fans make their way to dusty outdoor rings surrounded by grass huts and palm trees. They take their seats on makeshift wooden benches and through song and lots of cheering, glorify the gladiators of moraingy, Madagascar’s brutal bare-knuckle fighting tradition.

abstract: Juliette Robert set out to photograph women priests and bishops, who signified a powerful contrast to the conservative Catholicism Ms. Robert had known.
lead_paragraph: Raised Roman Catholic in France, Juliette Robert saw similarities between her childhood faith and the Church of Sweden. It’s not totally surprising, since Sweden’s Lutheran church was among those that split from Rome during the Reformation.

headline: You Can See What? Neighbors Take Tate Modern to Court Over Privacy
abstract: Owners of luxury apartments near the London museum have sued over a viewing platform they say offers a “relentless” invasion of privacy.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The 10-floor viewing terrace of the Tate Modern art gallery in London has a 360-degree view of the city, including some of its most famous landmarks.

headline: SoftBank Chief Won’t Shun Saudi Arabia Despite Killing
abstract: Masayoshi Son, the chief executive of Japan’s SoftBank Group, condemned the murder of the journalist Jamal Khashoggi but added that “we cannot turn our backs on the Saudi people.”
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of the SoftBank Group of Japan denounced the killing of a prominent dissident in a Saudi consulate in Turkey — but said he would not cut ties with the Saudi Arabian government.

headline: How to Eat Safely and Travel With an Autoimmune Disease
abstract: Travel is stressful enough without worrying that sampling the local specialties will make you ill or ruin your trip. Here are some tips to help.
lead_paragraph: Most medical professionals categorize travel as a stressful event, even more so for those suffering from autoimmune diseases like inflammatory bowel, celiac, Hashimoto’s or psoriasis. A change of routine, jet lag, and unfamiliar germs or foreign food can exacerbate one’s condition.

headline: Peer Review: The Worst Way to Judge Research, Except for All the Others
abstract: A look at the system’s weaknesses, and possible ways to combat them.
lead_paragraph: Even before the recent news that a group of researchers managed to get several ridiculous fake studies published in reputable academic journals, people have been aware of problems with peer review.

headline: For a Child’s Cough, the Best Medicine Is No Medicine
abstract: Instead of over-the-counter products, pediatricians recommend comfort measures like fluids and honey.
lead_paragraph: Parents are often disappointed or even a little bit upset when I tell them there’s no medicine to help their coughing, sneezing, drippy-nosed children feel better. There’s nothing that works, I say, and medicines can have bad side effects. We don’t recommend any of the cough and cold medications for children under 6.

headline: Need a Flu Shot? Get It Now
abstract: Immunity tends to wane by 20 percent a month, leaving those who got their shot in August or September with less than desirable protection by the time they’re exposed.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve waited until now to get your flu shot, your procrastination may actually pay off, though you’d be unwise to delay getting the vaccine any longer.

abstract: For years, Republicans in this state have attempted to undermine the foundation of democratic government: the vote.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Emblazoned on the front page of the website for Vote.org, which was founded in 2008 to increase voter turnout, there’s a quotation from Ronald Reagan: “For this Nation to remain true to its principles, we cannot allow any American’s vote to be denied, diluted, or defiled. The right to vote is the crown jewel of American liberties, and we will not see its luster diminished.”

headline: In Ports Everywhere, It’s Push Versus Pull
abstract: It’s more efficient for tugboats to nudge barges along, but some conditions require that the loads be towed.

headline: Mystery in a Small Town: A Quiet Couple Shot Dead, Their Daughter Missing
abstract: James and Denise Closs, who had worked at the Jennie-O turkey plant for years, were found dead. Their daughter, Jayme, vanished. And a town is on edge.
lead_paragraph: BARRON, Wis. — Cows and corn and silence stretch out on either side of Highway 8, beyond the Jennie-O turkey plant and 10 churches that serve this town of just over 3,400. So when James and Denise Closs, a quiet couple who had lived in town for decades, were found shot to death in their taupe house last month, residents were stunned. It was an agonizing loss of two lives, but also of a way of life.

headline: The Subway Bomber’s Journey to 42nd Street, Captured on Camera
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Stations and Terminals (Passenger)']
abstract: Nearly a year ago, Akayed Ullah was charged with detonating a bomb in the New York City subway. Evidence presented at his trial last week showed how security cameras recorded his every movement.
lead_paragraph: He looked like just another straphanger, traveling from Kensington, Brooklyn, into Manhattan. But authorities claim his intentions were to terrorize, and even kill, his fellow commuters. Now, because of widespread security surveillance, with thousands of public and private security cameras on the streets, and in subway stations and apartment buildings, it’s possible to witness the journey he took on that frightening day.

headline: How a Group of Gay Male Ballet Dancers Is Rethinking Masculinity
abstract: These men are finding new stages on which to express their queerness, collapsing gender barriers in the world of dance.
lead_paragraph: When I was 15, I met a dancer from Canada’s Royal Winnipeg Ballet. The company had come to Los Angeles to dance in the Olympic Arts Festival, and my parents volunteered to host a post-performance dinner in our backyard. I recall about 200 people — family friends, Olympic officials and maybe 25 dancers — eating curry (is that right?) off paper plates. But that’s not what this is about. No, this is about the ballerino — my word for him — I met and what he represented to a lonely gay kid in Southern California in 1984, a kid who had never before met another gay person. Earlier that evening, I had seen the dancer turn, leap and smile onstage, expressing through the mute language of ballet who he was. Something about his movement told me he was gay, and I felt he was dancing not only for himself but for me. Onstage, the ballerino wore brown tights that showed the trunks of his thighs, and everything else. Now he was in loose linen pants with a drawstring belt and an open collar that exposed the rod of his clavicle.

lead_paragraph: When I was a freshman at the University of California, Riverside, in 1988, I drove a carload of excited fellow Vietnamese students to nearby Orange County. It was only 13 years after the end of the Vietnam War, but already there was a Vietnamese American Dream, symbolized by our destination, the Asian Garden Mall in Westminster. To the strains of Vietnamese pop music, we ate Vietnamese food, browsed Vietnamese goods, and sat in the balcony of the American-style mall, sipping Vietnamese iced coffee while we watched Vietnamese people.

headline: An Oyster Plate Collection That Started With Martin Scorsese
abstract: Robin Standefer, a co-founder of the Manhattan interior design company Roman and Williams, first encountered the specialized dish in the ’90s.
lead_paragraph: Robin Standefer, who (with husband Stephen Alesch) founded the Manhattan interior design company Roman and Williams (their projects include New York City’s High Line Hotel and Upland restaurant), first encountered Victorian oyster plates as a 29-year-old consultant on Martin Scorsese’s 1993 film “The Age of Innocence.” Her job was locating Gilded Age table settings, and these majolica shellfish plates made in Staffordshire, England, by Minton were a must-have in upper-class homes of the 1860s on both sides of the Atlantic. A few years ago, when Roman and Williams were asked to redo the British galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, she saw the plates again and began collecting. Today, Standefer has amassed 20 of the jewel-tone platters, with their sea-creature embellishments and contoured divots (you shuck the bivalves and slide them onto the plate, shell-less). Recently, she has put a few up for sale at the Guild, a retail outpost she and Alesch opened last year in SoHo. “They’re magical,” she says, “and tell a story of the world at a certain time.”

headline: The British Turkeys Are Coming
abstract: KellyBronze heritage turkeys are heading to the Chelsea Market, just in time for Thanksgiving.
lead_paragraph: For several generations, KellyBronze heritage turkeys have been bred in England and preferred by chefs like Jamie Oliver. In 2014, the company established a 130-acre farm in Crozet, in the Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia, and it is the only commercial turkey farm that holds a Department of Agriculture license to dry-age and hand-pluck its birds. The free-roaming pampered turkeys, more flavorful than the average bird, are available somewhat more widely this year, always fresh, from the company’s website and, for New Yorkers, at Dickson’s Farmstand Meats in Chelsea Market.

headline: A Thanksgiving Centerpiece for the Sweet Tooth
abstract: This ample chocolate bird is worthy of a spot on the dessert buffet this holiday.

headline: Savory Cookies to Whet the Appetite
abstract: The Rounds, a new cookie made in Brooklyn, come in flavors like parmesan-olive, Cheddar-chive and anchovy-scallion.
lead_paragraph: In a way, Anna Harrington was one of the lucky ones. When Pilotworks, a chain of incubator kitchens, suddenly closed last month, it left 175 small food producers in New York and elsewhere without professional kitchen space. Ms. Harrington, who makes savory and sweet cookies called the Rounds, was scheduled to begin working at Pilotworks in Brooklyn, but it closed two days before she was going to start. She found a different commercial kitchen. “I am in much better shape than the producers who have been in there for a long time and have to move all of their things on very short notice,” she said. “The only nice thing about a crisis such as the current Pilotworks situation is how much people are willing and happy to help each other.” Ms. Harrington’s savory cookies are buttery, appetite-whetting and delicious, perfect for holiday entertaining in flavors like parmesan-olive, Cheddar-chive and anchovy-scallion.
