abstract: The Crimson Tide are making a mockery of college football. Can anyone give Alabama a game?
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — Alabama’s Crimson Tide are now college football’s Golden State Warriors.

headline: Andrea Bocelli Dethrones ‘A Star Is Born’ for His First No. 1 Album
abstract: The Italian tenor used a bundle of his new album with concert tickets to achieve his first chart-topper on the all-genre Billboard 200.
lead_paragraph: It took 26 albums, but Andrea Bocelli, the Italian tenor who has embodied the popular side of classical music and opera for two decades, has finally reached the top of the all-genre Billboard 200 chart.

headline: Historical Fiction That Takes Children to War Zones and Internment Camps
abstract: With settings as diverse as a Native American boarding school and the Battle of Okinawa, these books tell stories that are nuanced, honest and new.
lead_paragraph: In the past few years, children’s literature has become more committed to diversity, and lately we’re seeing more “Own Voices” books, whose authors share their protagonists’ marginalized identity. The best of this season’s historical fiction demonstrates why all kinds of diversity are important, with writers from varied backgrounds using settings we’ve seen before — a Native American boarding school, a World War II internment camp in Texas, Okinawa, Chicago during the Great Migration — to tell stories that are nuanced, honest and new.

headline: Never Butter a Muffin Tin Again
abstract: New silicone baking molds make muffins, loaves and Bundts without the need to grease a pan.
lead_paragraph: Oh, the baking! For parties, it’s often best to make small bites to serve as hors d’oeuvres and desserts. Silpat, the French company that produces nonstick baking mats and molds, has just introduced a collection for baking diminutive muffins, loaves, madeleines and Bundts, along with regular-size muffins. They’re made from food-grade silicone mesh (no greasing required), release their products easily and rinse out like new. But you do need a baking sheet to put under them in the oven.

headline: Spice Girls Are Back (Minus Victoria Beckham): 6 Things in Pop Culture Today
abstract: What you need to know in TV, music and movie news this Monday.
lead_paragraph: What would you like to see here? Email us at popculture@nytimes.com.

headline: Love’s Baby Soft Was Just the Beginning
abstract: Pricey perfumes are being made for small children. Yay?
lead_paragraph: First came mini-me designer clothing and handbags. Then the wee fancy jewelry (Van Cleef Sweet Alhambra, anyone?). Now you can buy a bottle of high-end perfume marketed especially to little girls, and maybe to some nonconforming boys (remember Jenna Lyons painting her son’s toenails pink?).

headline: What Is the Needle?
abstract: And other questions about our live election forecasts.
lead_paragraph: The needle is one way of following election results.  House is here; Senate is here.

headline: A Centrist and a Liberal Test Florida, and Democrats Everywhere Watch Closely
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, Governors', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senator Bill Nelson seeks re-election as a moderate, while Andrew Gillum runs for governor as an unabashed progressive. Presidential hopefuls will take notice.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The senior senator came out first, all drawl and political muscle memory — the man with the golden-est hair in the room and an entrance song, “Eye of the Tiger,” from 1982.

headline: Review: A Sex Scandal Upends a Campaign in ‘The Front Runner’
abstract: Hugh Jackman plays Gary Hart in Jason Reitman’s real-life morality play.
lead_paragraph: Senator Gary Hart’s second presidential campaign began on April 13, 1987, with an idealistic oration amid the natural grandeur of Red Rocks, Colo. It ended a little more than three weeks later in a Denver hotel ballroom with a bitter excoriation of the press and the political process.

abstract: The annual gala, a high point of the Los Angeles fall social calendar, was presented by Gucci and brought together Hollywood directors, actors and artists.
lead_paragraph: The annual gala, a high point of the Los Angeles fall social calendar, was presented by Gucci and brought together Hollywood directors, actors and artists.

abstract: This book recounts the scientific discoveries that have given us a better understanding of the heart.

headline: The 5 Shows We’re Most Excited About at the New York Comedy Festival
abstract: The 15th annual event features major names but our writer is looking forward to lesser known acts like Bassem Youssef and “Facial Recognition Comedy.”
lead_paragraph: The 15th annual New York Comedy Festival, which starts Monday, features a dense lineup of improv, sketch and stand-ups of varying levels of fame.

headline: Poland Elections Reveal a Deeply Divided Nation
abstract: The populist ruling party, Law and Justice, lost in almost all cities, but it gained ground in provincial assemblies.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Despite making major gains in provincial assemblies, Poland’s populist ruling party suffered a sweeping defeat in municipal voting in a set of elections that concluded on Sunday, confirming that Poland is a nation ever more deeply divided between its liberal cities and its conservative countryside.

headline: How the Midterms Made Us Feel: Afraid, Then Upset
abstract: The midterm election has been divisive and difficult for many Americans. Now that it’s coming to an end, how do we feel? This live map shows reactions from readers across the country through Election Day.
lead_paragraph: The midterm election has been divisive and difficult for many Americans. Now that it’s coming to an end, how do we feel? This live map shows reactions from readers across the country through Election Day.

headline: Iran Sanctions and Oil Prices: Who’ll Feel the Pain?
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Markets have taken the Trump administration’s move in stride so far. But experts differ on whether a reduction in output could yet prove disruptive.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The world’s oil producers and their customers entered a new period of uncertainty on Monday as renewed American economic sanctions against Iran took effect.

headline: His Three Loves: Photography, Art History and Lisa
abstract: A plain glass vase, a few simple flowers. The photographer Abelardo Morell offers a paean to his feelings — and evokes a cavalcade of art heroes.
lead_paragraph: Back in February 2014, the eminent American photographer Abelardo Morell found himself getting tired of the same old thing — that thing being his annual ritual of gifting Lisa A. McElaney, his wife and partner of almost 40 years, with a bouquet of flowers on the occasion of her birthday. (Truth be told, Lisa, herself a distinguished filmmaker and social worker, may not have been all that thrilled at the prospect either.) So instead he hazarded something altogether fresh: a photo of a gift of flowers.

headline: What America Owes Frederick Douglass
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Reconstruction Era', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: He said black people had three tools: their voice, their pen and their vote. Today all three are under threat.
lead_paragraph: In the introduction to Frederick Douglass’s second autobiography, “My Bondage and My Freedom,” published in 1855, his friend James McCune Smith wrote that if a stranger landed in the United States and sought out its most prominent men by using newspapers and telegraph messages, he would discover Douglass. Born a slave in Maryland, Douglass had escaped to the North to become a renowned abolitionist orator and writer. He was, Smith said, the sort of person people would ask, “‘Tell me your thought!’ And somehow or other, revolution seemed to follow in his wake.”

headline: Aretha Franklin Gospel Film Finally Has a Release Date, 46 Years After It Was Made
abstract: An Oscar push is planned for “Amazing Grace,” which captures a transcendent performance by the Queen of Soul at a Baptist church in Los Angeles in 1972.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — One of Hollywood’s holy grails, “Amazing Grace,” capturing what is considered to be Aretha Franklin’s most transcendent gospel performance, is headed to theaters 46 years after it was filmed.

headline: Artificial Intelligence Hits the Barrier of Meaning
abstract: Machine learning algorithms don’t yet understand things the way humans do — with sometimes disastrous consequences.
lead_paragraph: You’ve probably heard that we’re in the midst of an A.I. revolution. We’re told that machine intelligence is progressing at an astounding rate, powered by “deep learning” algorithms that use huge amounts of data to train complicated programs known as “neural networks.”

headline: 6 Types of Misinformation to Beware Of on Election Day. (And What to Do if You Spot Them.)
keywords: ['Rumors and Misinformation', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Social Media', 'Text Messaging', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Be careful of rumors and hoaxes about the voting and polling places. Here are some tips for spotting and avoiding false information.
lead_paragraph: • Go here for updates from around the country on Tuesday.

headline: Review: In Alexei Ratmansky’s ‘Bayadère,’ Mostly Good Revelations
abstract: Reconstructing Marius Petipa’s “La Bayadère” for the Staatsballett Berlin, Mr. Ratmansky makes it fluent but it’s still uneven.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — What’s a classic and why? The Russian ballet “La Bayadère” (1877) was largely unknown in the West until the 1960s, when its Shades scene was danced, out of context, by the Kirov (now the Mariinsky) and then the Royal Ballet.

headline: One Conference Is Working the System to Get More Teams in the N.C.A.A. Tournament
abstract: Come February, the top teams in Conference USA will face off only against other top teams, in hopes of improving their strength of schedule.
lead_paragraph: When fans of Conference USA men’s basketball teams look at their schedules for the coming season, they will see a curious twist in February: The dates of the games are set, but not the opponents. It is part of a new, innovative approach designed to finally get the conference an elusive second N.C.A.A. tournament bid.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Season 6 Is Getting Mixed Reviews: Here’s What to Read
abstract: Kevin Spacey’s departure created some difficult problems for the writers to solve. How did they do? We’ve rounded up the best of what’s being said.
lead_paragraph: What do you think of the final season of Netflix’s “House of Cards”? Read what everyone else is saying and share your own thoughts in the comments section. Watch out for spoilers ahead.

abstract: A reader suggests that true love may not be about finding the perfect soul mate.

headline: Two Ways of Looking at Philip Glass’s ‘Satyagraha’
abstract: The opera, a meditation on the life of Gandhi, has gotten simultaneous productions at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and Los Angeles Opera.
lead_paragraph: Productions of Philip Glass’s opera “Satyagraha,” a meditation on the life of Mohandas K. Gandhi and his philosophy of nonviolent resistance, always seem to arrive right on time.

headline: Review: In ‘Relations,’ 3 Choreographers Improvise Like Family
abstract: Ralph Lemon, Bebe Miller and Ishmael Houston-Jones supported, teased, challenged, embraced, nurtured and grappled with one another in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Ralph Lemon, Bebe Miller and Ishmael Houston-Jones have been friends for a long time, since at least the early 1980s. But until a few days ago, these celebrated choreographers had never danced with one another in front of an audience. How had this not happened before? And will it happen again?

headline: Justices Seem to Support Virginia’s Uranium Mining Ban
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Uranium', 'Federal-State Relations (US)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The case concerns a clash between a federal law that oversees uranium production and a state moratorium that by its terms addresses only extraction.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the largest known deposit of uranium in the United States was discovered in the 1970s in Pittsylvania County, Va., state lawmakers were wary. After some investigation, they imposed an indefinite moratorium on uranium mining.

headline: Lykke Li Shares a Spicy Seafood Recipe, and a Cocktail to Go With It
abstract: When she entertains at home, the musician and actress often whips up aguachile, inspired by a trip to Mexico City, and serves it with mezcal.
lead_paragraph: In “One Good Meal,” we ask cooking-inclined creative people to share the story behind a favorite dish they actually make and eat at home on a regular basis — and not just when they’re trying to impress.

headline: Ask Science Times
abstract: For the 40th anniversary of Science Times, we invite readers to ask questions about all things science: space, medicine, environment, animals, genetics, archaeology — you name it. Ask away!
lead_paragraph: For the 40th anniversary of Science Times, we invite readers to ask questions about all things science: space, medicine, environment, animals, genetics, archaeology — you name it. Ask away!

headline: Cancer Society Executive Resigns Amid Upset Over Corporate Partnerships
abstract: The American Cancer Society’s fund-raising alliances with Herbalife and others have stirred concerns, and influenced the departure of its chief medical officer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A top official of the American Cancer Society has resigned in part because of concern over some of the organization’s fund-raising partnerships.

headline: Introducing ‘Work Friend,’ an Advice Column on Careers and Money and Other Gigantic Pains
abstract: Submit your questions, and get devilish yet practical advice from an evolving cast of confidants. First up: Choire Sicha.
lead_paragraph: Work Friend is here to help with careers, money and the sometimes grim, sometimes hilarious Dungeons & Dragons-type maze that is the contemporary office. We want to help you scheme your way to where you want to be.

headline: China’s Leader, Hogging Spotlight, Elbows Communist Titan Aside
abstract: In a significant propaganda shift, Xi Jinping’s rise has come at the expense of Deng Xiaoping, long hailed as the architect of China’s prosperity.
lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China — Shortly after taking over as China’s leader, Xi Jinping made a pilgrimage to lay a wreath at a large bronze monument to one of his predecessors, the man credited with ushering in the country’s new era of capitalist prosperity 40 years ago, Deng Xiaoping.

headline: Will Harping on Immigration Do What Trump Wants It to Do?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: The president’s unrelenting focus on migrants may prove ineffective because voters have already sorted themselves out along partisan lines.
lead_paragraph: In the closing days of the campaign for the midterms, President Trump has clearly decided that immigration should be the central issue of this election. Mr. Trump called a caravan of Central Americans heading toward the United States it “an assault on our country” and asserted without evidence that it includes “bad people” and “unknown Middle Easterners.” He accused Democrats of having “something to do with it.” He floated the idea of ending birthright citizenship for children born in the United States to undocumented immigrants. He circulated an ad about a Mexican man convicted of killing two police officers that said, “Democrats let him into our country.”

headline: Backlash From 2008 Is on the Ballot in 2018
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Presidential Election of 2008', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: In Obama’s era, democracy done in good faith struggled. For his demagoguing opponents, that remains the whole point.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago yesterday, 240,000 spectators nestled in Chicago’s Grant Park and millions tuning in worldwide huddled together and watched a lithe, elegant African-American man stroll victoriously across a shimmering stage with his beautiful young family to accept the challenge of leading the free world. He opened his speech wryly asking, “If there is anyone out there who still doubts that America is a place where all things are possible, who still wonders if the dream of our founders is alive in our time, who still questions the power of our democracy, tonight is your answer.”

headline: One Legacy of Merkel? Angry East German Men Fueling the Far Right
keywords: ['Men and Boys', 'Politics and Government', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: Germany is again divided between east and west. To understand why, it helps to look at eastern men, who lost their jobs and their country as many women fled west.
lead_paragraph: EBERSBACH-NEUGERSDORF, Germany — Frank Dehmel was on the streets of East Germany in 1989. Every Monday, he marched against the Communist regime, demanding freedom and democracy and chanting with the crowds: “We are the people!”

headline: William J. Murtagh, Lion of Historic Preservation, Dies at 95
abstract: Trained in architecture, he became the first “keeper” of the National Register of Historic Places, created teaching programs and wrote a leading text book.
lead_paragraph: William J. Murtagh, the first designated “keeper” of the National Register of Historic Places and a paladin among preservationists, died on Oct. 28 in a retirement community in Sarasota, Fla. He was 95.

headline: Twitter Says It Is Ready for the Midterms, but Rogue Accounts Aren’t Letting Up
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: On the eve of the midterm elections, Twitter — like other social media companies — is still struggling to combat misinformation.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter created a team to automatically seek out suspicious activity, like thousands of messages intended to suppress the vote. It began coordinating closely with the Department of Homeland Security. And it recently introduced a tool to help people more easily report misleading tweets.

headline: Important European Financial Firm Bows to Trump’s Iran Sanctions
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Belgium’s Swift sits at the heart of the global financial system. Under pressure from the United States, it is cutting off Iranian banks. The European Union is not pleased.

headline: Dogs Can Detect Malaria. How Useful Is That?
abstract: Canines can sniff out the socks worn by children carrying the mosquito-borne parasites, a study found.
lead_paragraph: Dogs have such exquisitely sensitive noses that they can detect bombs, drugs, citrus and other contraband in luggage or pockets.

headline: AMC Promotes Sarah Barnett After Losing an Executive to Fox
abstract: The company behind “The Walking Dead” and “Breaking Bad” is in need of the next big show. On Monday, it promoted from within to fill a big vacancy.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Barnett, the head of BBC America, will take on an expanded role at AMC Networks that puts her in charge of several cable channels, including AMC, SundanceTV and IFC, the company said on Monday.

headline: Trump’s Expected Meeting With Putin to Be Delayed
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates']
abstract: President Trump said on Monday that he would not meet with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia during a visit to Paris this weekend.
lead_paragraph: CAPE GIRARDEAU, Mo. — President Trump said on Monday that a meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia expected to take place this weekend in Paris would be delayed, possibly until later in the month when both are planning to attend an international summit meeting in Buenos Aires.

headline: Former Belgian King Ordered to Give DNA for Paternity Test
abstract: A court in Brussels gave King Albert II of Belgium three months to give a DNA sample to determine whether he is the biological father of artist Delphine Boël.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Delphine Boël grew up certain that she should be a princess. Now a court ruling and a DNA test could make it true.

headline: Another Use for A.I.: Finding Millions of Unregistered Voters
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Start-ups']
abstract: Jeff Jonas, a prominent data scientist, has used his software for a multistate project to identify eligible voters and to clean up voter rolls.
lead_paragraph: The mechanics of elections that attract the most attention are casting and counting, snafus with voting machines and ballots and allegations of hacking and fraud. But Jeff Jonas, a prominent data scientist, is focused on something else: the integrity, updating and expansion of voter rolls.

abstract: The move is considered a last resort for the U.S.O.C. and essentially allows for the national committee to take over operations of the sport’s governing body.

Gymnastics of its power as a national governing body, sending waves of relief through a sport struggling to right itself after a devastating sex abuse scandal.

headline: 4 Takeaways From the Trump-Era Plunge in Corporate Penalties
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Corporations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: The Times examined financial penalties imposed on banks and big companies in the Trump and Obama administrations. The difference is in the billions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: At a time when the Trump administration is loosening rules established in the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis, financial penalties imposed on companies and big banks accused of wrongdoing have fallen precipitously since the Obama administration, according to analyses by The New York Times.

headline: Tiniest Ape Ever Discovered Hints at the Rise of the Monkeys
keywords: ['Monkeys and Apes', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Teeth and Dentistry', 'Evolution (Biology)', 'Paleontology', 'Fossils']
abstract: The newly identified extinct primate weighed slightly less than an average house cat.
lead_paragraph: A tiny fossilized molar found nestled in the sweltering shrub land of Kenya’s Tugen Hills belonged to what may be the smallest species of ape yet discovered, according to a new study. The newly identified extinct species, Simiolus minutus, weighed only about 8 pounds, or slightly less than an average house cat.

headline: Midterm Canaries: Races to Watch for Early Trends
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: In the On Politics newsletter, races we’ll be watching for an early idea of how the election is trending; plus, final thoughts from our live polls.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Sinister Doings at a Luxury Spa? Must Be a New Liane Moriarty Novel
abstract: In a setup that calls to mind Agatha Christie, the title characters of “Nine Perfect Strangers” convene at a remote resort with a rather severe proprietress.
lead_paragraph: At least Liane Moriarty’s new novel pampers her fans with its escapist premise. Wouldn’t it be nice to spend 10 days deliquescing at a spa named Tranquillum House, which sounds like a flower crossed with a state of bliss? That’s what the “Nine Perfect Strangers” of Moriarty’s latest book do, oblivious to even the most obvious warning signs.

headline: Industries Turn Freedom of Information Requests on Their Critics
keywords: ['Tax Preparers and Preparation', 'Freedom of Information Act', 'Law and Legislation', 'ACADEMIC FREEDOM']
abstract: Corporations, lobbyists and interest groups are increasingly using public records laws as weapons in dealing with academic work they do not like.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Dennis J. Ventry Jr., a law professor at the University of California, Davis, drew the ire of tax preparation companies like Intuit and H&R Block this summer by criticizing a deal they have to provide a free tax filing service through the Internal Revenue Service.

abstract: The big day has arrived.

headline: Federal Officials Shut Down Sales of ‘Ruinous’ Health Insurance Plans
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission said a Florida enterprise collected millions with a deceptive marketing scheme aimed at Americans searching for health coverage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal authorities have shut down a network of Florida companies that they say used aggressive, deceptive tactics to sell skimpy health insurance products that skirt requirements of the Affordable Care Act and left tens of thousands of people around the country with unpaid medical bills.

headline: Larry Drew Gets His Security, Agreeing to New Deal With Cavaliers
abstract: Asked to fill in after the firing of Tyronn Lue, Drew caused a stir by rejecting the interim label. Now he is simply their head coach.
lead_paragraph: Larry Drew no longer has to worry about being the “voice” of the Cleveland Cavaliers, the acting coach, or any other atypical distinction. He will simply be their head coach, the team announced Monday.

headline: Last Exit Off the Road to Autocracy
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Midterm Elections (2018)']
abstract: Taxes and health care aren’t the only things on the ballot.
lead_paragraph: Whatever happens in the midterms, the aftermath will be ugly. But the elections are nonetheless a fork in the road. If we take one path, it will offer at least a chance for political redemption, for recovering America’s democratic values. If we take the other, we’ll be on the road to autocracy, with no obvious way to get off.

headline: Do Democrats Know What Unites Us?
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Immigration Detention', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: They have failed to offer a response to Trumpian nationalism.
lead_paragraph: National identity is the most powerful force in world politics today. Most of the strong leaders around the world were swept to power with a strong nationalist story and govern in nationalist ways. This is true in Russia, China, India, the U.S., Israel, Turkey, Britain, Brazil and on and on. It’s hard to see how any party could appeal or govern these days without a strong national story.

headline: End Yemen’s Agony
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Stop the bombing and start a large-scale relief effort.
lead_paragraph: Though much remains clouded in the murder of the Saudi journalist-in-exile Jamal Khashoggi, this much is clear: Saudi Arabia’s rulers are ruthless and not to be trusted or believed. It is now time to recognize those realities in the kingdom’s unspeakably cruel war in Yemen. The Trump administration has been prodded into demanding a cease-fire, but that seems only to have provoked new fighting. The United States, Britain and other enablers of the Saudi campaign can and must demand an immediate halt to the carnage.

headline: Ruth Gates, Who Made Saving Coral Reefs Her Mission, Is Dead at 56
abstract: A marine biologist, Dr. Gates worked to develop a “super coral” to resist the deadening effects of warming ocean waters.
lead_paragraph: Ruth Gates, a renowned marine biologist who made it her life’s work to save the world’s fragile coral reefs from the deadening effects of warming water temperatures, died on Oct. 25 in Kailua, Hawaii. She was 56.

headline: Fighting for Stacey Abrams and Empowerment in Georgia
abstract: More than 100 years ago, black domestic workers in Georgia organized for better pay. Now they’re getting out the vote for a groundbreaking candidate.
lead_paragraph: All across Atlanta, hundreds of domestic workers have been knocking on doors for Stacey Abrams, the Democratic candidate for Georgia governor, hoping to turn her into first black woman in that role.

headline: How to Be a More Patient Person
abstract: Relax. It’s going to be O.K.
lead_paragraph: My jaw clenches when Hulu videos buffer. I huff and puff when stuck in a sluggish line at a coffee shop. Slow cars in the fast lane send me into a curse-filled tizzy. I’m ashamed how quickly I lose my cool over these minor things. I’ve often wished I could be a more patient person, but it’s overwhelming to know where to start.

He refused, telling a local radio host, “It really diminishes democracy if you’re going to show up to a meeting to just scream and yell.” Instead, he said, he was appearing on “every national TV show,” as if that were a substitute for facing his constituents.

Solvers teach each other, and many constructors mentor those who would like to try their hands at puzzle-making. Anyone who gets anywhere in a profession understands that they stand on the shoulders of those who came before them.

headline: Business Reaches a Turning Point
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: At last week’s DealBook conference, companies and executives agreed that corporations can no longer operate without considering their larger societal impact.
lead_paragraph: “I think as a group of business leaders, we have to think about the impact to our society of what’s happening in the political discussions in our country.” That’s what Kenneth C. Frazier, the chief executive of Merck & Co., said last week, just days before the midterm elections. It was the crystallization of a theme that has emerged louder than ever over the past several years among a c-suite that for much of the last half century tried to avoid politics and considered its role in society in simple terms: delivering profits to shareholders, often at the expense of other constituencies.

headline: Give Gig Economy Workers Equity? The S.E.C. Is Considering It
abstract: Contractors like Uber drivers can’t receive stock in private companies. But that could soon change, in a move supported by tech companies.
lead_paragraph: The gig economy has created economic opportunities for millions of people. Uber and Lyft have empowered everyday drivers to become paid chauffeurs. Airbnb has made homeowners hoteliers. And TaskRabbit has opened new markets for handymen and other laborers.

headline: Do Americans Dislike ‘Partisan’ Politics, or Just Other Partisans?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: It’s easy to nostalgize some postwar golden age of political consensus. But the divisions that followed were more intentional than some might think.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to think of a figure whose place in public life has been scrambled quite so fully in the past two years as John Brennan’s. As recently as last year, Brennan was serving as President Obama’s C.I.A. director — a political appointment that, by virtue of its awesome power, is supposed to exist at some remove from partisan politics. This has subsequently made Brennan one of the more alarmed and strident critics of Donald Trump — a president for whom the idea of anything existing outside partisan politics seems inconceivable — and of his Republican allies in Congress.

headline: Can We Disinherit Our Addicted Son?
keywords: ['E-Learning', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Plagiarism', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Wills and Estates']
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on leaving your addicted son money and reporting a teacher who is duplicating course material.
lead_paragraph: Our son has been a heroin addict for 10 years. He has drifted in and out of homelessness and prison. We have spent a fortune on rehab, counseling, legal fees and more, which changed nothing. We love our son, but we have also painfully learned that he is an inveterate liar, will steal anything not nailed down and has an incredible capacity for manipulation. We are in the process of updating our wills to reflect this reality, and we are struggling to articulate a fair plan as to inheritances. Our other children are living normal, happy, productive lives. Under other circumstances, we would split everything equally among our children, but for our addicted son, this would be like throwing gasoline on a fire. Even the process of distributing family treasures is fraught, knowing our son would head straight to a pawnshop. We are thinking of putting his share into a trust to be used exclusively for his future health needs, rehab and, hopefully, sobriety. But again, we love our son, and it is heartbreaking to realize we are essentially leaving him nothing tangible. What is the ethical thing for us to do? Name Withheld

headline: Crossing Paths With Meghan and Harry, and Missing the Plane to Paradise
abstract: In New Zealand, our columnist immerses herself in Maori culture. Then rain, traffic and a lost (and found) passport complicate what should have been an easy trip to Fiji.
lead_paragraph: Our columnist, Jada Yuan, is visiting each destination on our 52 Places to Go in 2018 list. This dispatch brings her to two places: Rotorua, New Zealand, which took the No. 45 spot on the list; and Fiji, which took the No. 24 spot. They are the 44th and 45th stops on Jada’s itinerary.

headline: New & Noteworthy
abstract: A selection of books published this week; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: KEEPING AT IT By Paul A. Volcker with Christine Harper. (PublicAffairs, $28.) Volcker was chairman of the Federal Reserve through most of the 1980s, a period of American prosperity. In this memoir, he recounts his life story as well as the economic booms and busts he has seen along the way. IN MY FATHER’S HOUSE By Fox Butterfield. (Knopf, $26.95.) Finding a unique way to examine the issue of mass incarceration in the United States, Butterfield, a Pulitzer Prize-winning former Times reporter, delves into the experience of one family, the Bogles, and how prison has become a legacy for them passed from parents to children over multiple generations. CHRONIQUES By Kamel Daoud. (Other Press, $28.95.) Daoud is the francophone journalist and author of “The Meursault Investigation,” which retold the story of Albert Camus’s “The Stranger.” In this collection of his columns from the Algerian newspaper Le Quotidien d’Oran, he writes about the trials and tribulations of Arab society teetering between change and entrenchment. ALMOST EVERYTHING By Anne Lamott. (Riverhead, $20.) Lamott seeks reasons for hopefulness at a moment when, like many of us, she finds herself most often “doomed, stunned, exhausted and overcaffeinated.” WHY JOURNALISM STILL MATTERS By Michael Schudson. (Polity, paper, $22.95.) One of the most important media scholars of our time, Schudson approaches the business of making news from a sociological and historical perspective, offering a new way to think of questions that bedevil us every day.

headline: Are You Voting for the First Time on Tuesday? We Want to Hear From You
abstract: If this is your first time voting in a U.S. election, tell us your story.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday marks the end of voting in one of America’s most anticipated midterm elections in years. But for one subset of voters, this election is not just a battle for control of Congress and state governors’ offices. For those who are casting a ballot for the first time, today is also a personal rite of passage.

headline: A Profusion of Diagnoses. That’s Good and Bad.
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Sleep', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Fibromyalgia', 'Insomnia', 'Testosterone', 'Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder', 'Doctors']
abstract: With millions of Americans taking risky medications for questionable diagnoses, have we medicalized everyday life?
lead_paragraph: I recently cared for a hairdresser who had gone through a year of vague and varied symptoms. What started as a few unpleasant aches soon became debilitating pain throughout her body. A heavy fatigue settled into her bones: Holding scissors or sweeping the floor became too much. She slept fitfully; her memory flagged. Frustrated by many symptoms and few answers, she grew anxious and depressed.

headline: The Eton Mess, a Classic Dessert for Endless Variation
abstract: Cranberry jam, lemon curd and ginger turn this typically warm-weather dessert into a fall or winter treat.
lead_paragraph: I got my first baking job through a friend of a friend of a friend and lost it a month or so later. I had no experience as a baker, no training, but I got lucky: The restaurant, the long-gone Soho Charcuterie, needed an extra pair of hands when my name came up. I was hired on the spot and given two specific jobs to do each day: make 100 chocolate cookies and bake a few chocolate cakes with whiskey and raisins. As both of the house specialties were similar to recipes I’d made at home, all went well. And then, one day, I had what I thought was a good idea. Without telling anyone, I made the cake with a few changes: I substituted Armagnac for the whiskey, pecans for the almonds, and prunes, not everyone’s favorite fruit, for the raisins. That’s when I was fired for “creative insubordination.” If I’d been less defeated, I might have seen that the real reason I was fired was that I was caught being myself.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Women’s Clothing
abstract: What’s labeled as for men or for women doesn’t have to be.
lead_paragraph: Last year, I walked into an upscale independent clothing store in Berlin and greeted the conservatively dressed, bespectacled woman hovering in the back. I’d seen a stylish male mannequin in the window, but it wasn’t clear that they sold men’s clothing, so I asked. “It’s all for everyone,” she said. “I mean, technically that rack and this rack are men’s, but I believe it’s outdated to think like that.”

headline: Dr. Leana Wen Dislikes the Politicization of Health Care
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning']
abstract: The new president of Planned Parenthood on patient advocacy, conspiracy theories and why it’s insulting when anti-choicers call themselves “pro-life.”
lead_paragraph: You are the new president of Planned Parenthood. What were some of your first exposures to the clinic? My mom was a patient when I was a kid, and I volunteered as a patient escort when I was a medical student. I remember thinking: What kind of world do we live in where, in order to get health care, women — and men, but mainly women — have to walk through lines of protesters? The politicization of care deeply troubles me. That’s, unfortunately, the reality that we’re in.

headline: Pip and Me: A Journey Into the World of ‘Great Expectations’
abstract: Dickens began his novel in the marshes of the Hoo Peninsula, about 25 miles from London. More than 150 years later, a traveler retraces the path of that book’s indelible characters.
lead_paragraph: It’s a warm morning, the sky is cloudless and the marshes of the Hoo Peninsula, 25 miles downriver from London, are thick with daises and red clover. In the churchyard of St Mary’s in the village of Lower Higham there is a scent of cut grass. The whole scene, in other words, is distinctly un-Dickensian.

headline: Some Hispanics With Jewish Roots Pursue an Exit Strategy: Emigrate to Spain
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Discrimination', 'Genealogy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A number of Hispanic Jews are taking Spain up on its invitation for citizenship. Some say it’s a response to growing racism in the United States.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — Ana Maria Gallegos’s family has called this part of the West home for centuries. But after growing horrified by the resurgent racism she has seen across the United States, she reviewed her options and decided on a plan: emigrate to Spain.

headline: Why a Book Tour Is More Brutal Than a Political Campaign
abstract: The former congressman Steve Israel thought he had a tough skin, but that was before he wrote a novel.
lead_paragraph: During the course of eight successful campaigns for Congress in my Long Island district, I was called every imaginable name by unhappy voters, including, but not limited to, idiot, Communist, socialist, liberal (what’s worse than that?), Pelosi puppet, Obama lackey and Bush sellout. I was criticized as too progressive, too conservative, too middle-of-the-road. In 2010, when Tea Party fever swept through congressional districts, I sat in a slow-moving convertible, waving to crowds at a Memorial Day parade. People waved back, many with one particular finger. Then there was my Town Hall on the Affordable Care Act. The crowd of 3,000 became so inflamed that a contingent of local police had to escort me to my car. I didn’t let any of it get to me. I brushed it off. In a swing district with about as many Democrats as Republicans — but all opinionated New Yorkers — dealing with voter rejection had become second nature.

headline: Google Workers Reject Silicon Valley Individualism in Walkout
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Organized Labor', 'Strikes', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: Last week’s protest could be a sign that highly-paid workers are losing patience with the technology industry’s worldview and embracing collective action.
lead_paragraph: The most remarkable aspect of the walkout at Google last week may not have been that an estimated 20,000 people participated or that it had global reach, or even that it came together in less than a week. It was the way the organizers identified their action with a broader worker struggle, using language almost unheard-of among affluent tech employees.

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Home Repairs and Improvements']
abstract: A Manhattan pied-à-terre gets a muscular makeover.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Bonsignore wasn’t planning on buying an apartment in Manhattan, because he already had a home in the Westchester County village of Bronxville. But as a partner at Altman, Greenfield & Selvaggi, an accounting and business management firm in Manhattan catering to entertainers and celebrities, he began spending some work nights in the city.

headline: What Do North Korean Gymnastics Say About Kim Jong-un’s Politics?
keywords: ['Gymnastics', 'Politics and Government', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: North Korea included something new, a giant image of China’s leader, Xi Jinping, at a mass gymnastics performance on Sunday, and excluded something old: missiles.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — For North Korea experts, virtually every detail in the authoritarian state is a potential window into the political priorities of its elusive leader, Kim Jong-un.

headline: ‘Love Island’ in the Land of Gender Equality
abstract: Versions of the hit British TV show in Denmark, Finland, Norway and Sweden also feature well-sculpted singles in a Spanish villa. In other ways, they’re quite different.
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — With two weeks to go before filming began, the producers for Denmark’s version of the TV show “Love Island” were finalizing the opening cast list. The day before, they had rejected a promising candidate — a gorgeous skateboarder with a penchant for World of Warcraft — because they feared she wasn’t emotionally mature enough to live under the glare of dozens of cameras for six weeks.

headline: After Man-Eating Tiger Is Killed in India, a Backlash Against the Hunters
abstract: Villagers were relieved when T-1, a tigress believed to have killed 13 people, met her end. But animal rights advocates, and some politicians, reacted with fury.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Days after a man-eating tiger was shot dead in central India, a backlash is underway, with politicians and animal rights advocates denouncing the killing and a senior government minister threatening legal action against people involved in the hunt.

headline: Where Is My Polling Place? Answers to Common Election Day Questions
abstract: It’s time to vote. Here are answers to some questions you may have about casting a ballot on Tuesday.

headline: China Grants Ivanka Trump Initial Approval for New Trademarks
abstract: The 16 new trademarks cover a broad array of goods and services, including purses, swimsuits, fire extinguishers and senior citizens’ homes.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China granted initial approval for 16 new trademarks to Ivanka Trump, the president’s elder daughter and senior adviser, renewing questions about the Trump family’s intermingling of official roles and international business interests.

headline: Mitt Romney Goes to Washington After All
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Elections, Senate', 'Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Missionaries']
abstract: The soon-to-be senator from Utah will have to decide when and how to make common cause with Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: The latest polling in Utah’s senate race has Mitt Romney up by some 36 points over Jenny Wilson, his Democratic opponent. Barring an enormous upset, Mr. Romney will join the United States Senate. This will put him a few checks and balances away from a president — the leader of his party — whom he once called “terribly unfit for office.”

headline: New York Today: Now Vote
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'State Legislatures', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Tuesday: Casting ballots, more showers and a flashback to New York’s first female voters.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday, it’s Election Day and it’s time to vote.

headline: One Wave, Two Waves, Red Wave, Blue Wave
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (2017)', 'Midterm Elections (2018)']
abstract: Who ever thought midterm elections could be this exciting?
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Bret, can you remember any other Election Day that was ever like this? With the whole nation so crazy nervous-excited about congressional races? I do not believe in other years I had intense conversations with neighbors about who was going to win the Indiana Senate race.

headline: James Comey: Let’s Vote to Uphold Our Nation’s Values
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Nineteen Hundred Twenties']
abstract: The lying, misogyny, racism and attacks on the rule of law from our president are awakening the vast middle of American politics.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been traveling around the United States for six months speaking about ethical leadership. Nearly every place I go, I hear some version of this question: “Are we going to be O.K.?” What the questioner means is, given the current leadership of our country and the ugly undercurrent on which it thrives, is America as we know it going to survive? Yes, is the answer I give, without hesitation. We will recover. How long that takes is up to us, but I am optimistic.

headline: Riled Up and Ready to Vote
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Youth', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Gun Control', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', "Women's Rights", 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Young voters discuss the issues motivating them this year.
lead_paragraph: Young people historically vote at lower rates, typically, than other age groups, and that has been especially true of the midterms. But this year, registration for younger voters is up substantially, with some studies anticipating the highest youth turnout in decades. We wanted to know what issues are motivating young people at such impressive rates this year, so we asked. In just a few days we had more than 800 passionate, sharp and often surprising responses.

headline: Melt Thy Rifles Into Garden Tools
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Pittsburgh, Pa, Shooting (2018)', 'Mennonite Churches']
abstract: A Mennonite blacksmith, following his beliefs, seeks a path to reducing the impact of gun violence in America.
lead_paragraph: The venerable art of blacksmithing is not generally considered to be a radical act. But for Michael Martin, a 36-year-old Mennonite from Colorado Springs, the malleability of glowing metal from a forge’s inferno makes it the perfect vehicle for addressing gun violence.

headline: Are Voting Selfies Legal? Not Always
abstract: How state laws are enforced may depend on turnout and how vigilant poll workers are this year.
lead_paragraph: A great number of Americans are poised to vote on Tuesday and what better way to commemorate the moment than with a selfie in the voting booth: smiling, marked ballot in hand, exercising one’s democratic freedom.

headline: A Field Guide to Today’s Elections
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Voting and Voters', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Gun Control', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: We look at how four major issues — immigration, the Supreme Court, guns and health care — are shaping voters’ choices.

headline: In China, Bill Gates Encourages the World to Build a Better Toilet
keywords: ['Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The Microsoft co-founder’s Reinvented Toilet Expo featured innovative approaches to a global problem — the fact that billions have no access to safe sanitation.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Bill Gates believes the world needs better toilets.

headline: Review: ‘Narcissister Organ Player’ (Partly) Unveils an Artist
abstract: How does a performance artist whose work relies to some degree on anonymity direct an autobiographical documentary?
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn performance artist Narcissister is known for wearing a mask — and sometimes even two, on the front and back of her head — despite often wearing little else. The combination of nudity and anonymity has a jarring effect. That cognitive dissonance, along with Narcissister’s grab bag of props, prosthetics and costumes, which she layers on as if she were a Russian doll, lends her dance pieces a sinister air.

headline: An ‘I Voted’ Sticker Can Get You Free Stuff. (But Is It Legal? Well …)
abstract: Providing voters with any kind of incentive for voting in a federal election is illegal, but law enforcement officials have bigger fish to fry.
lead_paragraph: [See the results for the House of Representatives, the Senate and governors’ races.]

headline: Fox Rebukes Sean Hannity’s and Jeanine Pirro’s Participation in a Trump Rally
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'News and News Media', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: The line between the Trump White House and Fox has always been a little blurry, but in one moment at least, the fusion of president and network seemed complete.
lead_paragraph: CAPE GIRARDEAU, Mo. — The show onstage might well have been called Fox & Friend. As President Trump wrapped up the midterm election cycle with a late-night rally on Monday in southeast Missouri, he was joined by a trio of conservative media rock stars.

headline: From Luxembourg to Mexico to the Warriors: Alfonzo McKinnie’s Wild Ride
abstract: A key player on the champions once got 40 percent off wings as a perk.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Alfonzo McKinnie was not exactly getting rich playing basketball for Rayos de Hermosillo in Mexico’s top league, but his contract did include one perk: 40 percent off wings at a sports bar not far from the arena. So McKinnie would plant himself in front of a big-screen TV with a plate of wings, and watch the Golden State Warriors compete in the N.B.A. playoffs without him, which was understandable since the Warriors had never heard of him.

headline: In Washington State, 3 G.O.P. Districts That Could Flip
abstract: Most of Washington State’s 10 congressional districts lean Democratic, but three of them — now held by Republicans — are in play.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — One district had been a Republican heartland of freight-haulers and timber-workers before a shift toward suburbs and tech. Another was historically Democratic from the power of the railroad unions, then veered toward the Republicans. A third is liberal on its western side, conservative to the east, and locked in a battle over which side will prevail.

headline: Let’s Hear It (Quickly) for the Half-Hour Drama
abstract: With TV culture stuck in binge mode, there’s something to be said for high-stakes, low-commitment series.
lead_paragraph: The new Amazon drama “Homecoming” has a lot going for it. Julia Roberts in her first starring TV role. Bravura directing from Sam Esmail of “Mr. Robot.” A top-notch supporting cast, taut writing and a mind-bending military-corporate thriller plot.

headline: It’s Easy to Feel Cynical About the Midterms. Will We Still Turn Out?
keywords: ['Millennial Generation', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Youth', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: How some young people are thinking about the midterms, politics and hope.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Edit. Each week in our newsletter, you’ll hear from college students and recent graduates about issues going on in their lives. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: Facebook Admits It Was Used to Incite Violence in Myanmar
keywords: ['Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'News and News Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Corporate Social Responsibility', 'Social Media', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The company, citing a human rights report it commissioned, said it was moving to prevent further abuses of its platform in Myanmar. Critics said they were unconvinced.
lead_paragraph: Facebook has long promoted itself as a tool for bringing people together to make the world a better place. Now the social media giant has acknowledged that in Myanmar it did the opposite, and human rights groups say it has a lot of work to do to fix that.

headline: Why Do Asian-Americans Remain Largely Unseen in Film and Television?
abstract: Actors of Asian descent have long either been cast as stereotypes — in embarrassing, demeaning roles — or simply whitewashed out of the picture.
lead_paragraph: THEIR FACES ARE familiar for the feelings of horror and shame they produce in me. Mickey Rooney as Mr. Yunioshi in 1961’s “Breakfast at Tiffany’s,” stumbling around his Manhattan apartment in a blue bathrobe, his face contorted — lips barely closing over grotesquely pronounced buckteeth, slicked-back hair dyed jet black. Ashton Kutcher as a Bollywood producer, Raj, in a 2012 commercial, his skin darkened, a brown mustache affixed to his face, speaking in a cheap singsong voice, swaying his body, which is clad in a bright blue silk sherwani, back and forth to imitate the Indian head waggle. Tilda Swinton, otherworldly in her beauty, as always, but monkishly bald as the Ancient One, a character originally intended to be Tibetan, in 2016’s “Doctor Strange.” More subtle, but still just as shocking: Emma Stone — blonde and green-eyed — as Allison Ng, leaning against a kitchen island in a scene from 2015’s “Aloha” and saying, “My dad was half Chinese, half Hawaiian,” as breezily as if she were saying goodbye to someone on the telephone.

headline: A Runner to Smarten the Table
abstract: These linen beauties — a collaboration between the apron maker Hedley & Bennett and the home goods company Parachute — add warmth to the Thanksgiving dinner.
lead_paragraph: Skip the tablecloth, or even the place mats. These new linen runners, nearly 8-feet long (90 inches) and 16-inches wide, will smarten your holiday table the way a great belt or tie might enhance your outfit. They come in autumnal tones — “merlot” and “curry” — with contrasting edging, but if your tastes are more neutral, there’s also “oat.” And they won’t break the budget. The runners are a collaboration between Hedley & Bennett, which makes aprons and chef wear, and Parachute, a home goods company.

headline: A Queens Bar That Serves CBD-Infused Cocktails
keywords: ['Cocktails and Mixed Drinks', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Restaurants', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'your-feed-onlyinnewyork']
abstract: Adriaen Block calls itself the first restaurant and bar in New York City to serve food and drinks infused with cannabidiol.
lead_paragraph: There are CBD massage parlors, CBD bakeries and even CBD cafes. So it was only matter of time before a bar would join this bandwagon. Adriaen Block, which opened in August, bills itself as the first CBD restaurant and bar in New York City, with four lower-alcohol cocktails infused with cannabidiol derived from hemp.

headline: Voting Problems Surface as Americans Go to the Polls
abstract: Among the areas experiencing problems were polling places in Georgia as Election Day voting began in the race for governor between Brian Kemp and Stacey Abrams.
lead_paragraph: From closed polling sites to malfunctioning machines, Election Day brought frustration for some voters in contests shadowed by questions about the security and fairness of the electoral system.

headline: The Mormon Church vs. Pot
keywords: ['Referendums', 'Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Medical Marijuana']
abstract: If Utah legalizes medical marijuana on Tuesday, it could signal that the church is no longer all-powerful in state politics.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — In September, a billboard appeared near downtown here urging voters to support Proposition 2, an initiative to legalize medical marijuana that is on the ballot Tuesday. Quoting from Mormon Church scripture and its “word of wisdom” about food and drink, the billboard read, “All Wholesome Herbs God Has Ordained for the Use of Man.” In other words, you can use pot for your medical ills and still be a good Mormon.

headline: Can Latin American Democracy Withstand the Populist Assault?
abstract: The region’s democratic systems have been tested by many authoritarian rulers throughout history. But lines of defense against its challengers often do their job.
lead_paragraph: AMHERST, Mass. — It is common to think of Latin America as the land of no hope for democracy. Since independence, the region has been ravaged by authoritarianism and populism. Brazil’s new president-elect, Jair Bolsonaro, an ex-military macho promising zero tolerance of everything he dislikes, evokes a “here we go again” feeling. Once again, illiberalism seems ascendant, to the detriment of democracy.

headline: Inside an Airy Williamsburg Loft Where Patterns Run Wild
abstract: Aqueous abstraction meets barefoot modernism in the Brooklyn home of the couple behind Eskayel.
lead_paragraph: AFTER TOSSING OUT her furniture following a bad breakup with her live-in boyfriend in 2006, Shanan Campanaro, a California-bred artist and graphic designer based in Brooklyn, needed something to mask the emptiness. So the Central Saint Martins graduate took one of the paintings she had been working on in her spare time — a set of antlers rendered in watery ink, from a series about headpieces from crowns to coxcombs — and digitally printed it onto a roll of paper in close repeats. The resulting wallpaper, which evoked the claustrophobic horror vacui of Victorian interiors, thrilled everyone who saw it and became the first pattern produced by Eskayel, the now 10-year-old wallpaper and design company Campanaro runs with her husband, Nick Chacona.

headline: Iran & Saudi Arabia, Thelma & Louise
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Women and Girls', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Shiite Muslims']
abstract: We made two bets, and the Iranians and the Saudis responded with their worst impulses.
lead_paragraph: With each passing day, U.S. policy toward Iran and Saudi Arabia more closely resembles the 1991 film classic “Thelma & Louise.”

headline: Martha Rosler Isn’t Done Making Protest Art
abstract: The artist’s work has been canonized, and feminist slogans are enshrined on T-shirts, but where does that leave her? A retrospective at the Jewish Museum takes us on her journey.
lead_paragraph: “Pretty much everyone hated my work when I made it, except for feminists,” the artist Martha Rosler said, sitting in the living room of her house and studio in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. “I’m used to a minimum 10-year lag before anyone has anything good at all to say about anything I’ve done.”

headline: Erdogan Champions Khashoggi While Trampling Journalists and Dissidents in Turkey
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Political Prisoners', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s demands for justice in the Khashoggi killing have left many deeply conflicted in Turkey, where tens of thousands have been detained in a government crackdown.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has kept the case of Jamal Khashoggi alive through a steady drip of leaks, forcing the Saudis to admit that the columnist and dissident was killed more than a month ago in their consulate in Istanbul.

headline: Abroad in America: The Moment We’ve Been Waiting For
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: This year, Election Day is an extended nationwide slog characterized by hope, anxiety and possibly despair, depending on your point of view.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The New York Times’s international election newsletter, where Sarah Lyall tries to explain the U.S. midterm elections to readers outside the United States (and perhaps to herself).

headline: These College Basketball Players Will Be Fun to Watch (for One Year Only)
abstract: Duke has the top 3, followed by Bol Bol at Oregon. Here are 10 rising stars you’ll be watching play one season of college basketball.
lead_paragraph: The 2018-19 college basketball season begins tonight with a full slate of games filled with the top young players in the country. With changes to draft rules on the horizon, the era of one-and-done in college basketball may be drawing to a close. But for this season at least, the college game will again be dominated by freshmen making brief cameos in college towns across America. Here are the top 10 one-and-done players you’ll be watching in college basketball ... briefly.

headline: A ‘Legacy of Terror’: ISIS Left More Than 200 Mass Graves in Iraq
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Civilian Casualties', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: It may not be much of a surprise, but the scale of the job of digging up Islamic State victims is shocking. The UN says there may be 12,000 victims.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Over 200 mass graves holding as many as 12,000 bodies have been found in areas of Iraq once controlled by the Islamic State, the United Nations said on Tuesday. The findings were highlighted in a joint report released by the United Nations mission to Iraq and the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, which called the sites a “legacy of terror.”

abstract: While a fresh crop of pizzerias are paying homage to the classic New York slice, Mama’s Too is trying to reinvent it.

headline: The New York Slice That Slices Through Tradition, at Mama’s Too
abstract: In the slice revival going on around New York, one pizzeria on the Upper West Side is having a Dylan-goes-electric moment.
lead_paragraph: For most of its time on earth, the New York slice has not been seen as a product that needed tinkering. Yes, pizza in the city has been accessorized with toppings from crayfish (not bad) to Buffalo chicken (hmm) to Caesar salad (no, no, no, no, no). But the foldable, portable triangles of cheese, sauce and dough themselves were generally held to be a natural resource that was perfect as is, much like the soft, unfiltered city tap water claimed to be the source of their excellence. Some pizzerias try to make a better slice. Very few try to make a different slice.

headline: Russians Meddling in the Midterms? Here’s the Data
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Social Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: They haven’t stopped trying to influence our elections. Indeed, they may be busier than ever.
lead_paragraph: Since the 2016 United States presidential election, which Russian operatives influenced through a coordinated campaign of disinformation on social media, platforms like Twitter and Facebook have taken steps to address the problem. Thousands of “sock puppet” personas with hundreds of thousands of followers have been taken down on Facebook, for example, and cannot easily be rebuilt. Twitter has reduced the risk that propaganda is spread through automated accounts, or bots.

abstract: Voters across the country reported a kind of emotional pinballing about the verdict the midterms will deliver, and what it will mean for democracy.

lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany’s interior minister faced calls for his resignation on Tuesday, after his dismissal of a spy chief who had given fuel to right-wing and anti-immigrant sentiment failed to end a monthslong controversy that weakened the government.

headline: How Bridge Banners Became New York’s Rogue Billboards
abstract: Since 1988, no fewer than eight banners have been hung from the Brooklyn, Manhattan, Queensboro, Williamsburg and Robert F. Kennedy Bridges.
lead_paragraph: A witch, a performance artist and a teacher walked onto the north side of the Manhattan Bridge’s bicycle path on Monday, wheeling a 100-foot-long bright pink vinyl banner with one word written on it: vote.

headline: At White House, Trump Watches Loss of House but Wins in Senate
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The president was mostly silent on Tuesday until about 11 p.m., after most votes had been cast and many races had been called across the country.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump spent Tuesday night at a private party in the White House residence, insisting to family and friends that Democratic victories in the House were expected, and focusing instead on Republican Senate wins that were a bright spot on an otherwise grim political referendum on his presidency.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: A Highway Kiss and a Rare Connection
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring five reader-submitted stories of 100 words or fewer.
lead_paragraph: It was way too early to be awake but I had a long commute from Tujunga to Marina del Rey. The 405 was stopped (this was way before ‘La La Land’). Suddenly, the driver door of the car directly in front of my Toyota swung open. The man I had gone out with for the first time the night before emerged and walked toward me. He kissed me through my window then strolled back to his car. Traffic began to move. Now we are both old and married forever. But the memory holds. — Peg Burr

headline: City Center’s Balanchine Festival Lacked a Balanchine Quality: Boldness
abstract: George Balanchine’s early years presented the festival both with an embarrassment of riches and a problem: Could it convey the range and plenitude?
lead_paragraph: George Balanchine was on a roll from 1948, when New York City Ballet was founded as a resident company of New York City Center, to 1964, when the troupe moved to its home at Lincoln Center. Balanchine knocked out great ballets by the dozen. But more extraordinary than quantity was the consistent level of imagination and innovation, outrageously high; and the variety, unbelievably wide.

headline: Movies Lost and Found: ‘Shirkers,’ ‘A Star Is Born’ and More
abstract: Film history is rife with scenes or entire movies missing because of government censors, unhappy studios or even renegade directors.
lead_paragraph: The process of filmmaking has been so established for so long — a well-trod path from script to deal to production to release — that there’s something thrilling, even subversive, about films lost and rediscovered, scenes tossed and restored, and movies that go unfinished for years or even decades. Two long-unfinished projects, Orson Welles’s “The Other Side of the Wind” and Sandi Tan’s “Shirkers,” are now streaming on Netflix; those pictures, an earlier version of “A Star Is Born” and other butchered classics make for fascinating stories of cinematic archaeology.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix Australia in November
abstract: Every month, Netflix Australia adds a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are the titles we think are most interesting for November.
lead_paragraph: Every month, Netflix Australia adds a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are the titles we think are most interesting for November, broken down by release date. Netflix occasionally changes its schedule without giving notice.

headline: As Famine Looms in Yemen, Saudi-Led Coalition Redoubles Attacks
abstract: The surge in fighting follows a U.S. call for peace talks, with the United Nations warning that as many as 14 million people could be at risk of starvation.
lead_paragraph: HUDAYDAH, Yemen — The fight in Yemen has escalated drastically over the past week, exacerbating a dire humanitarian crisis that the United Nations says could spiral into famine — despite, or even because of, a diplomatic push by the United States to get both sides to the peace table.

Brent Taylor, a beloved Utah mayor and National Guard officer who deployed to Afghanistan in January, had often voiced the hope that “everyone back home exercises their precious right to vote,” his wife, Jennie Taylor, recalled on Tuesday morning at Dover Air Force Base in Delaware.

headline: Jonathan Benno Opens His Latest in the Evelyn Hotel
abstract: The chef taps into his French and Italian training, a cocktail bar on the Lower East Side from Oliver Zabar, and other restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Benno’s latest, the crown jewel of his collection of spots in the restored Evelyn Hotel, is finally poised to open. Finally is the operative term here as the chef, who cooked at Per Se and Lincoln Ristorante, said he has been waiting about 30 years to open his own restaurant, spending the past five or so years on this project. The dining room, at the back of the hotel — past his Leonelli Focacceria e Pasticceria and the informal Leonelli Taberna — is fairly intimate, with 45 seats and another 10 at the bar. The décor suggests Art Deco and Modernist design, and includes original walnut woodwork, restored mosaic floors and a dramatic light fixture that hangs from a central skylight. Mr. Benno has tapped his French and Italian training and experience for a Mediterranean menu with a focus on Liguria, in Northern Italy, and Provence, in Southern France. There’s a risotto with squash and chestnuts; skate almondine; olive oil-poached steelhead trout; a terrine of sweetbreads, rabbit and foie gras; and short ribs niçoise-style. Pastas include spaghetti made with burnt wheat (grano arso) and dressed with seafood, lumache with lobster fra diavolo, and classic agnolotti del plin with duck and foie gras. “I could not resist doing the pastas,” Mr. Benno said. The pastry chef, Lindsey Bittner, also taps into Mediterranean fare with a rosemary flan, chocolate babka with pistachio halvah, and pears with goat cheese. (Opens Thursday)

headline: Kavanaugh May Hold Key Vote in His First Death Penalty Case
abstract: A death row inmate in Missouri with a rare medical condition prefers lethal gas to the state’s method, lethal injection, which he said would cause him excruciating pain.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court heard arguments on Tuesday in an appeal from a death row inmate in Missouri with a rare medical condition that he says will cause excruciating pain if he is put to death by lethal injection. Lawyers for the inmate, Russell Bucklew, said his condition, cavernous hemangioma, would make him choke on his own blood during his execution.

headline: The Man Behind Freddie Mercury’s Teeth in ‘Bohemian Rhapsody’
abstract: Chris Lyons of Fangs FX talks about those giant choppers and others projects, including a larger-than-life replica of Björk’s mouth.
lead_paragraph: If you thought Rami Malek’s teeth were big in “Bohemian Rhapsody,” consider this: They could have been even bigger. The giant prosthetic choppers the actor wore to help bring Freddie Mercury to life were made in different sizes, including a set that were the actual size of Mercury’s teeth, but they were a little too large for Malek’s face.

headline: Navy Completes Inquiry Into Strangling Death of Army Green Beret in Mali
abstract: The results of the yearlong investigation, which were not made public, were sent to an admiral who will decide whether charges will be brought.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Navy criminal authorities have completed their investigation into the strangling of an Army Green Beret in June 2017 in Mali, and sent their report to an American admiral who will decide what charges, if any, will be brought in the case, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: A Warning From Seattle to Amazon’s HQ2
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Relocation of Business', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Tech companies and their employees love big cities, but Amazon needs to do better for people who live in any city chosen for its second headquarters.
lead_paragraph: The prune capital of America. That was the future Silicon Valley’s greatest claim to fame in the 1920s, when it was a sleepy landscape of fruit orchards and farms far removed from the nation’s industrial might. Seattle was a city of fishing and timber, where a young entrepreneur named Bill Boeing had so few customers for his airplanes that he briefly pivoted to making furniture. The most innovative companies in the world clustered in the ferociously inventive cities of the East and Midwest — cars in Detroit; cash registers in Dayton, Ohio; light bulbs in Cleveland.

headline: ‘Chalk: The Art and Erasure of Cy Twombly’ Hunts for Big — and Elusive — Game
abstract: Joshua Rivkin allows that his book about the fiercely private Twombly is something “stranger and more personal” than a conventional biography.
lead_paragraph: Spoor is a hunter’s word, for the scent an animal leaves behind in a forest, the scent you track to bag your prey. It might be a biographer’s word, too — the essence of a person that drifts out of his or her diaries and letters, the idiosyncratic, unmistakable traces that a biographer pursues in the archives.

On Saturday evening, a bevy of esteemed film directors crowded the Los Angeles County Museum to honor Guillermo del Toro and Catherine Opie at the eighth annual LACMA Art & Film Gala, presented by Gucci.

lead_paragraph: Time is closing in for those who want to buy the original pages of “Master Race,” one of the most famous comic book stories published by EC Comics, which specialized in horror, crime and suspense tales. The story is up for bid at Heritage Auctions through Nov. 15, with an initial estimate of $150,000.

headline: Ex-Guard, 94, at Nazi Camp Is Tried in German Juvenile Court

lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A 94-year-old man who served as a guard in Hitler’s SS clutched his cane as a bailiff wheeled him into a courtroom on Tuesday for the start of his trial on charges of assisting in the murder of hundreds of the 60,000 people who perished at the Stutthof concentration camp.

headline: Sex, Surrealism and de Sade: The Forgotten Female Artist Leonor Fini
abstract: She rejected art's traditional roles for women, and spent her life blurring the lines of gender and sexuality. So why is she so little-known?
lead_paragraph: The artist Leonor Fini worked tirelessly throughout most of the 20th century, often alongside universally acknowledged masters like Max Ernst, André Breton and George Balanchine. Her paintings and designs were shown in London, Paris and New York over decades. Portraits of her, an eccentric European artiste draped in wild costume at fancy masquerade balls, regularly appeared in magazines like Life.

headline: The Artist and the Fashion Designer Celebrating Black Trailblazers
abstract: In both their separate practices and a recent collaboration, Derrick Adams and Kerby Jean-Raymond seek to reframe black narratives.
lead_paragraph: The fashion designer Kerby Jean-Raymond, known for stylishly addressing race and representation in his designs for his label Pyer Moss, considers his admiration of the artist Derrick Adams born out of a “common belief” — namely, that the trailblazers of black culture must be commemorated. Earlier in the year, Jean-Raymond, 32, launched an ongoing series of clothing collections called American, Also, through which he takes a closer look at the whitewashing of American history. The first installment, for fall 2018, was informed by traditional western wear and referenced black American cowboys, including the 19th-century deputy U.S. marshal Bass Reeves, who many argue was the inspiration for the Lone Ranger.

abstract: Tensions between the most prominent figures of rap were once confined to music. The social media era demands another approach.

There were 10 clips of Cardi filming herself talking into her phone, each more aggrieved than the one before it. The subject: Nicki Minaj and the long-stewing tensions between them.

headline: Kitty O’Neil, Stuntwoman and Speed Racer, Is Dead at 72
abstract: Her deafness was no hindrance as she broke the land-speed record for women, one highlight of a life in daredevilry. “Deaf people,” she said, “can do anything.”
lead_paragraph: On a dry lake in the Alvord Desert in Oregon in December 1976, Kitty O’Neil wedged herself into a three-wheeled rocket-powered vehicle called the SMI Motivator. She gave the throttle two taps to awaken the engine and then watched an assistant count down from 10 with hand signals. At zero, she pushed the throttle down.
