headline: Muriel Manings, Dancer in a Politically Charged Era, Dies at 95
abstract: She was part of the New Dance Group, which infused its dances with left-leaning ideas and sought to bring movement to the people.
lead_paragraph: Muriel Manings, who performed with the left-leaning New Dance Group during the politically anxious middle decades of the last century and later championed dance through teaching and advocacy work, died on Oct. 25 at her home in Manhattan. She was 95.

headline: Robert Indiana Estate to Sell Art Valued at Up to $4 Million
abstract: The executor of the estate, which is involved in several legal issues, said the money will go to pay lawyers and repair the artist’s leaky house.
lead_paragraph: Two major artworks from the collection of the artist Robert Indiana will be offered at auction in New York this month to help pay for his estate’s mounting legal fees and repairs to his former mansion in Maine.

headline: Losers in Amazon Sweepstakes Aren’t Ready to Throw In the Towel
keywords: ['Relocation of Business', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: There were tax breaks. Ads on Seattle buses. Amazon latte art. And, finally, fading hope that the e-commerce giant would be coming to town.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Chicago offered $2 billion in tax breaks. North Carolina wrapped buses in Seattle with a pitch for Raleigh. A Philadelphia coffee chain printed the Amazon logo into the foam of its lattes.

headline: Chris Watts of Colorado Pleads Guilty to Murdering Pregnant Wife and 2 Daughters
abstract: In August, Christopher Watts went on television to beg for the return of his missing wife and daughters. On Tuesday, he admitted that he had killed them.
lead_paragraph: When his pregnant wife and two daughters disappeared this summer, Christopher Watts went on television and begged for their return. “Shanann, Bella, Celeste, if you’re out there, just come back,” he pleaded.

headline: President of Spanish Soccer League Lashes Out at Rivals, and Partners
abstract: Javier Tebas, the president of La Liga, is taking aim at Manchester City, Paris St.-Germain, Real Madrid, UEFA and even his own federation.
lead_paragraph: In a week when Europe’s top soccer executives have hunkered down amid a wave of unprecedented leaks, the leader of Spain’s league took the opportunity to go on the attack.

headline: Sean Hannity Erased a Line by Taking the Stage With Trump

Trump for President campaign announced that Sean Hannity would appear at his rally on the eve of the midterm elections, the prime-time star of Fox News posted a Shermanesque tweet: “I will not be on the stage campaigning with the president.”

headline: Andy Barr Defeats Amy McGrath in Kentucky House Race, Buoying Republican Hopes
abstract: Representative Andy Barr defeated his well-financed Democratic challenger, Amy McGrath, on Tuesday, buoying Republican hopes of minimizing their losses.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Ky. — Representative Andy Barr, an incumbent Republican, defeated one of the Democratic Party’s most prominent challengers, Amy McGrath, on Tuesday in a deeply conservative district here, according to The Associated Press, giving his party hope of limiting losses in the race for control of the House.

headline: Two Years and Hundreds of Inflammatory Ads Later, the G.O.P. Is the Party of Trump
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Political Advertising', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Regardless of the outcomes, Republican candidates embraced the divisive, racially inflammatory messages of President Trump in 2018, folding up the party’s Big Tent.
lead_paragraph: The Republican Party’s post-mortem after Mitt Romney lost his presidential bid to Barack Obama in 2012 was brutally straightforward: Expand the tent or risk extinction. “We need to campaign among Hispanic, black, Asian and gay Americans and demonstrate we care about them, too,” party leaders wrote.

keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government']

headline: America Votes (Or Tries To)
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Voting Machines', 'Voting and Voters', 'Politics and Government', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The good news — and bad news — about long lines on Election Day.
lead_paragraph: Neighbors greeted one another in line. Strangers commiserated over the weather. Volunteer poll workers scoured voter rolls and processed ballots. On Sixth Avenue in Brooklyn, a state judicial candidate stood smiling on a street corner in the early-morning drizzle, introducing himself over and over to voters who he knew would probably forget his name five minutes later.

headline: Cuomo Wins Third Term in New York as Democrats Consolidate Control in Albany

lead_paragraph: Andrew M. Cuomo was resoundingly elected to a third term as governor of New York on Tuesday, riding Democratic enthusiasm in a deep blue state to beat back his Republican challenger and capture a victory for the party’s old guard.

headline: Cannupa Hanska Luger Wins New $50,000 Arts Prize
abstract: The artist is the inaugural winner of the Museum of Arts and Design’s Burke Prize for contemporary craft.
lead_paragraph: The artist Cannupa Hanska Luger has been selected as the winner of the inaugural Burke Prize for contemporary craft, the Museum of Arts and Design announced Tuesday. The prize constitutes a cash award of $50,000.

headline: Get Ready to Run

lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — I love it when I can travel from my seat. I love it when I can actually go places, of course, but when you travel from your armchair, there is no air travel to contend with, no lines to wait in and no unpacking to do when you get home.

lead_paragraph: CARLSBAD, Calif. — Two years ago, the Yankees were clamoring for starting pitching, and Chris Sale — a young, elite pitcher on a team-friendly contract with the Chicago White Sox — was on the market.

headline: Democrats Capture Control of House; G.O.P. Holds Senate
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Governors', 'States (US)']
abstract: Republicans were on track to add to their Senate majority, defeating Democratic senators and holding onto Texas by beating back Representative Beto O’Rourke
lead_paragraph: Democrats harnessed voter fury toward President Trump to win control of the House and capture pivotal governorships Tuesday night as liberals and moderates banded together to deliver a forceful rebuke of Mr. Trump, even as Republicans held on to their Senate majority by claiming a handful of conservative-leaning seats.

headline: Conservatives Oust Tony Clement After He Admits Sending Explicit Images
abstract: Mr. Clement acknowledged sending sexually explicit photographs and video to a woman, but said he had believed she had consented to it.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — A former cabinet minister and current member of Parliament was asked to leave the Conservative caucus on Wednesday after acknowledging he had sent sexually explicit photographs and a video to a woman over a three-week period.

headline: Heidi Heitkamp Ousted by Republican Kevin Cramer From North Dakota Senate Seat
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', 'Voting and Voters', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: Representative Kevin Cramer, an early supporter of President Trump, defeated Senator Heidi Heitkamp in North Dakota, buoying Republican chances of holding the Senate.
lead_paragraph: WEST FARGO, N.D. — Representative Kevin Cramer, who latched onto Donald J. Trump even before he was president and never let go, ousted North Dakota’s incumbent Democratic senator, Heidi Heitkamp, on Tuesday, flipping a key seat that was vital to Republican efforts to hold the Senate.

headline: Andrew Gillum Concedes to Ron DeSantis in Florida Governor’s Race
keywords: ['Elections, Governors', 'Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters', 'Midterm Elections (2018)']

lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — Ron DeSantis was elected governor of Florida on Tuesday, handing President Trump an important victory and extending the Republican Party’s dominance in the nation’s third-largest state.

headline: Pennsylvania Democrats Pick Up Victories 2 Years After Trump Wins State
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, Governors', 'Midterm Elections (2018)']
abstract: The biggest factor in the state’s congressional elections was redistricting: Democrats were all but set to net two Republican seats after congressional maps were redrawn.
lead_paragraph: DOYLESTOWN, Pa. — Pennsylvania voters, who went for President Trump two years ago, swerved in the other direction Tuesday, handing Democrats key victories and swelling the party’s share of the state’s House delegation.

headline: Laura Kelly, a Kansas Democrat, Tops Kobach in Governor’s Race
abstract: Ms. Kelly relentlessly tied her opponent, Kris Kobach, to former Gov. Sam Brownback, whose socially conservative policies became very unpopular.
lead_paragraph: TOPEKA, Kan. — Kansas voters rejected the sharply conservative message of Kris W. Kobach, a Republican known for fiery warnings about election fraud and illegal immigration, and instead elected State Senator Laura Kelly, a Democrat, as governor of their red-leaning state.

headline: Democrats Oust Walker in Wisconsin and Kobach in Kansas but Fall Short in Florida and Ohio
abstract: Over all, the Democrats reclaimed six governor’s seats from the G.O.P., including pickups in Michigan and Illinois.
lead_paragraph: Democrats wrested control of governorships from Republicans in seven states on Tuesday including Wisconsin, where they ousted Scott Walker after eight tumultuous years as the state’s chief executive, and Kansas, a surprise victory in a longtime Republican stronghold.

headline: Two Years After Trump’s Victory, Voters Erect an Impediment to His Power
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In handing Democrats the House majority, voters in urban and suburban districts ended one-party rule in Washington and decided to curb President Trump’s power.
lead_paragraph: The vaunted blue wave that Democrats had hoped for failed to fully materialize on Tuesday night, but the days of one-party control in Washington are now over. President Trump’s strength in rural areas kept the Senate in Republican control, but voters in urban and suburban districts across the country sent the White House a clear message: They want a check on the president.

headline: Josh Hawley Defeats Claire McCaskill in Missouri Senate Race
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Josh Hawley, the Republican candidate, ousted Claire McCaskill from the Senate, a key victory for his party that helped solidify its control of the chamber.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Beating back a liberal suburban groundswell that proved lethal to many House Republicans, Josh Hawley claimed victory here on Tuesday over Senator Claire McCaskill, toppling one of Senate Democrats’ last remaining moderate voices, The Associated Press said.

headline: A Partisan War Awaits Trump. That Just Might Suit Him.
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Combative by nature, happier in a fight, the president may now have to choose between escalating the conflict that has torn Washington apart in recent years and trying to reach across the aisle.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump will wake up on Wednesday morning to a radically new political environment as he confronts the prospect of a two-year partisan war with a Democratic-run House armed with subpoena power and empowered to block his legislative agenda.

headline: Gavin Newsom Is Elected Governor of California
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Governors', 'Elections, State Legislature']
abstract: Mr. Newsom will now take over a state that has openly resisted the agenda of President Trump.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Gavin Newsom, the Democratic former mayor of San Francisco, was elected governor of California on Tuesday, marking the ascension of an avowedly liberal leader who will now take over a state that has openly resisted the agenda of President Trump.

headline: Democrats Take Control of New York Senate for First Time in Decade
keywords: ['Elections, State Legislature', 'State Legislatures', 'Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)']

headline: The Thrill of a Women’s Wave
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government', "Women's Rights", 'Midterm Elections (2018)']
abstract: Watching anti-Trump female candidates win is exciting, but I’m worried about all they’re being asked to do.
lead_paragraph: Enormous turnout. A record number of women running — and winning, some of them in squeak-out victories unseating incumbents and turning red districts blue. Mikie Sherrill, who talked about her time as a Navy pilot and mother of four on the campaign trail, won in New Jersey. Elaine Luria and Abigail Spanberger both won in Virginia. Lauren Underwood won in Illinois. In the Kansas governor’s race, Laura Kelly beat Kris Kobach, one of the nation’s leading architects in voter suppression.

headline: The Democrats Won the House. Now What?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Midterm Elections (2018)']
abstract: For starters, pick policy battles wisely.
lead_paragraph: With the House of Representatives in Democrats’ control, the next two years will give them the opportunity to show that there’s a better model of legislating, that Congress is capable of doing more for Americans than cutting taxes for the wealthy and menacing everyone else’s health care. Now and again Democratic leaders may need to play constitutional hardball — and they’ll have a chance to do it in a more constructive fashion than Mitch McConnell and his team, who have dominated Congress since 2014.

headline: Midterms Deliver an American Stalemate
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A rebuke to President Trump in the overall returns, but not a presidency-ending repudiation. Two years of chaos and hysteria ending in a return to standoff.
lead_paragraph: For once, it all happened more or less as we foresaw — and by “we” I mean risk-averse political commentators who hugged the polling averages and projections tight while resisting both Betomania and the occasional flashbacks to 2016. A good night for Republicans in the Senate. An excellent night for Democrats in the House. The Trumpian Upper Midwest swinging back toward Democrats. Red-state senate voters sticking with the G.O.P. The mobilize-the-base strategy falling just short for Democrats in Florida and Georgia. A rebuke to Trump in the overall returns, but not a presidency-ending repudiation. Two years of chaos and hysteria ending in a return to stalemate.

headline: The Success in Beto’s Failure
abstract: O’Rourke gave Texans who have long felt disenfranchised a glimpse of what could be.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The condolence emails are already coming in, from New York, and California, and from my neighbors down the street, who are mostly limiting themselves to unprintable but predictable four-letter words. Yes, Beto O’Rourke lost to Ted Cruz, 51-48 percent, an outcome that surprised almost no seasoned politicos around these parts — they’ve been predicting it for months, some since the congressman from El Paso first announced his candidacy last year. Rest assured that the Monday-morning quarterbacking will proceed apace starting … now.

headline: The Election Showed a Divided Country. Investors Can Live With That.

headline: How to Play Dead
abstract: Let your mouth go slack. Stare at a fixed spot (even through your eyelids). Avoid the operatic gesture.
lead_paragraph: “The secret is to have your mouth slightly open,” says Brian Blessed, 82, a British actor who played the Roman emperor Caesar Augustus in the 1976 BBC television series “I, Claudius.” In his much-lauded death scene, the camera stays in close on Blessed’s face as he slowly succumbs to poisoned figs and then remains cadaver-like for nearly three solid minutes. A slack mouth forces your body into a sleepy limpness and allows you to take tiny, imperceptible breaths. To be convincing, you must not visibly breathe, swallow, blink or let your eyes or body convey any of the twitchy, lit-from-within traits of the living.

headline: You Already Email Like a Robot — Why Not Automate It?
abstract: Google is helping relieve the knowledge workers of the world from the drudgery of email — by revealing how inhuman it was in the first place.
lead_paragraph: In 1996, Microsoft unleashed Clippit, better known as Clippy, on users of Microsoft Office. The legendarily irritating mascot-helper spent the following years hovering around the edges of documents, blinking dumbly under his lascivious eyebrows and blurting out, “It looks like you’re writing a letter,” until he was sidelined by the company in 2001, officially recognized as a mistake. Clippy’s problems were manifold. He announced his presence, via a personified avatar, to tell us something that we already knew (or that should have been obvious in the first place) and then proudly offered us little in the way of actual help. He sat and watched us and learned nothing, and repeated himself. He said too much and did too little.

headline: What if the Placebo Effect Isn’t a Trick?
abstract: New research is zeroing in on a biochemical basis for the placebo effect — possibly opening a Pandora’s box for Western medicine.
lead_paragraph: The Chain of Office of the Dutch city of Leiden is a broad and colorful ceremonial necklace that, draped around the shoulders of Mayor Henri Lenferink, lends a magisterial air to official proceedings in this ancient university town. But whatever gravitas it provided Lenferink as he welcomed a group of researchers to his city, he was quick to undercut it. “I am just a humble historian,” he told the 300 members of the Society for Interdisciplinary Placebo Studies who had gathered in Leiden’s ornate municipal concert hall, “so I don’t know anything about your topic.” He was being a little disingenuous. He knew enough about the topic that these psychologists and neuroscientists and physicians and anthropologists and philosophers had come to his city to talk about — the placebo effect, the phenomenon whereby suffering people get better from treatments that have no discernible reason to work — to call it “fake medicine,” and to add that it probably works because “people like to be cheated.” He took a beat. “But in the end, I believe that honesty will prevail.”

headline: Glossier Will See You Now
abstract: With a new permanent New York shop, the online beauty brand that could explores a brave new world: offline.
lead_paragraph: The clean, well-lighted place is glowing. Even from the sidewalk, even without windows you can see through. There it is on Lafayette Street, a salt lamp of retail real estate, a frosted beacon. There is a name-printed banner flying above, but if you are coming here, you probably don’t need it. You already know, deep in your pores, that you are at the new Glossier flagship store.

headline: The Key to This Creamy, Thick Pesto? A Mortar and Pestle
abstract: I traveled to the proud home of basil pesto to learn the secrets of the sauce from a lifelong pounder.
lead_paragraph: Throughout my time working in restaurants, I developed an illogical dread of some basic kitchen tasks. None of them — picking and chopping parsley, peeling and mincing garlic, browning pans of ground meat — were particularly difficult. But at the scale required in a professional kitchen, they felt Sisyphean. And even though it has been years since I worked in a restaurant and I now cook for one, two, sometimes maybe eight, rather than 100, the dread still plagues me. But once I get going, I am a goldfish, invariably surprised that chopping, browning or peeling for a handful of people takes barely any time.

headline: What Gives the Logo Its Legs
abstract: Logomania is an obsession with no end in sight. Here’s why.
lead_paragraph: At a party last month, Gabriela Silvarolli embraced the full Fendi.

headline: How Meditation Might Help Your Winter Workouts
abstract: Some simple techniques might shore up our commitment to being physically active as the seasons change.
lead_paragraph: For many of us, the shorter, chillier days of autumn can dampen our enthusiasm for exercise. But a new study suggests that some simple techniques might shore up our commitment to being physically active as the seasons change, and one of them, surprisingly, is to learn to meditate.

headline: How to Ski for Less This Winter
abstract: The apps and strategies for singles, families and flexible travelers who want to beat the crowds to the slopes, and still not pay too much.
lead_paragraph: If I may borrow a phrase: Winter is coming. And with that comes holidays, family gatherings and vacation time. Ski vacations are certainly popular during the winter months, but they’re not always easy to plan. Furthermore, prepping for a ski getaway can vary wildly, depending on whether you’re a single professional or a couple with children; if you’re hemmed in by specific dates or have a good deal of flexibility in your schedule. Below are tips for your next ski trip no matter what your profile — and while it won’t necessarily be cheap, there are ways to make it more affordable.

headline: What We Don’t Know About Amazon’s Split HQ2
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Relocation of Business', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Land Use Policies', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Site details? Incentives? Much of the process has been secret, and local officials and developers signed nondisclosure agreements.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — For more than a year, Amazon searched for a second headquarters, a home to as many as 50,000 workers that would be coequal to its current home in Seattle. Instead, Amazon is closing in on deals to split what it called HQ2 into two locations, according to people briefed on the discussions. The company appears ready to move to Long Island City in Queens, according to two of the people. It is also close to a deal to move to a spot in Arlington, Va., just across the Potomac River from Washington, one of the people said.

headline: Five Places to Go in Jerusalem
abstract: Jerusalem’s city center has transformed into a vibrant scene, with youthful, often tattooed habitués offering a curious juxtaposition to the religious pilgrims roaming the Holy City.
lead_paragraph: In the city center, just a 15-minute walk from the cobblestone alleys of the Old City of Jerusalem, trendy restaurants and boutiques — even coffee bars that double as late-night performance venues — have blossomed.  Their youthful, often tattooed clientele offer a curious juxtaposition to the religious pilgrims roaming the Holy City. A growing tech scene — there are upward of 500 start ups in the city — has fueled the metamorphosis. So have art schools, with about 2,500 students combined; many of those students are remaining  thanks to city and nonprofit spaces supporting arts-minded entrepreneurs. The city’s creative energy is on full display at Machane Yehuda Market, also in the city center. In recent years, the 19th-century, open-air market for spices, meat, flowers and produce has had a second shift at sundown when it transforms into a lively night life scene with frequent D.J.-hosted events. In this sprawling labyrinth, artisan beer halls, tapas and falafel stands, and upscale restaurants open their graffiti-adorned garage-style doors to welcome the city’s multi-culti cool kids.

Of course, they didn’t always cooperate, but Mr. Trump was also able to push forward his agenda using the presidency’s unilateral powers — to deregulate, start trade wars and expel undocumented immigrants — and his power to appoint conservative judges with the consent of the Senate.

The Soviet tanks that rolled through Budapest also brought an end to the belief of many intellectuals and artists here in the ideals of Communism.

headline: Thanksgiving Deer Hunt? Sounds Like a Great Time to Talk to the Kids About Guns
abstract: When your child expresses anxiety about a family tradition filled with firearms, it’s worth having a discussion about it.
lead_paragraph: We were finalizing our travel plans for Thanksgiving, which we spend with my family in Vermont. Our 13-year-old son, who usually loves going, was hesitant about the trip this year, but he wouldn’t say why. So, we asked his older sister to investigate; they’re close. She told us his reluctance has to do with a family deer hunt that the men and boys go on the morning after the holiday. We told him he didn’t have to go hunting, but he doesn’t want to be around guns at all. Any advice for dealing with this?

headline: This Danish Designer Wages Battle Against Tasteful Nordic Grays
abstract: Nadia Olive Schnack’s Copenhagen home mixes unexpected, even clashing hues with an almost anarchic disrespect for convention.
lead_paragraph: BY AGE 10, Nadia Olive Schnack had already come to regard the tasteful neutrality of Scandinavian interiors with disdain. Unbidden, the self-taught Danish designer, now 39, closed her bedroom door in her family’s house in the northern town of Aalborg to slather a magnificent 1920s-era built-in bookcase with what she calls “ugly purple paint.” It was the opening salvo in her war on the Nordic gray-and-white aesthetic — a joyful, full-spectrum battle royal that has reached its apotheosis in the Copenhagen house she shares with her husband and their two children.

headline: Italy Loosens Gun Laws as Matteo Salvini Polishes His Tough Guy Image
abstract: Making it easier to buy a weapon was once unthinkable in the country. But the interior minister, working from a populist playbook, is pushing a hard line.
lead_paragraph: ROME — At a police convention in October, Matteo Salvini, the most powerful figure in Italy’s populist government, ran his hands over an enormous military-grade sniper rifle and posed with a submachine gun. Before elections this year, he campaigned at a gun show and signed a cooperation pledge with a group advocating looser gun laws in Italy.

headline: Trump Was Not Repudiated. He Was Rewarded.
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Economy', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The president made the midterms a real battle instead of a running retreat. He is widely hated and feared, but he is also much loved as a champion of his voters.
lead_paragraph: If Donald Trump inaugurated a new era of conflict in American politics, Tuesday’s midterm elections were just another skirmish, not a turning point in the war. Republicans lost fewer seats in the House of Representatives than Democrats lost in 1994 or 2010, when Bill Clinton and Barack Obama were in their first terms as president. Mr. Clinton and Mr. Obama both went on to win re-election two years after those midterm routs.

headline: On Midterm TV, Data Came Fast. Answers Came Later, if at All.
abstract: An election that was both covered and fought on cable news ended with debates about waves and a lot of whiplash.
lead_paragraph: The midterm election coverage began with intimations that the Democrats might unleash a “blue wave.” It proceeded, in early evening, with James Carville soberly declaring on MSNBC, “It’s not going to be a wave election.” It ended, after a re-reversal of the narrative, with cable news panels arguing over what the definition of “wave” is.

headline: When Robots Ring the Bell
abstract: A recent episode at the New York Stock Exchange was designed to prove that robots and people can happily coexist. Business research proves it’s possible — with certain caveats.
lead_paragraph: When Robo Global’s team recently gathered at the New York Stock Exchange to celebrate the fifth anniversary of its robotics index and exchange-traded fund, it marked the event in true robotic fashion: A robot, propped on a table, reached out its arm and rang the closing bell as 15 company executives applauded wildly next to it.

headline: Stacey Abrams, Brian Kemp and Neo-Jim Crow in Georgia
abstract: I saw the election through the eyes of black people who had to deal with Jim Crow, who remembered the euphoria of Barack Obama’s wins and who now have to grapple with Neo-Jim Crow.
lead_paragraph: So much has been written about the election for governor in Georgia between the Democrat Stacey Abrams, who would be the first black woman in that role, and Brian Kemp, her Republican opponent, a race that may not be over as they wait for absentee and provisional ballots to be counted.

headline: ‘Dr. Seuss’ The Grinch’ Review: Pointy-Headed and Pointless
abstract: Aside from colorful computer animation and enhanced cuteness for the lovable sidekick dog, Max, this new “Grinch” brings little of note to the table.
lead_paragraph: Grousing about pointless remakes is a critical activity so frequently practiced that it’s become a form of conventional wisdom. As such, I try to resist the reflex. However, I am flummoxed by “Dr. Seuss’ The Grinch,” a computer-animated iteration of “How the Grinch Stole Christmas.” The book was an instant classic in 1957 and still sells oodles today.

headline: Behind the Cover: Failure to See the Threat of White Nationalism

keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Despite warnings from within the G.O.P., Republicans lost their unity and grip on messaging, allowing the Democrats to gain a majority of congressional seats.
lead_paragraph: The message from Representative Kevin McCarthy, the House majority leader, was urgent and unsparing. In a meeting with Republican lawmakers before they left Washington for the August congressional recess, Mr. McCarthy warned that time was running short: Unless they intensified their campaign efforts and forcefully delivered a coherent message, he said, Republicans would suffer grievous losses in November.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the highest-ranking House Democrat, declared on Wednesday that she was confident that her newly ascendant colleagues would elect her speaker, as she moved aggressively to hold off a challenge to her leadership that could fracture the party.

headline: It’s the Day After the Election. What’s Your Take?
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: How are you viewing the midterm election results? We want to hear from our readers.
lead_paragraph: The Democrats took control of the House and won a few critical governorships during Tuesday’s midterm elections, delivering a rebuke to President Trump, as Republicans maintained control of the Senate and had their own big successes in state races.How are you feeling about the results? What do you think they say about the state of the country? Tell us in the comments how you think the election results will affect you, your community and the country at large. We will be featuring some of the comments below. Learn how to comment here.

headline: Social Media’s Re-engineering Effect, From Myanmar to Germany
abstract: When Facebook, YouTube and others use algorithms to keep us engaged, there can be unintended consequences. Max Fisher, his tools in a trusty Patagonia bag, covers the trend as one of The Times’s Interpreter columnists.
lead_paragraph: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Max Fisher, a reporter based in London who co-writes The Interpreter column and newsletter, discussed the tech he’s using.

keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Slogans and Mottoes']

headline: Fashion for a Walk on the Waterfront
abstract: Cooler air calls for utilitarian separates — from hooded jackets to protective boots — layered for a spirited exploration of sand and sea.
lead_paragraph: For this story from our Nov. 11 Travel issue, we boarded the jitney to East Hampton. With Three Mile Harbor as a backdrop, Collier Schorr captured the model Saskia de Brauw in utilitarian separates from the resort season, as styled by Vanessa Reid. Layered jackets and quilted vests met graphic (but earth-tone) prints, while trapper hats, scarves and over-the-knee boots completed the great-outdoors-inspired looks. See this and more in our slide show.

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — One of Russia’s most daring and innovative directors went on trial on Wednesday, charged in a financial fraud case widely seen among the country’s intelligentsia as a test of artistic freedom.

headline: Evelyn Y. Davis, Shareholder Scourge of C.E.O.s, Dies at 89
keywords: ['Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: For more than 50 years she harangued executives, sometimes wearing a costume to make a point. And sometimes this gadfly got results.
lead_paragraph: Evelyn Y. Davis, who spent more than 50 years haranguing American executives at shareholder meetings as she pushed companies to be more frugal and transparent, died on Sunday in Washington. She was 89.

headline: What Pokémon Can Teach Us About Fiction
abstract: Video games and novels have more in common than you might think. Jeremy Klemin explains how the logic of both involves enigmas and resolutions.
lead_paragraph: Between the ages of 5 and 10, I spent many solitary weekends at my grandparents’ house reading middle grade books and playing Pokémon on my Game Boy. The fact that I read one and played the other was unimportant; I was captivated by both in the same way — by how detailed they were, by how even the most trivial bits of information could prove meaningful in the context of their respective narratives. I spent an unjustifiable amount of time not only playing games like Pokémon, but also scouring them for secrets that may or may not have existed. The kinds of rumors that surrounded such games are instantly recognized by most millennials: “You can catch a Mew” — a particularly coveted and elusive Pokémon — “if you can get to the truck next to the S.S. Anne”; “There’s a secret stash of Pokémon behind Bill’s house.”

headline: He Helped People Cheat at Grand Theft Auto. Then His Home Was Raided.
keywords: ['Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Computer Security', 'Assets, Frozen', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Media', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: A gamer in Melbourne has had his assets frozen in connection with a popular video game cheat. He’s one of many being sued by game companies worldwide, raising questions about copyright law and the policing of online civility.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Imagine you are racing a car through a packed city center. You are in first place, only seconds from victory, when suddenly, a missile explodes and kills you.

headline: Watch Beatboxers Break It Down Inside an M.R.I. Scanner

lead_paragraph: It’s not every day that scientists get a beatboxer to perform inside an M.R.I. machine. But the researchers who did got to see a show, and now so do you (we recommend you watch this short video with the sound on).

headline: Wes Anderson, Curator? The Filmmaker Gives It a Try
abstract: Mr. Anderson and his partner, Juman Malouf, were given free rein in Austria’s largest museum. But you can’t make an exhibition as you would a movie, our critic writes.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Wes Anderson looked tired. The filmmaker was wearing a red blazer and a striped tie, standing beneath the elaborate 19th-century cupola of the Kunsthistorisches Museum. His partner, the author and designer Juman Malouf, was by his side.

lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of oil lamps illuminated the northern Indian city of Ayodhya as part of the festival of Diwali, casting a glowing light over the city on Tuesday.

headline: Amy McGrath, a Soaring Democratic Candidate, Is Brought Back to Earth on Election Day
abstract: Ms. McGrath, a retired Marine combat aviator, was supposed to be the Democrat who could bridge the urban-rural chasm. But her loss in a Kentucky congressional race exemplifies the nation’s divide.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Ky. — At 5 a.m. on Election Day, Mark Nickolas awoke to write a speech he thought would never be delivered.

headline: A Thought Experiment at the Supreme Court Over How to Sue a Country
abstract: Sailors injured in the 2000 bombing of the destroyer Cole won a $314 million default judgment. It was at risk at the Supreme Court on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2012, American sailors injured in a terrorist attack won a $314 million default judgment against the government of Sudan. The award was at risk at the Supreme Court on Wednesday over what might otherwise have seemed a minor and technical question: whether the sailors had properly served Sudan by sending their lawsuit to its embassy in the United States.

headline: ‘You Are a Rude, Terrible Person’: After Midterms, Trump Renews His Attacks on the Press
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'White House Building (Washington, DC)']
abstract: At a tense White House news conference, the president lashed out at CNN’s Jim Acosta and repeatedly told other reporters to “sit down.”
lead_paragraph: President Trump lashed out at journalists during a surly and contentious news conference at the White House on Wednesday, renewing his attacks on the news media as “the enemy of the people” just moments after pledging an end to partisan politics in the wake of a grueling midterm election.

headline: Jeff Sessions Is Forced Out as Attorney General as Trump Installs Loyalist
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']
abstract: Mr. Sessions was the first senator to endorse Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign. But his recusal as attorney general from the Russia inquiry proved to be his undoing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump fired Attorney General Jeff Sessions on Wednesday, replacing him with a loyalist who has echoed the president’s complaints about the special counsel investigation into Russia’s election interference and will now take charge of the inquiry.

headline: Deep Inside the Beatles’ White Album, 50 Years Later
abstract: An anniversary reissue, which includes remixes, reveals a band painstakingly working for an elusive perfection, running through songs again and again.
lead_paragraph: It took a remarkable effort to sound so casual. That’s one lesson of the hugely expanded 50th anniversary reissue of “The Beatles,” the double album that has been known as the White Album since its release in November 1968.

headline: A Record 117 Women Won Office, Reshaping America’s Leadership
abstract: The so-called Year of the Woman is living up to its name, though women remain far from having equal representation in Congress.
lead_paragraph: This is a special post-election edition of Gender Letter. Tell me what you think at dearmaya@nytimes.com.

headline: The Last Statesman of the Venezuelan Democracy
abstract: A restless defender of democratic values, Teodoro Petkoff never stopped criticizing Hugo Chávez’s autocratic tendencies and never gave up on his country.
lead_paragraph: For many suffering from Venezuela’s economic and humanitarian crisis, the death last week of an elder statesman, Teodoro Petkoff, at age 86, seemed yet another cause for despair.

headline: Getting Into Harvard Is Hard. Here Are 4 Ways Applicants Get an Edge.
abstract: A federal case against Harvard has brought to light many of its closely guarded admissions secrets.
lead_paragraph: For three weeks in October, Harvard’s admissions system was on trial before an often standing-room-only crowd in a federal courtroom in Boston. Harvard was accused of discriminating against Asian-American applicants, but the university firmly denied this throughout the trial, which ended last week.

headline: Marijuana Embraced in Michigan, Utah and Missouri, but Rejected in North Dakota
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Medical Marijuana', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Ballot measures that would approve marijuana for recreational or medical use were endorsed in three states. Voters in North Dakota rejected legalization.
lead_paragraph: Marijuana initiatives appeared on ballots in four states in the midterm elections. In Michigan and North Dakota, initiatives gave voters the opportunity to legalize marijuana for recreational use. In Missouri and Utah, voters chose whether to allow people who are sick to use the drug for medical reasons.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Maruja Mallo’s Surrealist works get a long-overdue survey; Neil Goldberg makes the personal political; and Martha Edelheit’s paintings and drawings of the sexually permissive ’60s.
lead_paragraph: Maruja Mallo — whose given name was Ana María Gómez González — was an avant-garde painter living in Madrid in the 1920s and early ’30s, before fleeing to Argentina at the start of the Spanish Civil War. (She returned to Spain in 1965.) Mallo pursued Surrealism in the company of Salvador Dalí, the filmmaker Luis Buñuel and the poet Federico García Lorca, but as with many female artists, her contributions are only beginning to be studied.

headline: Inside the Fight to Turn Red California Blue
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Big swaths of the Golden State remain conservative, and changing the political fabric and voting patterns of a community takes more than one election.
lead_paragraph: TURLOCK, Calif. — It started so small. Twenty people in Crystal Sousa’s living room, traumatized by the election of Donald Trump, trying to channel desperation into constructive action. Be the Change, they called the group that coalesced in this small, conservative city in the Central Valley of California. Almost all the leaders were women. Most had never engaged in politics. But they had been PTA mothers, Girl Scout leaders and teachers. They knew how to get things done.

headline: Review: A Chic but Dull ‘Tenant’ With James Whiteside
abstract: Arthur Pita’s shiny dance-drama is well made and has committed performances, but whenever the dancing starts, the tension drops.
lead_paragraph: Apartment life can be a nightmare. You move into a new place and discover something left by the previous tenant, reminding you that the place isn’t new at all — that you might have inherited someone else’s problems. And the neighbors! You can’t be quiet enough for them. If you so much as walk, they start banging on the walls. It could drive a person crazy.

headline: Think 2020 Will Be Better for Senate Democrats? Think Again
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Rural Areas', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: Without a smarter approach to rural America, liberals will be stuck in the minority for a long time.
lead_paragraph: As expected, the reality produced by Tuesday’s results will be a split Congress, with Democrats running the House of Representatives and Republicans in charge of the Senate. Republicans will expand their Senate majority from the current 51-49 to as much as 54-46, pending the outcomes of a few races that as I write are still too close to call, but in which Republicans hold slim leads.

headline: Terrence McNally Cherishes the Light in Art. Until It Goes Out.
abstract: “A great work is one you never get tired of — you find new value in it every day.” So says this playwright, who has a taste for lyrical realism.
lead_paragraph: Having a documentary made about you can prompt reflection, and “Every Act of Life” is having that effect on its subject, the four-time Tony-winning playwright and librettist Terrence McNally, who just turned 80.

headline: ‘I Don’t Even Know What to Think’: The Whiplash of Watching the Election Results
abstract: At a bar outside Pittsburgh, a few dozen relatively new but highly-motivated grass-roots volunteers gathered to watch election returns. It was a night of mixed feelings.
lead_paragraph: HOMESTEAD, Pa. — The night began with giddy eagerness as the crowd trickled into the warren of rooms at the back of a bar just outside Pittsburgh. They were nurses, social workers, professors and retirees who had spent the last two years learning the science of campaigning from scratch and the last few months doing the grueling work.

headline: Why Democrats’ Gain Was More Impressive Than It Appears
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: They are poised to win more seats this year than they did in 2006, despite far fewer opportunities.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t necessarily the night of either party’s dreams. The Democrats are poised to gain around 35 House seats after Tuesday’s elections. Republicans seem likely to gain a few seats in the Senate, and they triumphed in some high-profile governor’s races.

headline: Christopher Lehmann-Haupt, 84, Long-Serving Times Book Critic, Dies
abstract: Over three decades he wrote some 4,000 reviews and essays that influenced literary careers and book sales nationally. He later wrote obituaries of authors.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Lehmann-Haupt, a nationally influential literary critic for The New York Times for three decades, who wrote some 4,000 reviews and essays, mostly for the daily column Books of The Times, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: Maryland Fires Two Trainers Who Treated Jordan McNair Before His Death
abstract: The two trainers were released a week after the university president fired D.J. Durkin, the head football coach.
lead_paragraph: COLLEGE PARK, Md. — Two University of Maryland athletic trainers who attended to a football player who died after contracting heatstroke at a spring practice are no longer employed there, a university spokeswoman said on Wednesday.

headline: A Patriot Returns
abstract: The remains of Brent Taylor, who served in the military and as a mayor, arrived home, appropriately, on Election Day,
lead_paragraph: Brent Taylor, the mayor of North Ogden, Utah, and a major in the National Guard, was killed in Afghanistan on Saturday on his fourth deployment to a war zone. As Americans headed to the polls early Tuesday, Jennie Taylor, his wife and the mother of his seven children, was at Dover Air Force Base in Delaware to meet his remains. Their two oldest sons were by her side. “It seems only fitting that Brent, who in death now represents something so much greater than any of our own individual lives,” she said, “has come home to U.S. soil in a flag-draped casket on our Election Day.” Major Taylor, 39, had guided several large infrastructure improvements as mayor since 2013. In his final Facebook post, in late October, Major Taylor, a Republican, said that he hoped “everyone back home exercises their precious right to vote” and said that whether Republicans or Democrats win, “We all remember that we have far more as Americans that unites us than divides us.”

headline: Driver Who Killed Two Children in Brooklyn Is Found Dead
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The driver, Dorothy Bruns, 44, was discovered dead in her Staten Island home with a bottle of pills and a suicide note nearby, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A driver charged with manslaughter after she fatally struck two young children and injured a pregnant mother in Brooklyn last March was found dead in her Staten Island home on Tuesday in what appeared to be a suicide, the police said.

headline: The N.B.A. Sets a Blistering Pace, Leaving Defenses in the Dust
abstract: The game is being played faster than at any point since the late 1980s, and that, combined with a rule change, has scoring way up.
lead_paragraph: If it seems you have heard the phrase “transition defense” a lot this N.B.A. season, you are not mistaken. Basketball’s evolution has made everything smaller and faster, and offenses are looking for any opportunity to run. This leaves coaches desperately looking for ways to combat the offensive surge.

keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (2017)', 'United States Politics and Government']

headline: Midterm Results Leave Canadians Wary Over Fate of Trade Agreement
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The Democrats’ control of the House of Representatives may create new trade headaches for Canada.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Canadians will closely watch the fate of a newly negotiated trade pact, analysts said, after the American midterm elections brought Democrats to power in the House and injected a new element of uncertainty in trade relations.

headline: The ‘Blue Wave’ Wasn’t Enough to Overcome Republican Gerrymanders
abstract: Democrats increased their popular vote share in many states, but gerrymanders prevented them from adding seats.
lead_paragraph: Democrats increased their popular vote share in many states, but gerrymanders prevented them from adding seats.

headline: A Better Way to Vote? Just Look to Canada
abstract: A Canadian says she is “dumbfounded” by how elections are conducted in America. An American wonders why the efficiency of online purchases can’t be applied to voting.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What the Midterms Mean for Climate Change
abstract: The election results were a mixed bag for potential climate policy. Also this week, we look at how to get involved after the election.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: In Superstar Cities, the Rich Get Richer, and They Get Amazon
keywords: ['Relocation of Business', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Urban Areas', 'Income Inequality', 'Innovation']
abstract: New York and Washington are leaving the rest of the country behind. Companies like Amazon explain why.
lead_paragraph: In the end, even Amazon has behaved according to this rule: In the modern tech economy, cities that already have wealth, opportunity, highly educated workers and high salaries will just keep attracting more of them.

headline: Get Better TV Sound (Without a Lot of Wires)
keywords: ['Speakers (Audio)', 'Television Sets and Media Devices', 'Headphones and Headsets']
abstract: Flat-panel HDTVs are too thin to house good speakers. These simple tips and gear upgrades can give you great sound without a lot of work.
lead_paragraph: The latest TVs pack better image quality than ever before into impossibly thin bodies, but their designs leave little room for decent built-in speakers. Forget room-rumbling explosions — making out basic dialogue can be difficult on all but the highest-volume settings for many TVs.

headline: 6 New York Jewelers to Know
abstract: Think delicate diamond rings, chunky glass necklaces, whimsical painted brooches.
lead_paragraph: The holidays are coming, and so-called engagement season is fast approaching. Little wonder, then, that jewelry is on the brain. For the city’s stellar local jewelers, of course, jewelry is top of mind year-round. And now we finally have a proper way to celebrate them: New York City Jewelry Week, which kicks off Nov. 12 and runs through Nov. 18. Participants range from up-and-comers to behemoths like David Yurman and Fred Leighton, and events will include panels and studio tours. Unlike New York Fashion Week, many events are open to the public. Here, some jewelers worth checking out because, simply put, they make cool stuff.

headline: Review: A Rare Staging Finds the Magic in Schumann’s ‘Faust’
abstract: Achim Freyer’s production in Hamburg conjures a world that, for all its surreal touches, has a zany beauty that gently smooths over Schumann’s flaws.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG — One reason Schumann’s “Scenes From Goethe’s ‘Faust’” is so rarely performed is its hybrid shape: part literary oratorio, part opera. Another handicap is his selections.

headline: A Rose Reborn
abstract: A Park Chan-wook film presented by Ermenegildo Zegna and Stefano Pilati

headline: 2018 Holiday Gift Guide: Hard to Please
abstract: The New York Times and Wirecutter bring you this indispensable guide to the best gifts of the holiday season. Browse by interest or price; we promise you’ll find something nice.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times and Wirecutter bring you this indispensable guide to the best gifts of the holiday season. Browse by interest or price; we promise you’ll find something nice.

headline: Is Democracy at Risk? A Lesson Plan for U.S. and Global History Classes
abstract: In this lesson, students reflect on why democracies are worth protecting, what elements are essential to a healthy democracy and how it is that democracies sometimes fail.
lead_paragraph: Often we take for granted that the United States is a democracy, and that democracy is a form of government worth celebrating. This lesson starts there, but then pushes students to reflect on why democracies are worth protecting, what elements are essential to a healthy democracy and how it is that democracies sometimes fail.

headline: Busy Philipps Reads ‘How to Break Up With a 2-Year-Old’
abstract: On this week’s Modern Love podcast, the actor and talk-show host tells the story of a woman’s doubly painful breakup.
lead_paragraph: At 40, Laurie Sandell met a man with a child whom she learned to love as her own. When the relationship with the man unraveled, Ms. Sandell was forced to say goodbye not only to him but also to the little girl she had come to love. On this week’s Modern Love podcast, Busy Philipps reads Ms. Sandell’s essay, “How to Break Up With a 2-Year-Old.”

headline: Dead Pimp Dennis Hof Cruises to Victory in Nevada State Election
abstract: Mr. Hof died last month at a brothel he owned in Crystal, Nev. On Tuesday, he was overwhelmingly elected to the State Assembly.
lead_paragraph: In life, Dennis Hof claimed many titles: “America’s pimp” and “the P.T. Barnum of Booty,” based on his notoriety as an outspoken brothel owner in Nevada. He called himself the “Trump of Pahrump,” nodding to his political style and the town he called home.

headline: Older Fathers More Likely to Have Babies With Health Problems
abstract: Premature birth, low birth weight and seizures are among the problems reported.
lead_paragraph: Babies of older fathers are at greater risk of premature birth, low birth weight and other neonatal problems, a new study reports.

headline: How Sessions’s Firing Could Affect the Russia Investigation
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Attorneys General', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']
abstract: The acting attorney general, Matthew G. Whitaker, is seen as loyal to President Trump. He now oversees the special counsel’s inquiry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s decision to fire Attorney General Jeff Sessions and appoint Mr. Sessions’s former chief of staff, Matthew G. Whitaker, as the acting head of the Justice Department immediately raised questions about what the move means for Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel leading the Russia investigation.

headline: Eric Garner Died in a Police Chokehold. Why Has the Inquiry Taken So Long?
abstract: Federal prosecutors spent years weighing whether to charge the officer involved in the 2014 death. That left the local officials’ hands tied — until they decided it didn’t.
lead_paragraph: Eric Garner died on July 17, 2014, when a New York City police officer, Daniel Pantaleo, wrapped his arm around Mr. Garner’s neck and, along with other officers, wrestled him to the ground during an arrest after he was seen selling untaxed cigarettes on a Staten Island street.

headline: In ‘Rainbow Wave,’ L.G.B.T. Candidates Are Elected in Record Numbers
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'State Legislatures', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Transgender and Transsexuals']
abstract: More than 150 L.G.B.T. candidates were elected nationwide, and Massachusetts voted to uphold a state law protecting transgender people from discrimination.
lead_paragraph: More openly lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people were elected Tuesday night than in any previous election, signaling a shift in cultural attitudes even as the Trump administration has chipped away at L.G.B.T. rights.

headline: Barbara Jonas, Who Traded Art Collecting for Philanthropy, Dies at 84
abstract: She and her husband began a family foundation to improve nursing, help veterans and protect children from environmental hazards.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Jonas, who with her husband collected Abstract Expressionist paintings and sold them three decades later to promote a cause seldom embraced by philanthropists — the recruitment and training of nurses — died on Oct. 23 in Manhattan. She was 84.

headline: Takeaways From Trump’s Midterms News Conference: ‘People Like Me’
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Trump and his fellow Republicans lost the House but gained seats in the Senate. He said his greatest lesson from Tuesday’s election was, “People like the job I’m doing.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump gave a wide-ranging, nearly 90-minute news conference on Wednesday, boasting about the Republicans’ victories a day earlier, even as his party lost control of the House.

headline: After Protest, Booksellers Are Victorious Against Amazon Subsidiary
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'E-Commerce', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Two days into a strike by antiquarian booksellers against the Amazon unit AbeBooks, the company capitulated.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A worldwide strike by antiquarian booksellers against an Amazon subsidiary proved successful after two days, with the retailer apologizing and saying it would cancel the actions that prompted the protest.

headline: Election Consolidates One-Party Control Over State Legislatures
keywords: ['State Legislatures', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'States (US)', 'Politics and Government', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment']
abstract: For the first time in 104 years, every state but one will have a legislature in which a single party controls both houses.
lead_paragraph: In a stark display of the nation’s divide, the lower and upper chamber of every legislature but one — Minnesota — will be controlled by the same party following Tuesday’s midterm elections. It will be the first time in 104 years that only one state will have a divided legislature.

headline: With Sessions Out, What Happens to Mueller?
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Congress and the public must now push for protections for the special counsel.
lead_paragraph: Despite the extraordinary success of the special counsel, Robert Mueller — or more likely because of it — faces his most serious threat yet: the forced resignation of Attorney General Jeff Sessions.

headline: Up Against Big Oil in the Midterms
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Global Warming', 'States (US)']
abstract: The election produced some wins for the climate, but also underscored the power of the fossil fuel industry.
lead_paragraph: The victories in the midterm elections were real and sweet for environmentalists and progressives: There will be at least 119 women in Congress, and for the first time their ranks will include a Muslim (two, actually) and a Native American (at least two).

headline: Dirk Nowitzki Knew LeBron Would Pass Him, but He’s Still Gunning for Wilt
abstract: Nowitzki has yet to play this season as he recovers from an ankle injury, but he has plenty to say about chasing LeBron, off-season dieting and Dallas Mavericks rookie Luka Doncic.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The Dirk Nowitzki Farewell Tour is not yet underway in Dallas — for at least three reasons.

headline: Overlooked No More: Jackie Mitchell, Who Fanned Two of Baseball’s Greats
abstract: Mitchell was a 17-year-old pitcher in 1931 when she struck out Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig in an exhibition game, but questions about that exploit linger.
lead_paragraph: Since 1851, obituaries in The New York Times have been dominated by white men. With Overlooked, we’re adding the stories of remarkable people whose deaths went unreported in The Times.

headline: Searching Social Media for Clues About Violent Crimes
abstract: To understand the behavior of two suspects in recent, high-profile crimes, the reporter Kevin Roose dug into the darker corners of the internet.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

headline: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Will Push Washington. Will Washington Push Back?
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A history-making candidate prepares to enter the establishment, but hopes not to be changed by it.
lead_paragraph: Minutes after starting her acceptance speech on election night, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, the newly elected congresswoman from Queens, was surprised to hear groans.

headline: Ex-Police Chief and 13 Others Arrested in Peru for Suspected Child Trafficking
abstract: Fourteen people were arrested in Peru, including a former head of the national police, accused of selling children taken from vulnerable women.
lead_paragraph: LIMA, Peru — Police arrested 14 people in Peru and took a five-month-old baby into protective custody, dismantling a human trafficking ring suspected of selling children taken from vulnerable women.

headline: Midterm Elections Deliver a Ratings Surge, With Fox News in the Lead
abstract: CNN placed second in total viewers, with NBC taking first place among the major broadcast networks.
lead_paragraph: In a big night for television news, 36.1 million people watched the Tuesday evening coverage of the midterm elections, according to Nielsen.

headline: U.S. Is Back in Fed Cup Final, but Its Stars Are Not
abstract: Sloane Stephens, CoCo Vandeweghe and Madison Keys carried the United States in the semifinals, but none of them will take the court against the Czech Republic this weekend.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, the United States captured its first Fed Cup championship since 2000, with a 3-2 win over Belarus in Minsk. Sloane Stephens, fresh off her United States Open victory, and CoCo Vandeweghe, who had just ascended into the world’s top 10 for the first time, led the way for the Americans.

headline: Facebook Thwarted Chaos on Election Day. It’s Hardly Clear That Will Last.
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'News and News Media', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense']
abstract: Facebook made strides toward cleaning up its service in the last two years. But it continues to behave most responsibly only when placed under a microscope.
lead_paragraph: After an Election Day largely free of viral social media misinformation, and with little trace of the kind of Russian troll stampede that hit its platform in 2016, executives at Facebook may be tempted to take a victory lap.

headline: The Midterms Are Over. Now What?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: In the On Politics newsletter, looking into our political future; plus, checking in on some of the biggest undecided midterm races.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Who Wants to Lead the House of Representatives?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: After Tuesday’s elections, a number of lawmakers announced their intent to run for leadership in the House. Here’s a look at who some of them are.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday’s elections swept Democrats to power in the House for the first time since 2010, but before Election Day, the leaders of both parties were under pressure.

headline: Jets’ Sam Darnold, in a Walking Boot, Is Most Likely Out for Sunday
abstract: The rookie quarterback did not report any injuries after Sunday’s loss, but a strained foot may lead to the Jets starting Josh McCown against the Bills.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Jets quarterback Sam Darnold had a setback in his rookie development this week when it was revealed on Wednesday that he had strained his foot in Sunday’s loss to the Miami Dolphins.

headline: How AT&T Fooled the Federal Judiciary
abstract: The telecom giant promised it wouldn’t use its merger with Time Warner to hurt consumers. But now it is doing precisely that.
lead_paragraph: HBO has long been the crown jewel of American television. It was HBO, in the 1990s and 2000s, that kick-started the golden age of television, funding and running shows like “The Sopranos” and “The Wire.” And it is HBO that still captures broad audiences with shows like “Game of Thrones.”

headline: Red-State Voters Stand by Republicans Despite Trump’s Trade War Pain
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Voting and Voters', 'Soybeans', 'Midterm Elections (2018)']
abstract: Gains in the Senate show that President Trump is insulated from the economic fallout.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Voters in red states largely shrugged off concerns about the economic effect of President Trump’s global trade war, throwing their support behind Republican candidates who embraced the administration’s protectionist agenda despite attempts by Democrats to turn it into a wedge issue.

headline: A Citywide Paper Jam: Ballot Problems Fuel Calls for Election Reform
abstract: Nearly four million ballot pages were stuffed into aging scanners on Tuesday, more than ever before, leading to widespread breakdowns and voting delays.
lead_paragraph: There was plenty of blame to go around for the outbreak of voting machine breakdowns and long delays that plagued New York City polling places on Election Day, but no one was certain of a precise solution — only that one was needed fast.

headline: Lasting Implications for the Courts as Republicans Gain in the Senate
abstract: The party’s expanded majority leaves Democrats with dwindling hopes of being able to swiftly diminish the conservative imprint on the judiciary even if they win the White House in 2020.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans’ expansion of their Senate majority means that the conservative legal movement is poised to expand and entrench its influence over the federal courts, leaving Democrats with dwindling hopes of being able to swiftly diminish that imprint even if they win the White House in 2020.

headline: 7 Dubious Claims From Trump’s Postelection News Conference
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Border Barriers']
abstract: The day after midterm elections, the president inaccurately boasted about the results and gave misleading statements on health care, immigration and trade.
lead_paragraph: Republicans appeared to be on the verge of expanding their narrow Senate majority after Tuesday’s midterm elections. But even wins in all three races that remained uncertain on Wednesday evening would get them to only 54 seats, a number they had as recently as last year.

headline: What Max Rose Can Teach Democrats About Beating Republicans
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Gentrification']
abstract: The winner in one New York congressional race was not favored to succeed in a Republican stronghold. He beat the odds — as a bald white guy.
lead_paragraph: The unexpected victory of Max Rose in the 11th Congressional district, which encompasses Staten Island and a sliver of southern Brooklyn, now means that the current president cannot count a single Republican in the House of Representatives from New York, the city that invented him.

headline: With Republican Gains in Senate, Social Conservatives Tighten Their Grip
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'ABORTION', 'Law and Legislation', 'States (US)', 'Politics and Government', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: Democrats won the House, and can stymie efforts to defund Planned Parenthood. But their power in the Senate is diminished, with big implications for the courts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican victories in crucial Senate and governors’ races this week have tightened social conservatives’ grip across American government, strengthening the party’s power as it seeks to limit abortion rights and push harder to the right on a number of divisive cultural issues.

headline: A Two-Party Texas and Other Takeaways From the Cruz-O’Rourke Race
abstract: Texas hasn’t seen a midterm election like this one in decades. Here are five takeaways.
lead_paragraph: EL PASO — Texas didn’t turn blue Tuesday night. It didn’t turn purple. But it is pinker now — largely because of Beto O’Rourke.

headline: Native Americans Score Historic Wins in Midterms After Years of Efforts
keywords: ['Native Americans', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Victories in an array of federal, state and local races took decades of organizing and legal battles. And strong candidates.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Two states sent the first Native American women to Congress. Another elected its first Native American lieutenant governor. A Navajo candidate won a pivotal county race in an area long dominated by a white minority.

headline: Steve Stockman, Ex-Congressman, Gets 10 Years in Prison for Stealing Charitable Donations
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The former representative from Texas was also ordered to pay about $1 million in restitution. He was previously convicted on 23 criminal counts.
lead_paragraph: A former United States representative from Texas was sentenced Wednesday to 10 years in prison and ordered to pay about $1 million in restitution after being convicted of stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars meant for charity and using it to pay for personal expenses and his political campaigns.

headline: Trump, Under Scrutiny and Unleashed
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Elections, Senate', 'Politics and Government', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']
abstract: The Democrats made progress in the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: Well, that was bittersweet.

headline: Mueller Was Running on Borrowed Time. Has It Run Out?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Attorneys General']
abstract: In forcing out Attorney General Jeff Sessions, the president seems to want a lawman he can control.
lead_paragraph: Robert Mueller, the special counsel, always knew he was running the Russia investigation on borrowed time. That time may have just run out on Wednesday afternoon, when President Trump ousted his attorney general, Jeff Sessions, less than 24 hours after Republicans lost their eight-year lock on the House of Representatives.

headline: For Both Parties, a Political Realignment Along Cultural Lines
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Suburbs', 'Rural Areas']
abstract: Two years after a divided country elected President Trump, voters delivered a cascade of contradictory results that added up to a portrait of a nation at odds with itself.
lead_paragraph: The midterm elections on Tuesday laid bare the growing chasm between urban and rural America, leaving Republicans deeply concerned about their declining fortunes in the metropolitan areas that extinguished their House majority and Democrats just as alarmed about their own struggles to win over voters in states that strengthened the G.O.P.’s grip on the Senate.

headline: Trudeau Apologizes for Canada’s Turning Away Ship of Jews Fleeing Nazis
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Apologies', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: In 1939, Canada refused desperate pleas for asylum by the captain of the St. Louis, a ship with more than 900 passengers. Most were Jews fleeing Germany.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Prime Minister Justin Trudeau stood in Parliament on Wednesday and apologized for Canada’s decision to turn away a steamliner full of Jewish refugees fleeing Nazi Germany on the eve of the Holocaust 79 years ago, saying it reflected years of regrettable anti-Semitic foreign policy.

headline: 1.4 Million Floridians With Felonies Win Long-Denied Right to Vote
abstract: In ending some of the harshest voting restrictions in the nation for those with criminal records, Florida voters responded to the argument that people should get another chance.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — As soon as he turned 18, Keith R. Ivey got a voter registration card and tucked it into his wallet. He’s 46 now and has never used it.

headline: Parkland Activists Took On the N.R.A. Here’s How It Turned Out.
keywords: ['Parkland, Fla, Shooting (2018)', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks']
abstract: The midterm elections yielded mixed results for the student gun control activists, showing that voters were still wrestling with guns and gun safety.
lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. — After the shooting massacre at a high school in Parkland, Fla., survivors found themselves taking on the National Rifle Association as they crisscrossed the country rallying young adults to register and vote against candidates opposed to gun control.

headline: Man Who Destroyed Trump’s Hollywood Star Is Ordered to Pay Nearly $9,500
abstract: The man who vandalized the star with a pickax had said his action was a “one-man protest” against the president and the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: A 24-year-old man who destroyed President Trump’s star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame with a pickax in July reached a plea deal on Wednesday requiring him to pay nearly $9,500 for the marker’s replacement.

headline: Trump Is a Really Happy Loser
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Sure, the House is gone. But so is Jeff Sessions.
lead_paragraph: Wow, Jeff Sessions was gone before they finished counting votes in Arizona.

headline: ‘Florida’s Being Florida’: Senate Race May Be Heading to, What Else? A Recount
abstract: Florida is accustomed to razor-thin vote margins. But Tuesday’s election has seen five races so close they could go to recounts.
lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — Election night in Florida’s capital began with a biblical deluge, the kind of epic rainfall that lends itself to political metaphors. Partisan waves! Electoral storms!

headline: Trump Installs a Critic of the Mueller Investigation to Oversee It
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Attorneys General', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']
abstract: Matthew G. Whitaker, the new acting attorney general, is a loyalist who once wrote that the Russia inquiry “is going too far” and should be limited in scope.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Matthew G. Whitaker, the attorney general’s chief of staff, jockeyed over the last two months to replace his boss by forging a close relationship with the White House, where he was seen as a reliable political ally. On Wednesday, President Trump fired Jeff Sessions and named Mr. Whitaker acting attorney general, rewarding his loyalty.

headline: How to Clean the Most Common Cat Messes
abstract: From fur balls to, ahem, stains, here’s some help.
lead_paragraph: You, a cat owner, love your cat. Your love for your cat runs so deep that you overlook the hairballs he coughs up, even the overlooked ones that you stepped on in the middle of the night on your way to the bathroom.

headline: Review: In ‘Eve’s Song,’ the Ghosts Are Not the Scariest Part
abstract: Patricia Ione Lloyd’s macabre domestic comedy suggests that for African-Americans, every day is a potential horror movie in the making.
lead_paragraph: Several sharp and funny reasons are offered in “Eve’s Song,” Patricia Ione Lloyd’s disconnected, macabre comedy at the Public Theater, as to why horror movies are nothing to be scared of if you’re African-American, at least not after the first five minutes. By that time, the only black character will surely have been killed off.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Political Realignment Without a Clear Winner
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 8, 2018.
lead_paragraph: “The further you get from metropolitan areas, the more powerful Donald Trump is and the more allegiance there is to whatever he says and does.”

abstract: Amazon appears to be leaning toward opening a new office in New York. Now word comes that Google, already a big employer in the city, may add on.

lead_paragraph: CARLSBAD, Calif. — Yankees catcher Gary Sanchez will have surgery next week to remove tissue from his left shoulder but is expected to be ready for opening day, General Manager Brian Cashman said on Wednesday.
