headline: On Politics: The Biggest Stories of the Week
abstract: It’s been a very busy week in American politics. Here are some of the stories you might have missed.
lead_paragraph: From a monumental Election Day to a shake-up in the Trump administration, it’s been a busy week in American politics. Here are some of the biggest stories you might have missed (and some links if you’d like to read further).

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: Democrats take the House. A Utah mayor was killed in Afghanistan. Gillian Flynn’s dark side. Mo Bamba is more than a rap anthem. Classic California in pictures. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. Most of the votes are counted, and we are settling into an altered political reality. We are also settling into fall and getting ready for the holidays. Are you making a list and checking it twice? No matter what you’re up to, don’t forget to indulge in some fantastic journalism.

headline: How to Date a Lot of Billionaires
keywords: ['Social Media', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'your-feed-selfcare']
abstract: Jyoti and Kiran Matharoo sought fame on social media by flaunting what nature — and men — gave them. Then they got locked up abroad.
lead_paragraph: After years of romances with a series of fabulously wealthy Nigerian boyfriends, the flamboyant Canadian sisters Jyoti and Kiran Matharoo needed somewhere to store the pricey spoils of their dating careers. So they converted a bedroom in their Toronto home into a large walk-in closet that resembles a luxury boutique.

headline: Boeing’s 737 Max: What You Need to Know
abstract: This popular passenger jet was recently involved in the Lion Air fatal crash. If you’re worried about flying one on your next trip, here is a quick guide to the plane and the airlines that fly it.
lead_paragraph: The Boeing 737 Max, which the company unveiled in 2017, quickly became one of its most popular planes: 200 Maxes bought by airlines ranging from American to Southwest, are already in the air and more than 4,700 are currently on order.

headline: How Did Race Play on Election Day? ‘Near Civil War-Like’? Or ‘It Really Didn’t Matter’?
abstract: Victories in communities that had never elected a black representative run counter to the divisive rhetoric that played out in some contests across the country.
lead_paragraph: When Joe Neguse discussed his newborn child on the campaign trail in his congressional race in Colorado, he found himself empathizing with constituents concerned about early education for their own children.

headline: Why Did New York City’s Electorate Submit Votes on a Piece of Paper Several Inches Longer Than a Page of the U.S. Constitution?
abstract: Join us as we travel down this rabbit hole.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans will go their entire lives without ever holding a piece of paper that is more than three times longer than a normal piece of paper, but of standard width. Try, for a moment, to envision such a sheet. Does the paper of your reckoning curl inward at both ends, like an ancient scroll? Or is it flat and unwieldy, like a rather small, very thin door with no knob that is attached to nothing? Is it more like something out of Kafka’s nightmares, or Picasso’s dreams?

abstract: As leaders commemorate the end of World War I, some of the same forces that threatened democracy and peace 100 years ago are resurgent today.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Joseph Musser’s family has always lived in the region of Alsace, but not always in the same country.

headline: Can’t Take Your Fancy Dog Hiking in the Country? Hire a Pro
abstract: Rich New Yorkers who feel bad about keeping their dogs inside all day are paying dog hikers to let them run free in the country.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Dane and Brooke Carillo brought home Mackey, an English cream golden retriever, to their two-bedroom apartment in Manhattan, but they quickly realized he wasn’t cut out for city life.

headline: Tayari Jones: In Praise of Ann Petry
abstract: “ ‘The Street’ is my favorite type of novel, literary with an astonishing plot.”
lead_paragraph: In 1946, Ann Petry had it all, well before we were wondering if this was even possible for a woman. Born in 1908 (or 1911 — biographers do not agree), Petry was trained as a pharmacist, worked as a reporter, married, and would soon be a mother. Hers was not an overnight success. She paid her dues, publishing short stories and essays, sometimes writing under a male pseudonym. Her star began to rise when she was awarded a $2,500 fellowship from Houghton Mifflin to write her first novel, “The Street,” which sold a staggering 1.5 million copies. And did I mention that she was a black woman?

headline: New Women’s Groups Focus on Generational Mix
abstract: The youngs bring energy, the elders history, and it’s not just about career.
lead_paragraph: Susan Good was sitting with a group of women in her home in Palm Springs, Calif., when one of them began lamenting the difficulties of aging. But it wasn’t the usual script about aches, pains and skyrocketing cholesterol levels. “She said that she felt invisible,” recalled Ms. Good, who is in her 70s. The speaker felt generally silenced. Unseen. As if she had nothing to contribute to the world.

headline: Bonhomie? C’est Fini as Trump and Macron Seek to Defuse Tension
abstract: President Trump’s meeting with President Emmanuel Macron of France appeared far chillier than their earlier warm sessions, demonstrating how the relationship has soured.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — They shook hands politely and patted each other on the arm stiffly. Their tight-lipped smiles appeared strained and forced. No cheeks were kissed, no friendly rubs were given, none of the bonhomie of their earlier meetings was on display.

lead_paragraph: BASE CAMP DONNA, Tex. — Sgt. 1st Class Daniel Micek, a platoon sergeant with the 89th Military Police Brigade, tore open the brown packaging of his M.R.E. on Thursday.

headline: The Chemists’ War
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'World War I (1914-18)', 'Chemistry', 'Water']
abstract: One hundred years after the end of World War I, the Army Corps of Engineers is still cleaning up the relics of experiments that helped develop chemical weapons to counter the Germans’ gas attacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Under a canopy of poplar and oak trees, a team of geophysicists surveyed the forest floor for century-old wartime relics. They positioned an electromagnetic scanner atop the carpet of leaves while the delicate instrument harvested data about objects in the soil beneath.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Turkey said on Saturday that it had turned over an audio recording of the killing of a Saudi dissident to the United States and other Western countries, intensifying the pressure on President Trump to take stronger punitive measures against his allies in Saudi Arabia.

headline: ‘How Can I Help?’ Meet 5 People Who Serve the Community
abstract: Whether it’s teaching English to refugees or helping neighbors find healthy food, these volunteers support work by beneficiary agencies of The Times’s Neediest Cases Fund.
lead_paragraph: Carolyn Bratton spent part of her childhood in the foster care system. The experience left her meek and dwindled, she recalled recently, incapable of making simple eye contact.

headline: ‘An Impossible Dream Come True’
abstract: The bride and groom, both widowed, bonded over who they were, not over what they did for a living.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Kapu’uwailani Lindsey and George D. Crowley III are to be married Nov. 11 at the Butterfly Conservatory, Fairchild Garden in Coral Gables, Fla. Ashley Jansen, a friend of the couple who was ordained by the Renewal of the Spirit Institute, is to officiate in a nondenominational ceremony.

headline: Can I Stop My Neighbor From Building an Intrusive Balcony?
abstract: Homeowners in the city can’t just build any size balcony off the side of a building, but shutting down the project may be tricky.
lead_paragraph: Q: We recently purchased a co-op in an Upper West Side brownstone with a large living room window overlooking our building’s garden. Now the owners of the abutting apartment in the neighboring brownstone are building a glass balcony off their master bedroom that will obstruct our view and dim our light. Worse, anyone standing on the balcony could peer directly into our living room. The owner claims to have the proper permits. Is there anything we can legally do to stop or alter these plans?

headline: Christopher Lehmann-Haupt’s Most Memorable Book Reviews
abstract: From 1969 to 1995, he tackled two or three books a week, making and breaking literary careers.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Lehmann-Haupt, the influential critic who died earlier this week, wrote some 4,000 reviews and essays during his three-decade tenure covering books for The New York Times. According to his obituary, “readers and colleagues called him a judicious, authoritative voice on fiction and a seemingly boundless array of history, biography, current events and other topics, with forays into Persian archaeology and fly fishing.” Here are some of our favorites.

headline: Afghanistan Is the World’s Polio Capital. These Afghans Hope to Fix That.
abstract: These Afghans Are Trying to Fix That.
lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — At just 2 years old, Madina had been vaccinated seven times. It was not enough: When she fell ill this fall, a trip to the doctor in Kandahar City confirmed that she was among the latest Afghan toddlers to contract polio.

headline: Our 43 Best Thanksgiving Desserts
abstract: Cranberry curd tart, nutmeg-maple cream pie and more sweet treats.
lead_paragraph: Take this Thanksgiving as an opportunity to try something new. Make a cranberry curd tart (above), nutmeg-maple pie, pecan pie truffles or any of the recipes in the collection below.

headline: A Blue Wave in Kansas? Don’t Be So Surprised
abstract: If the Electoral College is the barometer, this state is deep red. But it’s the only one that has elected three female Democratic governors.
lead_paragraph: WICHITA, Kan. — At an open-air debate at the Kansas State Fair in September, a raucous crowd roared, cheered and booed with such vigor that the candidates often were forced to pause before they could speak.

headline: I Miss Northwestern Football’s Losing Tradition
abstract: My college was usually on the bottom of the Big Ten. When I think of the players’ futures, I wish it still was.
lead_paragraph: The football team at my alma mater, Northwestern, is having a pretty good season. Once, that would have thrilled me. Now, it just makes me uneasy.

headline: Mexico Gave the Migrant Caravan a Warm Welcome. It Wasn’t Always This Way.
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: A caravan of Central American migrants has left Mexico City, bound for the U.S. border. The group has forced a reckoning in Mexico over the treatment of migrants.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The caravan of Central Americans that has been making its way from Honduras toward the United States border moved on from Mexico City in the pre-dawn chill of Saturday, as migrants strapped on backpacks, rolled up blankets and hoisted sleeping children into their arms to begin the next leg of their journey.

headline: Who Won That Arizona Senate Race? What Day Is It?
abstract: Kyrsten Sinema has pulled to a lead in the Arizona Senate race, but days of ballot-counting remain.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — At first, the Republican looked as if she could win Arizona’s Senate race by a razor-thin margin. Then the Green Party emerged as a potential spoiler, even though its candidate had dropped out of the race. Now the Democrat has taken the lead.

headline: California Is Already Tough on Guns. After a Mass Shooting, Some Wonder if It’s Enough
abstract: Gun control activists and politicians in the state were already weighing what more can be done, and whether existing measures could have prevented the killing.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After a mass killing in Santa Barbara in 2014, California passed a law that let police officers and family members seek restraining orders to seize guns from troubled people. A year later, a shooting rampage in San Bernardino led to voters approving a ballot proposition to outlaw expanded magazines for guns and require background checks for buying ammunition.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox, Henry Rathvon, and we are all made of stars.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — Today’s excerpt is from a book called “Warped Passages” by Lisa Randall, a Harvard professor, cosmologist and particle physicist who’s been a popular name for some years — I remembered her from an appearance on “Wait Wait Don’t Tell Me” a few years ago. Her books are best-sellers, and she’s often written up alongside Neil deGrasse Tyson in science stories.

headline: Ma Jian, Exiled Chinese Novelist, Hails Appearance as Victory for Rights
abstract: The temporary cancellation of his appearance at a literary festival had been seen as the latest sign of erosions of freedom in Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — An exiled Chinese novelist spoke at a literary festival in Hong Kong on Saturday, two days after his appearance had been briefly canceled in a move that was widely seen as the latest erosion of freedoms in the semiautonomous city.

headline: Democrats Have Two Paths for 2020: Daring or Defensive. Can They Settle on Either?
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The results of Tuesday’s election have some in the party pushing moderation, while others, citing Beto O’Rourke’s close loss in Texas, want grass-roots inspiration
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For Democrats, the victories, near wins and stinging losses on Tuesday have intensified a debate in the party about how to retake the White House, with moderates arguing they must find a candidate who can appeal to President Trump’s supporters and historically Republican suburbanites, and progressives claiming they need someone with the raw authenticity to electrify the grass roots.

headline: The Times’s Capsule of History Goes Digital
abstract: The Times photo archive spans 1896 to the present. For the first time, all six million pictures are being scanned.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, Governors', 'Elections, State Legislature']
abstract: The vote tallies in three statewide races fell within a margin of half a percentage point, the legal trigger for required recounts.
lead_paragraph: RIVIERA BEACH, Fla. — Florida began the first full, statewide vote recount in its history on Saturday after authorities found that tallies submitted by its 67 counties left the contests for Senate, governor and agriculture commissioner too close to call.

headline: Rome Mayor Acquitted on Lying Charge, to Relief of Five Star Movement
abstract: The long-running corruption case had threatened both her political career and the credibility of her anti-establishment party.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Rome’s embattled mayor was acquitted on Saturday of charges of lying about a city hall appointment, a case that threatened her career as well as the credibility of the anti-establishment Five Star Movement she represents.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'Art']
abstract: Welcome to the first edition of With Interest — the most important business and tech news of this week and next.
lead_paragraph: Hello! Welcome to the first edition of With Interest. Every Sunday, we’ll send you the most important business and tech news, highlighting essentials from the past week and what’s in store for the next. We’ll keep it concise, informative and hopefully entertaining — because we know your time is precious, especially on the weekend.

headline: Who’s the Real American Psycho?
abstract: Trump’s bad, but don’t beatify the other malefactors.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald Trump is running wild — and running scared.

headline: Slow-Cooking History
abstract: I add the leaf of the cocoyam plant to dried mudfish, mushrooms and snails, and think of my indomitable ancestors.
lead_paragraph: Fufu is boiled green plantains and cassava, pounded in a wooden mortar to a distinct pum-pum-pum beat. Fufu, the way I like it, comes out a warm yellow, with specks of black from the plantain seeds. But fufu on its own is bland. Fufu is both food and utensil, and strong enough to scoop up soup. Ghanaians eat it with palm soup, groundnut soup, a tomato soup called light soup or ebunuebunu, green soup. Adventurous eaters go for a combination of all four, known as nkatenkontobenkwan. But I am a purist. Ebunuebunu is my favorite.

headline: The Resistance Strikes Back
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls', 'States (US)', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: Two years of progressive organizing built the blue wave.
lead_paragraph: In April 2017, progressives across America turned toward Georgia’s Sixth District for the race to fill the House seat vacated by Tom Price, who’d become President Trump’s (short-lived) secretary of health and human services. That affluent, highly educated district in Atlanta’s northern suburbs had been solidly Republican for decades; Newt Gingrich had held it for 20 years, and Price won his 2016 election by more than 23 percentage points. But Trump had prevailed there only narrowly, and Democrats dreamed of using the special election to rebuke him.

headline: Why I Dread Returning to an American Public School
abstract: In Germany, my daughter’s school offered circus lessons. Now I'll have to sell wrapping paper to keep the gym lights on.
lead_paragraph: After almost six years in Munich, my family and I will soon be returning to California, and there are a few things I already know I will miss. I am not talking about the obvious (fresh pretzels, fresh pretzels with cheese, fresh pretzels with cheese and pumpkin seeds, no potholes, universal health care) but the less known differences that come with spending time in schools.

headline: Be Afraid of Economic ‘Bigness.’ Be Very Afraid.
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: In the 1930s it contributed to the rise of fascism. Alarmingly, we are experimenting again with a monopolized economy.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the Second World War, an urgent question presented itself: How can we prevent the rise of fascism from happening again? If over the years that question became one of mostly historical interest, it has again become pressing, with the growing success of populist, nationalist and even neofascist movements all around the world.

headline: Why Do You Keep Dreaming You Forgot Your Pants? It’s Science
abstract: Where your brain goes when you’re asleep helps you when you’re awake.
lead_paragraph: One muggy Saturday last summer, I went on a date with a man who seemed entirely fine. We drank two beers and went for a walk, and he explained why he liked certain buildings that we passed. We kissed, and his breath tasted like cigarettes. We parted ways, and I couldn’t muster the energy to answer his emoji-laden follow-up texts about my weekend activities.

headline: By Protecting Veterans’ Health, You May Protect Your Own
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Hospitals', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: V.H.A. doctors care for some of America’s most vulnerable. They are not “bad apples” who “rob us or cheat us.”
lead_paragraph: This Veterans Day, in addition to honoring those who serve in uniform, we should spend some time remembering the 300,000 employees of the Veterans Health Administration. The V.H.A. — the nation’s largest public health system — doesn’t just keep veterans healthy; it has developed treatments that help all Americans. And if we don’t defend it, it could be dismantled and auctioned off in whatever remains of the Trump era.

headline: There’s No Nice Lady Caucus in Congress
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: With 100-plus women heading to the House, let’s examine some myths.
lead_paragraph: The 116th Congress will have a record number of women. So that means more women will bring their vaunted ability to compromise and work across the aisle. Right?

headline: A Defeat for White Identity
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Whites', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: What the midterms tell us about racial backlash and economic populism.
lead_paragraph: Running for president in 2016, Donald Trump sold two kinds of populism. One appealed to white tribalism and xenophobia — starkly in his early embrace of birtherism, recurrently in his exaggerations about immigrant crime, Muslim terrorism and urban voter fraud.

headline: My Son Was Dead. Did I Feel Better Holding a Gun?
keywords: ['School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Gun Control', 'Firearms', 'Las Vegas, Nev, Shooting (October, 2017)', 'Thousand Oaks, Calif, Shooting (2018)']
abstract: It wasn’t going to bring him back, or keep others safe.
lead_paragraph: In 1992, my son was killed in a school shooting in Massachusetts, a random victim of a disturbed fellow college student who’d purchased a semiautomatic rifle at a local gun shop and smuggled it onto campus. College officials had been warned that this student had a gun, but they didn’t know how to respond; school shootings were still too new.

headline: Elvis Presley and Babe Ruth Among Trump’s First Medal of Freedom Honorees

abstract: The president will recognize an eclectic mix of conservative political figures and cultural and athletic luminaries.

headline: The War That Never Ended
abstract: World War I officially concluded a century ago. But its aftershocks reverberate even today.

There, inside railroad car 2419D, they signed the armistice that brought World War I to a close.

headline: California Hasn’t Seen Fires Like This: Pictures of a State in Flames
abstract: Photographers documented the wildfires ravaging California — along the palm-fringed shoreline near Los Angeles and the evergreen forests of the Sierra Nevada foothills.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — California is burning — along the palm-fringed shoreline near Los Angeles and the evergreen forests of the Sierra Nevada foothills. An entire town in the Sierra was nearly erased this week by the most destructive fire in California history. At least 29 people were killed there, and more than 6,400 homes were destroyed. In Malibu and other cities in the hills west of Los Angeles, residents fled their homes — mansions and modest ranch houses alike.

headline: Rocket Lab’s Modest Launch Is Giant Leap for Small Rocket Business
keywords: ['Private Spaceflight', 'Rocket Science and Propulsion', 'Satellites', 'Space and Astronomy']
abstract: The company’s Electron rocket carried a batch of small commercial satellites from a launchpad in New Zealand, a harbinger of a major transformation to the space business.
lead_paragraph: A small rocket from a little-known company lifted off Sunday from the east coast of New Zealand, carrying a clutch of tiny satellites. That modest event — the first commercial launch by a U.S.-New Zealand company known as Rocket Lab — could mark the beginning of a new era in the space business, where countless small rockets pop off from spaceports around the world. This miniaturization of rockets and spacecraft places outer space within reach of a broader swath of the economy.

abstract: The government’s efforts to help those who were defrauded by their schools have all but ground to a halt. Instead, it is fighting claims in court.
lead_paragraph: The students attended institutions with pragmatic names like the Minnesota School of Business and others whose branding evoked ivy-draped buildings and leafy quads, like Corinthian Colleges. Tens of thousands of them say they are alike in one respect: They were victims of fraud, left with useless degrees and crushing debts.

headline: ‘The Grinch’ Rakes in the Green at the Box Office
abstract: The latest adaptation of the classic Christmas story was a big No. 1. But two other new films, “Overlord” and “The Girl in the Spider’s Web,” struggled.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Grinch, 61 years old, may be “as cuddly as a cactus” and “as charming as an eel,” to quote his creator. But slather him with high-fructose corn syrup (perky computer animation), roll him in a mega-marketing campaign (10 million Grinch-themed boxes shipped by Amazon alone), and the green critter is as sure a bet as there is in mass holiday entertainment.

headline: In a Netherlands Museum Director, the Nazis Found an Ally
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Art', 'Museums', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: As Dutch museums scour their holdings for Nazi-looted art, historians are revisiting a wartime arts administrator associated with tainted works.
lead_paragraph: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands — In 1943, an official of an art clearing house the Nazis set up in the Netherlands to sell looted Jewish property, approached the director of the Boijmans Museum in Rotterdam. He had four works he wanted to sell, including a lovely oil painting, “Woman Seated on the Grass at the Edge of a Meadow and Reading,” by Nicolaas van der Waay.

headline: How a Former Canadian Spy Helps Wall Street Mavens Think Smarter
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Mutual Funds', 'Hedge Funds']
abstract: Shane Parrish worked for Canada’s Defence Department before he turned to blogging about books. Now titans of finance seek his advice.
lead_paragraph: Shane Parrish was a cybersecurity expert at Canada’s top intelligence agency and an occasional blogger when he noticed something curious about his modest readership six years ago: 80 percent of his followers worked on Wall Street.

headline: California Fires, D.I.Y. Drugs, Alibaba: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: ‘Calling Glenn’ Puts a Humorous Spin on Gaga Dancing
abstract: Ate9, the choreographer Danielle Agami’s company, performs with the Wilco drummer Glenn Kotche onstage, but he’s not the center of attention.
lead_paragraph: Since 2013, when the Israeli-born choreographer Danielle Agami moved to Los Angeles, she has been making a name for herself there, winning awards with and without her company, Ate9. New Yorkers don’t have many chances to check out her work, but one came on Saturday, when her troupe performed at the Schimmel Center. And the piece, “Calling Glenn,” alludes in its title to an additional attraction: Glenn Kotche, the drummer for the rock band Wilco.

headline: Louise DeSalvo, Memoirist and Virginia Woolf Scholar, Dies at 76
abstract: She initially avoided writing about the traumas in her life, focusing instead on the food. “Life is too short for even one bad meal,” she wrote.
lead_paragraph: Louise A. DeSalvo, a Virginia Woolf scholar and memoirist who mined her Italian-American heritage for her books and who once observed that life “is too short for even one bad meal,” died on Oct. 31 in Montclair, N.J. She was 76.

headline: He Befriended 4,000 Dogs to Get Their Side of the Story
abstract: An author wanted to set the record straight about what life is like for four-legged New Yorkers. So, he interviewed some — and their humans — for a new book.
lead_paragraph: Dogs in New York City have a miserable life — that’s what Ken Foster kept hearing. How could they not? Many live in tiny apartments. Most do not have backyards to romp around in. They are bored at home all day while their owners toil long hours.

headline: What Happens When Fluxus Enters the Concert Hall?
abstract: The music of Fluxus, a nebulous and anti-establishment art movement of the 1960s, is receiving a season-long festival at the Los Angeles Philharmonic.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Fluxus is fraught with contradiction. The interdisciplinary art movement, which emerged in the 1960s, is funny but serious; indefinite but authoritative; destructive but full of possibility.

headline: Are You Ready for the Nanoinfluencers?
abstract: Influencers are so 2014. And microinfluencers are so last week. Now advertisers see value in people with as few as 1,000 followers: the nanoinfluencers.
lead_paragraph: By now you have probably heard of influencers, that group of internet-famous people who have more than a million social media followers and can make big money by plugging various brands. And you may have even heard of microinfluencers, who do the same thing for a still sizable but somewhat smaller social media audience — from the tens to low hundreds of thousands.

headline: Poland’s Leaders March With Far-Right Groups on Independence Day
abstract: The president said the 100th anniversary of Polish independence was “for everyone.” The march included the far right and omitted opposition leaders.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — It was meant to foster unity and celebrate the sacrifices of past generations in the creation of the modern Polish nation. But after days of wrangling and controversy, the country’s Independence Day celebration on Sunday ended up highlighting Poland’s deep divisions.

headline: How to Help California Fire Victims
abstract: Three raging wildfires have displaced hundreds of thousands of people and destroyed thousands of homes. Here are some charities that are helping those affected.
lead_paragraph: Three wildfires in California have displaced hundreds of thousands of people and destroyed thousands of homes. So far, dozens of people have been confirmed dead and hundreds more are missing.

headline: Jay O. Sanders on How an ‘Oak Tree’ Became Uncle Vanya
abstract: Mr. Sanders, a veteran of four decades of stage and screen work, is giving the performance of his career in his first appearance in Chekhov.
lead_paragraph: Jay O. Sanders is, by his own definition, “an oak tree” — an imposing physical type associated with sturdiness, reliability and, on occasion, menace. And because Mr. Sanders has been a much-employed actor on stage and screen for some 40 years, he knows that oaks are rarely cast as the neurotic and cerebral title character of Chekhov’s “Uncle Vanya.”

headline: Manchester City Surges Past United, and to a Higher Level
abstract: Manchester City’s stunning start to the season is perhaps best appreciated by the idea that its pursuers have been nearly flawless — and can’t keep up.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — Leroy Sané took a touch, and flicked the ball to Raheem Sterling. Ashley Young, the Manchester United captain, tracked the pass. Sterling controlled the ball and slipped it back to Sané. Young shuttled back the way he came. Sané waited until he arrived, and then rolled the ball to Phil Foden. Young set off again. Foden back to Sané, Sané to Sterling, around and around, again and again, hypnotic and unstoppable and relentless.

headline: OPEC, Russia Weigh Production Cuts to Prop Up Oil Prices
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Oil ministers warned that the gap between supply and demand could widen next year, which “may require new strategies to balance the market.”
lead_paragraph: Major oil producers meeting in Abu Dhabi on Sunday signaled that they were considering once again changing course and cutting production.

headline: Jailbreaks, Submarines, a Gold-Plated AK-47: El Chapo’s Trial Will Tell an Epic Tale
abstract: Two years have passed since the Mexican drug lord Joaquín Guzmán Loera was extradited to New York. His trial begins on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Even as the Mexican police jet started its descent into Long Island, Joaquín Guzmán Loera had no idea where he was going. All he knew was that hours earlier, he had been whisked from a prison in Ciudad Juárez and put aboard the plane.

headline: Show Up for Negotiations
abstract: Kathy Bloomer calls us to order.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — We begin our solving week by welcoming a new constructor named Kathy Bloomer, who is calling this meeting to order.

headline: Should the Press Boycott Trump? Political Strategists Weigh In
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Veterans of presidential campaigns offer reporters options for dealing with a president who loves making them part of the show.
lead_paragraph: The CNN chief Jeff Zucker gave his troops unexpected orders the day after President Trump snatched the press credential away from Jim Acosta, one of the network’s White House correspondents.

headline: Canada’s Message to Teenagers: Marijuana Is Legal Now. Please Don’t Smoke It.
abstract: Canadian teenagers use more marijuana than youths anywhere else in the world. The government hopes legalization will change that.
lead_paragraph: THORNBURY, Ontario — Parents and grandparents jammed the small hall of Thornbury, a sleepy ski town north of Toronto, to glean tips on how to talk to their teenagers about the potential harms of marijuana.

headline: Forced Out by Deadly Fires, Then Trapped in Traffic
abstract: The infernos raging at both ends of California have created a double nightmare for residents. Many who fled fires found themselves stuck on traffic-clogged roads. Some died in their cars.
lead_paragraph: For the latest on the California fires, read our Monday live updates here.

headline: See How New York Celebrated Veterans Day
keywords: ['Veterans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Parades', 'World War I (1914-18)', 'Veterans Day (US)']
abstract: This year’s parade marked the 100th anniversary of the end of World War I.
lead_paragraph: For Chris Lotspeich, Veterans Day is a family affair.

headline: Scholar Who Escaped Nazis Dies After a Push by a Subway Rider in a Rush
abstract: A Hofstra professor escaped Austria as the Nazis took control. Eighty years later, he died after someone knocked him down on a subway platform.
lead_paragraph: Among the thousands of commuters traveling through Pennsylvania Station late last month was Kurt Salzinger, a native of Austria who fled the country as the Nazis marched in. He distinguished himself years later in the United States as a scholar in the field of behavioral psychology.

headline: Not Down for the Count on China?
abstract: President Trump’s sanctions may still be a threat.
lead_paragraph: Despite Mr. Trump's beating in last week’s midterm elections, President Xi Xinping may not want to breathe a sigh of relief just yet, as the sanctions against China are seen by many as having broad support, perhaps even among the soon-to-be bluer U.S. House of Representatives.

headline: How to Rake Leaves on a Windy Day
abstract: After the elections, a red-state liberal ponders futility — and against all odds, arrives at hope.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Leaf blowers are like giant whining insects that have moved into your skull. They are swarming just behind your eyes, drilling deep inside your teeth. Leaf blowers have ruined autumn with their insistent whine and their noxious fumes, and they are everywhere. You may believe it is futile to resist them, but you still can. In almost every situation where something is loud, obnoxious and seemingly ubiquitous, resistance is an option.

headline: E! People’s Choice Awards Red Carpet
abstract: There’s only one awards show that celebrates not only musicians and actors but also game changers, social celebrities, animal stars and beauty influencers, all on one stage.
lead_paragraph: There’s only one awards show that celebrates not only musicians and actors but also game changers, social celebrities, animal stars and beauty influencers, all on one stage: The E! People’s Choice Awards. Formerly hosted on CBS, this year the awards have a new network and no host. Votes came in across platforms like Snapchat, Instagram and Facebook, and categories have been expanded to include best T.V. show revival and best concert tour.

headline: Now Serving Pie. And Only Pie.
abstract: How The Times created a print special section that opens up to reveal a kaleidoscopic, 48-inch array of life-size pastries.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

headline: Let the People Vote
keywords: ['States (US)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Ex-Convicts', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Referendums']
abstract: America finally has a pro-democracy movement — and it did very well at the polls last week.
lead_paragraph: The United States finally has the pro-democracy movement that it needs.

headline: Remembering the Forgotten War
abstract: Technically, Korea wasn’t even a war. But that doesn’t mean we can ignore the veterans who fought in it.
lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. — Although more than 1.8 million Americans served in the Korean War — and more than 33,000 were killed in action — it is still our Forgotten War, a kind of also-ran in our historical consciousness.

headline: Deadly Gaza Raid by Israel Threatens Nascent Cease-Fire
abstract: A covert mission apparently went awry on Sunday, leaving an Israeli lieutenant colonel and at least seven Palestinians dead and setting off a flurry of rocket fire and airstrikes.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A covert Israeli operation in the Gaza Strip apparently went bad on Sunday, leaving at least seven Palestinians dead, including one senior Hamas military commander, and puncturing a nascent cease-fire with a flurry of airstrikes and rocket fire.

headline: You Have a Right to Weariness
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Impeachment', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates']
abstract: The struggle for goodness and decency is an eternal struggle, not a seasonal one.
lead_paragraph: Do we have a right to weariness in an era of animus? More precisely, can we afford it, or is exhaustion a luxury reserved for those whose wealth, privilege and status insulate them from the losses the rest of us could suffer? Does patriotic defense of country require perpetual, obsessive vigilance, or is it permissible to retreat occasionally for one’s own mental and spiritual health?

headline: Parishioners Gather to Support Bronx Bishop Accused of Sexual Abuse
abstract: John Jenik, an auxiliary bishop at Our Lady of Refuge in the Bronx, remains barred from the church. Supporters are skeptical of a sexual abuse allegation against him.
lead_paragraph: On Friday evening, inside Our Lady of Refuge church in the Bronx, a man tapped on his phone and then raised it high, so each of the approximately 250 people in attendance could see the screen.

headline: Uncounted Ballots, Overvoted Ballots: Why Is the Governor Claiming Fraud in Florida’s Election?
keywords: ['Elections, Governors', 'Elections, Senate', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Voting and Voters', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Questions swirl around the vote tally in Florida, where Gov. Rick Scott has filed lawsuits over the handling of ballots, alleging fraud. The truth is more complicated.
lead_paragraph: LAUDERHILL, Fla. — In the chaos that has swirled over the vote count in Florida following Tuesday’s midterm elections, one headline made its way ominously around the state: A teacher in Broward County had discovered a box labeled “provisional ballots,” left behind at the polling place at her school.

headline: E! People’s Choice Red Carpet
abstract: For the first time E! took over the People’s Choice Awards. Here are photos from the red carpet.
lead_paragraph: For the first time E! took over the People’s Choice Awards. Here are photos from the red carpet.

headline: ‘Outlander’ Season 4, Episode 2 Recap: Southern Hospitality
abstract: Claire and Jamie arrive at River Run, there to meet dear old Auntie Jocasta ... and her 152 slaves.
lead_paragraph: Last time “Outlander” engaged the subject of slavery, Claire and Jamie bought a person. (They promised to free him — and did, although Temeraire’s patent disbelief was that subplot’s best note.) But he existed largely as a plot point, and the slave auction scene was more concerned with how Claire felt than with the slaves. The white-savior framework felt like a way for the show to acknowledge slavery without making Jamie and Claire tackle it head on.

headline: Review: Michael C. Hall Probes the Despair of ‘Thom Pain’
abstract: In Oliver Butler’s revival, Will Eno’s reputation-making monologue of masochistic bleakness suddenly feels a lot less shocking.
lead_paragraph: The dark and sulfurous chamber of Thom Pain’s mind has been unsealed for public inspection again. Audiences already familiar with Will Eno’s “Thom Pain (based on nothing),” which has been revived by the Signature Theater, may find this Stygian space roomier and less oppressive than they remembered.

headline: Review: Mike Birbiglia Is a Very Nervous Dad in ‘The New One’
abstract: This one-man show, about the anxieties of impending fatherhood, makes a seductive case for seeing a comedian live in the age of Netflix.
lead_paragraph: If Mike Birbiglia were a piece of furniture, he would surely be a well-worn, deeply stained, slightly squishy couch, much like the one he describes at the beginning of “The New One,” his winning Broadway debut at the Cort Theater. That may not sound like a flattering comparison.

headline: Quotation of the Day: In the Campaign, Democrats Didn’t Let Trump Distract Them. That Will Be Harder Now.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 12, 2018
lead_paragraph: “These Democrats didn’t get elected, by and large, to war with Trump. They got elected to try and get some positive things done on issues like health care and economic issues.”

headline: Corrections: November 12, 2018
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, November 12, 2018.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, November 12, 2018.

headline: Australian Woman Accused of Spiking Strawberries With Needles
abstract: The tampering fueled a nationwide panic that severely hurt the industry, prompted copycat incidents and led some stores to stop stocking the fruit.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The Queensland police have arrested a former strawberry industry worker for spiking strawberries with needles, a crime that fueled a nationwide scare that crippled Australia’s strawberry industry.

headline: This Town Once Feared the 10-Story Waves. Then the Extreme Surfers Showed Up.
abstract: The residents of Nazaré used to think the immense waves that broke against town’s cliffs were deadly to any who braved them. Today, those same waves have made the town a surfers’ mecca.
lead_paragraph: NAZARÉ, Portugal — At the market in the ancient fishing village of Nazaré, Portuguese pensioners shopped for their fruit and vegetables. Retired fishermen chatted over coffee. And a record-breaking American surfer sipped on a cucumber and celery smoothie.

headline: World War I, California, Gaza Strip: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘The Price of Everything’ and ‘Mars’
abstract: An HBO documentary spotlights the role of art in the age of consumerism. And the space exploration series “Mars” returns on National Geographic.
lead_paragraph: An HBO documentary spotlights the role of art in the age of consumerism. And the space exploration series “Mars” returns on National Geographic.

headline: Saudi Arabia Is Misusing Mecca
keywords: ['Mosques', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Politics and Government', 'Royal Families', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Social Media']
abstract: In the aftermath of the Jamal Khashoggi murder, the kingdom has exploited the podium of the Grand Mosque in Mecca by using its imams to praise, sanctify and defend the rulers and their actions.
lead_paragraph: The rulers of Saudi Arabia derive much of their legitimacy and prestige in the Muslim world from their control and upkeep of the Grand Mosque and the Kaaba in Mecca and the mosque of Prophet Muhammad in Medina. King Salman, like the rulers before him, wears the title of the “Khadim al-Ḥaramayn al-Sharifayn,” which is translated as the “Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques” or, more precisely, “The Servant of the Two Noble Sanctuaries.”

headline: On Politics: Democrats Contemplate Their House Majority
abstract: Nancy Pelosi has encouraged fellow Democrats in private meetings to resist the urge to leap at President Trump’s every utterance and misdeed.
lead_paragraph: Good Monday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

headline: U.S.-China relations are bound to change
abstract: The economic relationship between the U.S. and China will still be existential and essential, but there will be a large underlying shift that will bring about a different price point, different equilibrium, different terms. Marginal shifts will come about as a function of the continuing trade talks but we need to be cognizant of the more fundamental shift in the relationship.
lead_paragraph: The economic relationship between the U.S. and China will still be existential and essential, but there will be a large underlying shift that will bring about a different price point, different equilibrium, different terms. Marginal shifts will come about as a function of the continuing trade talks but we need to be cognizant of the more fundamental shift in the relationship.

headline: Word + Quiz: affable
abstract: This word has appeared in 165 articles on nytimes.com in the past year.

headline: New York Magazine’s Sites Are Going Behind a Paywall
abstract: Following a media-wide trend, a web pioneer finally decides to put a price tag on its online offerings: A digital subscription will cost $5 a month, or $50 a year.
lead_paragraph: Information may want to be free, as an aphorism had it in the early days of digital media. But these days, increasingly, journalism wants to be paid for.

headline: They Were Stopped at the Texas Border. Their Nightmare Had Only Just Begun.
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Sex Crimes', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: After crossing the Rio Grande, three immigrant women were picked up by a Border Patrol agent in 2014. Their relief soon turned to terror.
lead_paragraph: MCALLEN, Tex. — The Border Patrol agent, she remembers, was calm when he tied her to the tree and put silver duct tape over her mouth. He said very little.

headline: Blockchain will create more wealth
abstract: Joseph Lubin thinks that blockchain technology will push us from a scarcity mindset to an abundance mindset, allowing us to be in greater control of our own identity and agency and in turn creating more wealth.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Lubin thinks that blockchain technology will push us from a scarcity mindset to an abundance mindset, allowing us to be in greater control of our own identity and agency and in turn creating more wealth.

headline: Luxury is a global game
abstract: Will the geographical origin of a luxury brand become less important in this global age? Thierry Andretta says that luxury has always been a global concept, and that brands need to play a global game to appeal to its customers.
lead_paragraph: Will the geographical origin of a luxury brand become less important in this global age? Thierry Andretta says that luxury has always been a global concept, and that brands need to play a global game to appeal to its customers.

headline: ‘Couples, Some With Children in Strollers, Surround Me as They Pose for Photos’
abstract: Retrieving a copy of a marriage license in person, unsolicited health advice from a stranger and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: In North Korea, Missile Bases Suggest a Great Deception
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Trump says the nuclear threat from North Korea is over. New satellite images of 16 hidden ballistic missile bases suggest that it has worsened since his summit meeting.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — North Korea is moving ahead with its ballistic missile program at 16 hidden bases that have been identified in new commercial satellite images, a network long known to American intelligence agencies but left undiscussed as President Trump claims to have neutralized the North’s nuclear threat.

headline: The importance of brand protection
abstract: Alibaba must be a global leader in brand protection. Protecting brands and rooting out counterfeits is good for consumers, and good for Alibaba itself.
lead_paragraph: Alibaba must be a global leader in brand protection. Protecting brands and rooting out counterfeits is good for consumers, and good for Alibaba itself.

headline: Coming to Papua New Guinea: World Leaders (and 40 Maseratis)
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The island nation, the poorest member of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation regional forum, has spent lavishly as host of the group’s annual summit meeting.
lead_paragraph: PORT MORESBY, Papua New Guinea — The Maseratis and Bentleys have been delivered. Laborers from China have repaired roads and installed bus stop shelters with signs saying “China Aid.” Three cruise ships will serve as temporary hotels.

headline: Who Is Your Favorite Visual Artist? What Is Your Favorite Work of Art?
abstract: What artists or works do you most appreciate?
lead_paragraph: Do you have a favorite work of art? Who created it? Is that person your favorite visual artist? If not, who is?

headline: Something Happened to U.S. Drug Costs in the 1990s
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Medicare', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Nineteen Hundred Nineties']
abstract: Two decades ago, the costs began rising well beyond that of other nations, and in recent years have shot up again. What can explain it?
lead_paragraph: There was a time when America approximated other wealthy countries in drug spending. But in the late 1990s, U.S. spending took off. It tripled between 1997 and 2007, according to a study in Health Affairs.

headline: Too Much Caffeine May Stress the Heart
abstract: In moderate doses caffeine has mainly positive effects for most people. But it increases production of cortisol, which can lead to health problems including anxiety, weight gain and heart disease.
lead_paragraph: As my brother neared the end of a smooth, swift recovery from open-heart surgery to bypass an 80-percent blockage in his heart’s most important artery recently, he reverted to a longstanding habit of downing many cups a day of strong coffee. I objected, but he insisted that the caffeine doesn’t affect him, meaning it doesn’t disturb his sleep.

headline: The War to End All Measles
keywords: ['Measles', 'Mumps', 'Children and Childhood', 'Preventive Medicine', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'World War I (1914-18)', 'Parenting']
abstract: Young people who went to war 100 years ago often died from what are now preventable childhood diseases. We can try to keep today’s children a little safer.
lead_paragraph: Armistice Day was first celebrated in 1919, a year after the armistice that ended the long and terrible first World War, taking effect at precisely 11:11 a.m. on Nov. 11. It was renamed Veterans Day in 1954, to honor all those who had served, but also perhaps to acknowledge that the “war to end all wars” had done no such thing.

headline: Applications Open for the 2019 New York Portfolio Review
keywords: ['Photography', 'News and News Media', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: Applications Open for the 2019 New York Portfolio Review
lead_paragraph: It takes time, passion and obsession to make great work. But you also need the opportunity to have your work seen in the first place. And since we at Lens believe only the quality of work should matter — not your connections or bank account — we are again bringing together 160 talented photographers with 75 top photo editors, publishers, curators, gallery owners and video producers, for the 7th annual New York Portfolio Review on March 30 and 31 in New York City.

headline: Trump’s Nafta Plan Could Be Upended by Democrats’ House Takeover
keywords: ['North American Free Trade Agreement', 'United States International Relations', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: The president wanted speedy passage of a revised trade deal, but Democrats want significant improvements to labor and other provisions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s promise to quickly pass a revamped North American Free Trade Agreement has been upended by the midterm elections, with Democrats who will soon control the House vowing to withhold their support to extract greater protections for American workers.

headline: The Wheels on These Buses Go Round and Round With Zero Emissions
keywords: ['Buses', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Education (K-12)', 'Environment', 'Diesel Power']
abstract: Some states, concerned about pollution and global warming, see school buses as the next frontier for electric vehicles. Prices are high, but that's starting to change.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. — “Some of the kids call it the singing bus,” said Juliessa Diclo Cruz, 10, as she rode in back of one of New York State’s first-ever electric school buses on a chilly October morning.

headline: In Brazil, Animals Cross a Road of No Return
abstract: Highway BR-262 is among the deadliest in the world for wildlife. Biologist Wagner Fischer has been monitoring its grim toll for more than two decades.
lead_paragraph: Whenever Wagner Fischer drives, he notices the roadkill.

headline: ‘It’s Like Reliving My Past’: Harvard Lawsuit Echoes Previous Fight Over Race and Admissions
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Minorities', 'Colleges and Universities', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Asian-Americans']
abstract: A lawsuit against Harvard has spurred a national discussion over affirmative action. To one former professor and one congressman, the debate reminds them of another 30 years ago.
lead_paragraph: In March 1990, L. Ling-chi Wang got on a plane to Washington, where he felt that his words were being twisted.

headline: Finding a Mom Network in Battery Park City
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Single Mothers']
abstract: A single mother leaves TriBeCa for Gateway Plaza, a rental complex that she discovers is “tailor-made for families.”
lead_paragraph: When Aisling McDonagh became pregnant with her daughter three years ago, she was living in Independence Plaza, a three-tower complex in TriBeCa.

headline: American Jews Face a Choice: Create Meaning or Fade Away
abstract: Five new books touch on American Jewish identity and what will sustain it into the future.
lead_paragraph: When a gunman slaughtered 11 worshipers in a Pittsburgh synagogue on a Shabbat morning last month, American Jews were left with a jumble of intense emotions: horror and fear, certainly, but also an old embattled feeling, centuries in the making. They were victims, in America, a country that has never seen even a hint of a pogrom. In their pain and worry, individual Jews had a rare chance to feel themselves part of a larger community — one that mourns together, gets angry together, imbued with a separate and unique identity, threatened yet resilient. And in this, victimhood offered an illusion.

headline: With Petrino Debacle, Not Being a Judge of Character Bites Louisville Again
abstract: Louisville thought it saw something it could exploit: a willingness to hire top coaches with checkered pasts. It did not work out with Bobby Petrino, or with Rick Pitino.
lead_paragraph: Less than a year ago, Bobby Petrino was in a New York City ballroom waiting to see if his quarterback, Lamar Jackson, would win the Heisman Trophy. Jackson came in third, but that was O.K.: He had won it the year before, the first Louisville player to do so.

headline: Where Will Science Take Us? To the Stars
keywords: ['Telescopes and Observatories', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Stars and Galaxies']
abstract: A monthlong visit to observatories in Chile, Hawaii and Los Angeles revealed spellbinding visions of the heavens.
lead_paragraph: After 30 hours of bumping along on planes and buses, at long last I stood in the darkness and gazed upon an immense night sky. My long journey seemingly had brought me to the shoreline of interstellar space rather than the high-altitude plateau that is Chile’s Atacama Desert.

headline: U.S. Navy Carrier Suffers Second Aircraft Crash in Weeks
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety']
abstract: An F/A-18 Super Hornet, assigned to the U.S.S. Ronald Reagan, on Monday crashed into the sea northeast of the Philippines. The two aviators inside the plane were rescued.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A United States Navy warplane crashed into the sea northeast of the Philippines on Monday, the second crash in less than a month involving aircraft from the carrier the U.S.S. Ronald Reagan.

headline: Taliban Slaughter Elite Afghan Troops, and a ‘Safe’ District Is Falling
abstract: Times journalists traveled to the site of a Taliban assault. Instead of a fierce stand by government commandos, they found a massacre of those American-trained troops.
lead_paragraph: SANG-E-MASHA, Afghanistan — One pickup truck after another arrived at the government compound in a district capital in Afghanistan on Sunday, pulling around to the back of the governor’s office to unload the dead, out of sight of panicked residents.

headline: Do the Math. Moderate Democrats Will Not Win in 2020.
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)']
abstract: Learning the right lessons from the midterms is key for the party.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Gillum and Stacey Abrams, progressive African-American Democratic candidates, may not have won their races for governor in Florida and Georgia (both are still too close to call). But the strategy they followed is still the best strategy for Democrats to win: inspiring, mobilizing and turning out voters of color and progressive whites.

headline: Meet the New House Democrats: They May Not Toe the Party Line
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Midterm Elections (2018)']
abstract: The freshman House Democrats are the most diverse, most female class in history — and span the ideological spectrum. They arrive in Washington for orientation this week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There is a former N.F.L. linebacker, a climate scientist, and a rapper with a Harvard Law degree. There is one immigrant from Somalia and another from Ecuador. There are two former C.I.A. officials, an Air Force veteran, a former Navy helicopter pilot, and a retired Marine commander — all of them women. Not to mention a pediatrician and a human rights advocate.

headline: The Dallas Cowboys: Striving for Mediocrity in a Topsy-Turvy World
abstract: A victory over the equally-mediocre Philadelphia Eagles gives the Cowboys a chance of winning the mediocre N.F.C. East.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Jerry Jones strode into the Dallas Cowboys’ locker room a few minutes before midnight Sunday. “Woooooo!” Jones bellowed, à la the wrestler Ric Flair, as he moved from player to player, pumping hands, offering hugs, dispensing congratulations after a 27-20 triumph against the Eagles that, he said, thrust his team into N.F.C. East contention.

abstract: Now, after holding back for so long, is the time for the luxury industry to jump into online shopping, says Ian Rogers, chief digital officer of LVMH. But the focus should be on making online shopping a luxury, with customer experiences, not technical capabilities, as the main priority.
lead_paragraph: Now, after holding back for so long, is the time for the luxury industry to jump into online shopping, says Ian Rogers, chief digital officer of LVMH. But the focus should be on making online shopping a luxury, with customer experiences, not technical capabilities, as the main priority.

abstract: While online shopping will become ever more prevalent, brand-building will still be fundamentally an offline, physical experience, says Scott Malkin, founder and chairman of Value Retail P.L.C.
lead_paragraph: While online shopping will become ever more prevalent, brand-building will still be fundamentally an offline, physical experience, says Scott Malkin, founder and chairman of Value Retail P.L.C.

headline: China, After Outcry, Reinstates Ban on Rhino and Tiger Parts in Medicine
abstract: The State Council said in a rare concession that it had decided to postpone an order to undo a 25-year prohibition on the trade.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese government, bowing to pressure from environmental groups, said on Monday that it would temporarily reinstate a ban on the use of rhinoceros horns and tiger bones in medicine.

headline: Stimulus Plan or Populist Giveaway? Italy’s Budget Sets Up Clash With E.U.
abstract: How best to invigorate the country’s economy has reanimated a wrenching debate in Europe about whether it is better to spend or cut in the face of stagnation.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Italy — Italy’s desperate need for a financial shot in the arm is palpable at all levels of the economy, from the entrepreneurs in the industrial north who are hungry for tax breaks and a streamlined bureaucracy to the welfare seekers in the poverty-stricken south, with its dizzying levels of youth unemployment.

headline: Broadway’s Next Evan Hansen? A 16-Year-Old High School Junior
abstract: Andrew Barth Feldman is to take over the role in “Dear Evan Hansen” on Jan. 30.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Barth Feldman has been keeping a list of people he’ll need to call when the news comes out: that he, a 16-year-old high school junior, will be making his Broadway debut this winter as the title character in “Dear Evan Hansen.”

headline: Five More Museums Acquire Art From Souls Grown Deep Foundation
abstract: To reshape the narrative of art told by American institutions, the foundation will transfer 51 works by black self-taught artists to additional museums.
lead_paragraph: In a strategic effort to reshape the narrative of American art, the Souls Grown Deep Foundation will help five museums acquire paintings, sculptures and works on paper by self-taught African-American artists of the South. These acquisitions bring to 12 the number of museums that have received more than 300 works from the Atlanta-based nonprofit, through gifts and purchase.

headline: Alone in New York, She Needed a Mattress
abstract: Escaping the Nazis taught Yana Gilchenok to survive hardship. But everyone can use a comfortable place to sleep.
lead_paragraph: When she was 13, Nazi bombs dropped on Yana Gilchenok’s house in the Gorodok ghetto of Belarus, driving her, along with her mother, sister and niece, to seek shelter with other families in a nearby forest.

headline: Before the Fights Over Recounts: An Election Day Vote on Voting
abstract: A flurry of ballot measures on Election Day were the latest move to reshape how we vote, and who can cast a ballot.
lead_paragraph: Amid the recounts, recriminations and allegations of voter suppression or ballot fraud, something else happened in Tuesday’s elections — a wave of actions aimed at making voting easier and fairer that is an often-overlooked strain in the nation’s voting wars.

headline: What to Cook Right Now
abstract: It might be a nice time for Japanese fried chicken with soy sauce-pickled eggs, a kale, coconut tomato salad, or slow-cooker chicken tacos.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I was in Portland, Ore., over the weekend, eating great food (at Han Oak and Kachinka, if you're wondering). The visit was a chance to talk to the chef Edward Lee about his book “Buttermilk Graffiti” at the Portland Book Festival. There was no cooking for me.

headline: ‘Toy Story 4’ Trailer: Introducing Forky
abstract: Tony Hale joins the returning members of the voice cast, including Tom Hanks, Tim Allen and Joan Cusack. The movie is due next June.
lead_paragraph: More than 20 years after the original “Toy Story,” the toys are back in town with a teaser for the fourth installment of the smash animated franchise. Favorites like Woody (voiced by Tom Hanks), Buzz Lightyear (Tim Allen) and Jessie (Joan Cusack) frolic in a circle to Judy Collins’s cover of Joni Mitchell’s “Both Sides Now” until a newcomer wreaks havoc. That would be Forky.

headline: Tim Daly, Sibling Bonds and the Stage
abstract: Daly speaks about “Downstairs,” the play Theresa Rebeck wrote for him and his sister Tyne. He also discusses his life and his arts activism.
lead_paragraph: In 1979, Tim Daly was playing a Russian soldier outfitted with an imposing black wool hat in Shaw’s “Arms and the Man” in Palm Beach, Fla., when his older sister Tyne, who was performing nearby at the Burt Reynolds Dinner Theater, dropped by on closing night.

headline: Cost of Botched Gaza Spy Mission? Israel’s Back on Brink of War
abstract: Israel and Hamas exchanged intense fire after a covert Israeli operation went awry. The resulting fighting threatened to scuttle peace talks.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — On Sunday, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu assured Israelis weary of conflict with Palestinians in the Gaza Strip that he was “doing everything I can in order to avoid an unnecessary war.”

headline: It’s Time to Make Video Games Safe for Children
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Ratings (Parental Guidance)', 'Children and Childhood', 'E-Sports']
abstract: Video games, streaming sites and eSports are plagued with trolls.
lead_paragraph: Imagine that your daughter is playing Fortnite, and a troll in another country joins the game and begins sexually harassing her. Imagine that your son is watching his favorite video gamer live-stream an eSports game, and the streamer begins to shout obscenities.

headline: Tales From the Warhol Factory
abstract: In each of three successive spaces called the Factory, Andy Warhol created movies, paintings, time capsules and psychosexual dramas with a half-life of many decades. Here his collaborators recall the places, the times and the man.
lead_paragraph: Concealed behind the pasty mask, the trademark fright wig and the impassive expression Andy Warhol showed to the world was a man of roiling complexities. Depending on who does the talking, Warhol was either an emotional vampire draining vital juices from the animated nut-jobs he gathered to him or a kindly, if slightly creepy, avuncular figure whose motives have been misunderstood.

headline: How to Reduce the Risk of the Scary Thing You Want to Do
abstract: Ready to start a restaurant? Make a big investment? Quit your job? First, try a small test of your big idea.
lead_paragraph: You shouldn’t start a restaurant unless you know people like your cooking.

headline: What the Heck Is That?
abstract: A look at one of the entries in last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
lead_paragraph: Many animals appear in the New York Times Crossword, but the ring-tailed COATI, a relative of the raccoon, seems to go relatively unrecognized by solvers.

headline: The Gun-Safety Issue Is Actually Helping Democrats
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Campaign Finance', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: Midterm election results suggest that the power of the N.R.A. may be diminishing.
lead_paragraph: It is an unsettling coincidence that mass shootings bookended the 2018 election, from a Pittsburgh synagogue on Oct. 27 to a bar in Thousand Oaks, Calif., on Nov. 7. The election that took place in between, though, demonstrated that Democrats and even some Republicans found gun-safety advocacy a boon to their campaigns in a way not seen in a long time. In comparison with previous elections, the gun-rights forces’ customary blaring megaphone seemed nowhere near as loud as usual — or as effective. This is borne out by an examination of public attitudes, candidate positions, money and exposure.

headline: Wildfire Becomes Deadliest in California History

lead_paragraph: PARADISE, Calif. — [For the latest updates on the California wildfires, read our Tuesday live briefing here]

headline: ‘Touch Not the Cat’
abstract: The Scottish wildcat, the last native cat in the United Kingdom, is endangered; fewer than 100 purebred specimens remain in the wild.
lead_paragraph: A. The biggest threat to the Scottish wildcat, Felis silvestris, is widespread interbreeding with feral domestic cats. The wildcats are endangered; just 45 to 100 purebred specimens remain, mostly roaming remote parts of Scotland’s western Highlands.

headline: Does Calgary Really Want the Winter Olympics? Does Anyone?
abstract: The Canadian city is set to vote on whether to bid for the 2026 Games. Norway and Austria and Switzerland have already passed.
lead_paragraph: CALGARY, Alberta — Hobbled by a reputation for gross expense and corruption, the International Olympic Committee has become a mendicant, shuffling from nation to nation, shaking its cup and asking if anyone might be interested in bidding on the 2026 Winter Games.

headline: Meet the KGB Spies Who Invented Fake News
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'News and News Media', 'your-feed-opinionvideo']
abstract: We reveal how one of the biggest fake news stories ever concocted — the 1984 AIDS-is-a-biological-weapon hoax — went viral in the pre-Internet era. Meet the KGB cons who invented it, and the “truth squad” that quashed it. For a bit.
lead_paragraph: We reveal how one of the biggest fake news stories ever concocted — the 1984 AIDS-is-a-biological-weapon hoax — went viral in the pre-Internet era. Meet the KGB cons who invented it, and the “truth squad” that quashed it. For a bit.

headline: Like a Diamond in the Sky: The Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree Has a New Glow
abstract: Daniel Libeskind’s architectural feat — all 900 pounds, 70 spikes, and three million Swarovski crystals of it — will light up the night at Rockefeller Center.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Libeskind, the world-renowned master-plan architect for the reconstruction of the World Trade Center, first saw the Rockefeller Center Christmas tree as a teenager, in 1961, shortly after he had moved to New York from Poland — though the star was not at all memorable.

headline: The Story of America, Told Through Mark Twain’s Favorite Foods
abstract: In a new audio series, the actor Nick Offerman explores political, cultural and ecological shifts through the author’s palate.
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD — Mark Twain was a well-traveled literary superstar, so famous that his editor once journeyed to Washington to ask President Theodore Roosevelt if he would move Thanksgiving because it coincided with Twain’s birthday plans. (Twain moved his party.)

headline: Have You Had to Flee the California Wildfires? We Want to Hear From You
abstract: As we cover the devastating fires in California, we are hoping to hear more from those who have been forced to evacuate.
lead_paragraph: Three major fires are ravaging California, killing dozens, destroying thousands of homes and forcing families to leave almost everything behind and evacuate.

headline: Merkel Antagonist Quits Party Post but Stays On as Interior Minister
abstract: Horst Seehofer’s announcement that he would step down as head of his Bavarian conservative party comes after a similar decision by Chancellor Angela Merkel.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Horst Seehofer, the defiant German interior minister whose provocations have undermined Chancellor Angela Merkel’s government and eroded support for his own conservative party, said Monday that he would step down as head of the Christian Social Union, a key part of Ms. Merkel’s governing coalition.

headline: Portrait of a Marriage, Onstage and at the Barricades
abstract: The archive of Ruby Dee and Ossie Davis, now at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, traces more than 60 years in the theater, in the movies and at the front lines of social activism.
lead_paragraph: In a 1995 joint profile in The New York Times, the actors and activists Ruby Dee and Ossie Davis were described  as being “without peer in an industry not known for nurturing black people, older people or long marriages.”

headline: The Rise and Fall of Turkey Brining
abstract: After two decades of flying high, the wet-brined bird has lost altitude with many of the food-media influencers who sent it soaring.
lead_paragraph: Dear Thanksgiving cooks of America: On behalf of food writers everywhere, I apologize.

lead_paragraph: In rehearsals for “A Chorus Line,” it can be difficult to tell where practice ends and the show begins.

headline: Japanese Theater Inspires a New Opera of Celestial Textures
abstract: “Only the Sound Remains,” Kaija Saariaho and Peter Sellars’s reinterpretation of Ezra Pound’s translation of two Noh plays, arrives in New York.
lead_paragraph: “The Noh is unquestionably one of the great arts of the world,” the poet Ezra Pound wrote in 1916, “and it is quite possibly one of the most recondite.”

lead_paragraph: Stocks dropped on Monday, giving back a slice of their recent gains as investors dumped shares in some of the large technology companies that hold outsize sway over major market indexes.

keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Space and Astronomy', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']

lead_paragraph: ACCESSORY TO WAR The Unspoken Alliance Between Astrophysics and the Military By Neil deGrasse Tyson and Avis Lang Read by Neil deGrasse Tyson and Courtney B. Vance18 hours, 38 minutes. Random House Audio.

lead_paragraph: Stan Lee was for many the embodiment of Marvel Comics, if not comic books in general.

headline: Stan Lee Is Dead at 95; Superhero of Marvel Comics
abstract: Mr. Lee helped create Spider-Man, the X-Men, the Fantastic Four, Iron Man and others while overseeing his company’s emergence as a media behemoth.
lead_paragraph: If Stan Lee revolutionized the comic book world in the 1960s, which he did, he left as big a stamp — maybe bigger — on the even wider pop culture landscape of today.
