headline: Should PoMo Architecture, at the 50-Year Mark, Be Saved?
abstract: Post-Modernist monuments by Michael Graves and Philip Johnson are spared but a museum addition by Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown is being demolished.
lead_paragraph: Post-Modernist buildings, those teasing, colorful mash-ups of columns, pilasters and pediments, were both praised and reviled in the 1970s and ’80s, their heyday. But by the end of the ’80s they fell out of fashion, consigned with surprising abruptness to the dustbin of architectural history. In 1988, at the paradigm-shifting “Deconstructivist Architecture” show at the Museum of Modern Art, Michael Graves, one of America’s pre-eminent Post-Modernists, observed, “I’m toast.”

headline: Notes From the Book Review Archives
abstract: In which we consult the Book Review’s past to shed light on the books of the present. This week: a vintage review of holiday books.
lead_paragraph: The holidays are a stressful time for many reasons, not least of them the art of finding the perfect gift. In 1909, an unsigned review of the season’s holiday books meditated on the pressures of gift giving and concluded that no gift is as perfect as a book.

headline: Ghosts, Robots and Monsters: A Roundup of New Sci-Fi and Fantasy
abstract: As the weather grows wetter and colder, it’s an excellent time to hole up with fantastical new fiction.
lead_paragraph: It’s that deepening part of autumn where darkness spreads wetter and colder, paving a path for winter and illness, and eliciting a general reluctance to leave one’s home. In other words, it’s an especially excellent time to hole up with some fantastic books, so here’s a roundup of recent robots, ghosts and a variety of monsters to take with one’s tea.

headline: The Orchestra Brawls in a ‘Beer and Pizza’ Oedipus Opera
abstract: Mark-Anthony Turnage’s raucous “Greek,” which moves Sophocles forward to an unsettled contemporary London, comes to the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Oedipus is wearing a bright red tracksuit. His parents, brandishing beer bottles, are off to the pub to watch a football match. “So, I was born in Tufnell Park,” he says aggressively to the audience, adding: “It’s a cesspit!”

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Make Danny Bowien’s pastrami, if you’re feeling particularly ambitious (and if you’re not, we have a hack).
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Hanukkah gets underway on Sunday night, so of course we’ve polished the silver in our collection of best Hanukkah recipes. We’ve got latkes and challah if you’re celebrating, sufganiyot (above) and kugel, briskets for days.

headline: The Latest Romance Novels: Firefighters, Buff Male Nannies, Astronauts and More
abstract: Our romance columnist, Jaime Green, picks her fall favorites.
lead_paragraph: Romance is both loved and derided for its formulaic nature. It is comfort, escapism and reassurance in a troubling world. It is generic in the truest sense, a genre defined and constrained by a handful of conventions. The heart of every romance is a love story, and by the last page of the book the lovers wind up together, happily ever after or at least “happily for now.” (Less codified but no less crucial is that no children or pets are harmed. This is a place for happy endings, after all.) These rules give rise to a rich variety of stories, but they are constraints nonetheless. Here are four recent books that either test the boundaries or occupy the essential core of what a romance novel is.

headline: South Korean Women Smash Makeup, and Patriarchy
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Beauty (Concept)', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Plastic Surgery', 'Celebrities', '#MeToo Movement']
abstract: The movement is called “Escape the Corset.” Plus: Jameela Jamil’s social media campaign against those weight loss teas and remembering Harvey Milk.

headline: How to Stop Radical C.E.O.s From Going Rogue
abstract: There are four obvious lines of defense that can be used to stop chief executives from engulfing themselves and their companies in scandal.
lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline: After Whitey Bulger Killing, Warden of ‘Misery Mountain’ Faces Removal
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: As the investigation expands, there are indications that the lead suspect was allowed to have unusual influence with inmates and prison staff.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Bureau of Prisons is considering the ouster of the warden of the prison where James (Whitey) Bulger, the famous mobster and informant, was murdered in October.

headline: In ‘I Might Regret This,’ Abbi Jacobson Hits the Road. Insomnia, Heartbreak, Hilarity and Self-Discovery Ensue.
abstract: Ahead of the fifth and final season of “Broad City,” its co-creator and co-star leaves New York to see the country, finding herself (and some good laughs) along the way.
lead_paragraph: I MIGHT REGRET THIS Essays, Drawings, Vulnerabilities, and Other Stuff By Abbi Jacobson 313 pp. Grand Central. $28.

headline: What Is ‘La Lista,’ Which Controls Migrants’ Fates in Tijuana?
abstract: The first all-important step for caravan migrants who come to northern Mexico to seek asylum in the United States is to get on The List.
lead_paragraph: TIJUANA, Mexico — They call it “La Lista” — The List. And the thousands of migrants who have arrived in northern Mexico in recent weeks with plans to apply for asylum in the United States have quickly learned its importance to their future.

headline: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Some fiction writers try to capture reality, using stories to illuminate social conditions or plumb interior lives. Others just like to make up crazy things. (And also illuminate social conditions and interior lives, yes! Don’t @ us.) We like both kinds of fiction around here, but our picks this week decidedly, and determinedly, range beyond the bounds of conventional realism. There’s an austere little fairy tale about the chaos of sexual desire, “The Governesses.” There’s a turbulent, myth-inflected debut that made its author the youngest-ever finalist for the Booker Prize, “Everything Under.” There’s a dystopian New York story about consumerism and immigration, “Severance,” and a surreal Japanese story collection, “The Lonesome Bodybuilder,” that shakes up narrative expectations right alongside social expectations about gender and marriage and body image. And while Louisa Hall’s “Trinity” would seem to be more traditional than any of those — it’s a biographical, historical novel about Robert Oppenheimer and his work on the atomic bomb — even that goes about it in a nontraditional way.

headline: How Did He Catch That? A New N.F.L. Stat Can Confirm Your Amazement
abstract: Through tracking devices attached all over the field, and to the players, the league measures the difficulty of a passing play with a statistic called completion probability.
lead_paragraph: Philip Rivers’s 4-yard touchdown to Keenan Allen in the Los Angeles Chargers’ 45-10 victory last Sunday tied the N.F.L. record for consecutive completions to start a game, with 25. It was the kind of play that warranted several viewings, just to marvel at Rivers’s synchronicity with Allen.

headline: Leave Your Fondue Pot Behind (but Keep the Fondue)
abstract: You don’t need to break out anything special for this rich, creamy fondue: Instead, a roasted squash is its serving vessel.
lead_paragraph: Fondue is not something you serve at a party; fondue is something that defines the party.

headline: The Man Who Brought Weimar Into Germans’ Living Rooms
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Nineteen Hundred Twenties']
abstract: With seven hit novels, now the basis of a blockbuster TV show, Volker Kutscher has helped ignite a debate in Germany about whether history is repeating itself.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Like many people, Volker Kutscher reads daily newspapers to keep up with things. What’s less usual is that the two papers he relies on, the Vossische Zeitung and the Berliner Tageblatt, have been out of print for more than seven decades.

headline: A Long Visit to Weimar-Era Berlin Through an Epic Graphic Novel
abstract: Jason Lutes’s “Berlin,” over two decades in the making, explores a society on the verge of collapse. One of two books reviewed in Ed Park’s Graphic Content column.
lead_paragraph: Every 40 pages or so in Jason Lutes’s BERLIN (Drawn + Quarterly, $49.95), a sequence appears that seems to hold the key to this massive graphic novel. In one of the earliest, a drawing instructor stands before a chalkboard, lecturing on the use of perspective. “The observer’s location is what really determines the placement of a vanishing point,” he explains, and asks his students to consider the views out of three adjacent windows in the studio. “Stand still in front of each and imagine it as a framed picture.” The same scene looks different depending on the observer’s position. It’s a metaphor, of course, for the book itself — an opus of more than 500 pages set in the late 1920s in the titular city, teeming with journalists and junkmen, artists and runaways, fiery rabble-rousers and burnt-out cases from the First World War, perceiving the city with their own nervous systems.

headline: Those Halls Won’t Deck Themselves: Pros Help With Holiday Lights
abstract: Many companies not only hang and remove the lights, but also store the decorations. The cost, though, can run from hundreds of dollars to thousands.
lead_paragraph: It is that time of year again, the time for outdoor holiday lighting, and homeowners now have options besides climbing a ladder in the cold to hang decorations.

headline: Makaya McCraven Sees the Future of Jazz Through Layers of History
abstract: The Chicago-based drummer keeps expanding his communal improvisational process. He released the album “Universal Beings” in October to wide acclaim.
lead_paragraph: On a rainy evening in August of last year, a barely advertised show by the Chicago-based drummer and beatsmith Makaya McCraven jammed an overflow crowd into H0L0, a sparse little basement club in Ridgewood, Queens. His band was a group of New York musicians, some of whom Mr. McCraven had hardly played with before; what they performed was entirely improvised, but with Mr. McCraven subtly steering, listeners had room to get comfortable, to fall into the music. His thick snare drum splattered against the bulb tones of Joel Ross’s vibraphone patterns, making an elliptical groove. Sometimes Brandee Younger’s plucks on the harp led Mr. McCraven into a buoyant, driving beat. Elsewhere, he minimized himself, letting Dezron Douglas’s bass guide the rhythm.

headline: When the Social Mission Comes Before Making a Buck
abstract: The “giveback” strategy, in which a social cause is an integral part of a corporate mission and brand marketing, has become a necessity for some entrepreneurs.
lead_paragraph: A granola bar can stave off hunger, but can it save a life? Two American actors, Ryan Devlin and Todd Grinnell, are aiming to find out.

headline: Catch Up on the Trailers You Need to See
abstract: “The Lion King” has already made a splash but are “Artemis Fowl,” “The Aftermath” and “Serenity” worth your time? These teasers suggest not.
lead_paragraph: Just as it did with back-to-back teasers of “Toy Story 4” and “Dumbo” in the week leading up to Thanksgiving, Disney dominated the trailer scene after the holiday. Here’s a look at what worked, and what didn’t.

headline: For the Art Lovers on Your List, Career Retrospectives of Two British Painters
abstract: Massive and lavish boxed sets give Bridget Riley and Lucian Freud their due.
lead_paragraph: BRIDGET RILEY The Complete Paintings Edited by Robert Kudielka with Alexandra Tommasini and Natalia Naish Illustrated. 1,572 pp. Thames & Hudson. $700.

headline: Rap’s Radical First Act
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Rap and Hip-Hop']
abstract: “The Last Poets,” by Christine Otten, is a novelized account of the radical Harlem spoken-word group whose style and themes paved the way for contemporary rappers.
lead_paragraph: THE LAST POETS By Christine Otten Translated by Jonathan Reeder 541 pp. World Editions. Paper, $17.99.

headline: African Officials Respond to France’s Restitution Report
abstract: Government officials from Senegal and the Ivory Coast ask for African treasures to be returned.
lead_paragraph: Initial responses from African officials to a report issued last week by France on the return of looted treasures from the continent reveal the path to restitution will be a thorny one.

headline: Trump Defends Pursuit of Russia Deal in 2016 as ‘Very Legal’
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Trump said he had looked only “lightly” at constructing a building in Russia. “Put up zero money, zero guarantees and didn’t do the project,” he said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump woke up in balmy Buenos Aires early Friday, but his mind was back in Washington as he defended his decision to continue pursuing business deals as he ran for president in 2016, including looking “lightly” at constructing a building in Russia.

headline: A Lively, Fast-Paced Account of France’s Second Empire
abstract: “City of Light,” by Rupert Christiansen, recounts Georges-Eugène Haussmann’s swift modernization of Paris in the mid-19th century.
lead_paragraph: CITY OF LIGHT The Making of Modern Paris By Rupert Christiansen 206 pp. Basic Books. $25.

headline: Pontius Pilate’s Name Is Found on 2,000-Year-Old Ring
abstract: The piece bearing the name of the Roman official thought to have ordered the killing of Jesus was found decades ago near Bethlehem, but the inscription was revealed only recently.
lead_paragraph: The name of Pontius Pilate, the Roman official who ordered the killing of Jesus, according to the Gospel, is mentioned in thousands of sermons every year and is familiar to countless people, but little is known about his life and work.

headline: Behind the Cover: The Insect Apocalypse
abstract: For this issue, a look at the casualties of the Anthropocene.

headline: Deutsche Bank’s Top Management Offices Searched by German Investigators
abstract: Law enforcement authorities searched offices of the management board as part of an investigation into accusations of money laundering and tax evasion.
lead_paragraph: German law enforcement authorities targeted offices of the Deutsche Bank management board Friday as they spent a second day gathering evidence in an investigation into whether the bank helped clients launder money in an offshore tax haven.

headline: An Awkward Moment for the Russian Art Market
abstract: Sales have slowed in the face of new political realities, including Western sanctions on Moscow. But wealthy buyers continue to create surprises.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The spending power of wealthy Russians has been one of the elements that have given the 21st-century art market an air of excess.

headline: A Life of Cy Twombly Brings a Poet’s Eye to the Artist’s Mythic Work
abstract: “Chalk: The Art and Erasure of Cy Twombly,” by Joshua Rivkin, the first biography of the artist, is a deeply personal work — as much about the biographer as his subject.
lead_paragraph: CHALK The Art and Erasure of Cy Twombly By Joshua Rivkin 478 pp. Melville House. $32.

headline: Gloria Katz, a Writer of ‘American Graffiti,’ Is Dead at 76
abstract: She and her husband, Willard Huyck, also worked on “Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom” and “Howard the Duck,” and did uncredited work on “Star Wars.”
lead_paragraph: Gloria Katz, who went from a struggling screenwriter to a sought-after one when “American Graffiti,” a film she wrote with her husband, Willard Huyck, and the not-yet-famous director George Lucas became a surprise hit of 1973, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. She was 76.

headline: Bernie Sanders Steps Out With His Favored Political Partner: His Wife
abstract: At a symposium organized by Jane Sanders, the Vermont senator didn’t quite take the reins of 2020 leadership. But he didn’t drop them either.
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — When Jane Sanders introduced her event’s keynote speaker here on Thursday night, she called him “my best friend” but didn’t say his name.

headline: The Fantasy Master N.K. Jemisin Turns to Short Stories
abstract: The fans of her two series — the Inheritance trilogy and the Broken Earth trilogy — will find much to love in her new collection, “How Long ’Til Black Future Month?”
lead_paragraph: HOW LONG ’TIL BLACK FUTURE MONTH? By N.K. Jemisin 416 pp. Orbit. $26.

headline: What Are You Craving?
abstract: A spiced chickpea stew, shrimp scampi and deviled chicken thighs are exactly what we want to eat right now.
lead_paragraph: Hello! It’s Five Weeknight Dishes, recipes for busy people who still want something good to eat. I’m all business today. Last week, I asked you what you wanted to see in December, and the answers were so helpful that I’m putting the call out again: What do you want to have for dinner next month? What are you craving in between all those cookies, spiced nuts, pigs-in-blankets or slabs of Brie?

headline: Hate Mail and Conversion Advice: Interfaith Couple Caught in Israel’s Fault Lines
abstract: Lucy Aharish, a TV anchor, and her husband, Tsahi Halevi, an actor, deflect condemnation from politicians and angry strangers with humor and song.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — For as long as she has anchored her own television news program — about five years, in different iterations — Lucy Aharish has always opened by greeting her viewers in both Hebrew and Arabic.

headline: Mad, Bad and Dangerous: The Legacy Left to Byron’s Wife and Daughter
abstract: Miranda Seymour’s dual biography, “In Byron’s Wake,” chronicles the lives of his widow, Annabella Milbanke, and his daughter, the mathematician Ada Lovelace.
lead_paragraph: IN BYRON’S WAKE The Turbulent Lives of Lord Byron’s Wife and Daughter: Annabella Milbanke and Ada Lovelace By Miranda Seymour Illustrated. 547 pp. Pegasus Books. $35.

headline: College Football Conference Championships: Who Will Make the Playoff?
abstract: Three of this weekend’s major conference title games have implications for the four-team playoff bracket, which will be announced Sunday.
lead_paragraph: All five major conferences hold their championship games this weekend, setting the stage for Sunday, when the College Football Playoff selection committee will release its final rankings and determine the four-team playoff bracket.

headline: Rains Turn Squalid Migrant Camp Near California Border Into Scene of Fetid Misery
abstract: A downpour quickly flooded the open-air complex sheltering arrivals from Central America, reducing their few belongings to a soggy mess.
lead_paragraph: TIJUANA, Mexico — The skies opened before the border did.

headline: Brexit, Borders, and the Bank of England (Wonkish)
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Foreign Investments']
abstract: How bad will it be when Britain leaves the European Union?
lead_paragraph: A few days ago the Bank of England released a report on the possible macroeconomic impact of Brexit. The most pessimistic scenarios were eye-poppingly bad — see Figure 1 — showing a worse slump than the one that followed the 2008 financial crisis. Not surprisingly, Brexit opponents seized on the report, while supporters accused the BoE of engaging in scare tactics.

headline: Music With Messages
abstract: A book on the Weavers and another on protest songs examine the connections between music and politics.
lead_paragraph: WASN’T THAT A TIME The Weavers, the Blacklist, and the Battle for the Soul of America By Jesse Jarnow Illustrated. 296 pp. Da Capo Press. $27.

headline: A Rich, Beautifully Rendered Mystery Evokes 15th-Century England
abstract: In Samantha Harvey’s immersive new novel, “The Western Wind,” the village priest spends four days unraveling a local murder.
lead_paragraph: THE WESTERN WIND By Samantha Harvey 294 pp. Grove Press. $26.

headline: New York City at War
abstract: John Strausbaugh’s “Victory City” describes a time of great heroes, and great villainy too.
lead_paragraph: VICTORY CITY A History of New York and New Yorkers During World War II By John Strausbaugh Illustrated. 496 pp. Twelve. $30.

headline: Ukraine, on a War Footing, Looks Westward for Help
abstract: Russia’s attack on three Ukrainian naval vessels only underscores Kiev’s vulnerability, particularly at sea.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — With 24 of his sailors and three of his warships held captive by Russia after a confrontation on Sunday in waters near Crimea, the commander of Ukraine’s tiny navy declared that Russia under President Vladimir V. Putin was “the plague of the 21st century” and vowed that it must be stopped.

headline: Review: At the Philharmonic, a Screaming Reflection on War
abstract: Jaap van Zweden led the orchestra in Shostakovich’s “Leningrad” Symphony and Britten’s Violin Concerto, with Simone Lamsma in a brilliant debut.
lead_paragraph: Shostakovich’s “Leningrad” Symphony is a sprawling score that heaves, blasts, marches and meanders for nearly 80 minutes. Written in 1941, while Hitler’s forces were devastating Leningrad in a siege that would last 900 days and take at least a million lives, the work practically screams, “This is a big statement!”

headline: Do You Know What You’re Breathing?
abstract: Personal pollution monitors and masks are exactly what you need for Burning Man.
lead_paragraph: The hottest new apocalypse preparation choice for 2019 is not a bunker or a gun or a lifeboat. And it’s not moving to New Zealand. It’s a small gadget that measures the air pollution around you.

headline: 5 Shows to See in New York: Not Just Cher but Cher Horowitz
abstract: Off Broadway productions in December consider migrants from Africa, the Middle East and Manhattan, plus one well dressed emissary from Beverly Hills.
lead_paragraph: If you follow theater, you probably already know about the Broadway bigfoots opening this month: “Network” starring Bryan Cranston, “To Kill a Mockingbird,” starring Jeff Daniels, and “The Cher Show,” starring three Chers. But it’s also a month, Off Broadway, for wider exploration, from Beverly Hills and Brooklyn to France, Iran and Iraq.

headline: Nearly a Month After the Midterms, Some House Races Are Still Undecided
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Another week is ending, and winners have yet to be called in a district in California and one in New York.
lead_paragraph: And here you thought the midterms would be over after the special election in Mississippi on Tuesday.

headline: An Unapologetically Feminist Western Novel
abstract: With “Heresy,” Melissa Lenhardt has delivered an all-out women-driven, queer, transgender, multiracial takeover of the Old West.
lead_paragraph: HERESY By Melissa Lenhardt 460 pp. Redhook. Paper, $15.99.

headline: The Playlist: Mark Ronson and Miley Cyrus’s Melodrama, and 9 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Grimes, Jeff Tweedy, Meek Mill, Mary Halvorson and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Tear Gas and Water Cannon Hit Belgian Protesters Inspired by France’s ‘Yellow Vests’
abstract: Hundreds of protesters took to the streets of Brussels on Friday, stopping cars and blocking roads as they called for the country’s leader to resign.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Hundreds of protesters inspired by France’s “yellow vests” movement took to the streets of Brussels on Friday, stopping cars and blocking roads as they called for the country’s leader to resign.

headline: Jeeves and Wooster Are Back in a Fizzy New Homage to P.G. Wodehouse
abstract: Think of Ben Schott’s “Jeeves and the King of Clubs” as “Downton Abbey” with a laugh track.
lead_paragraph: JEEVES AND THE KING OF CLUBS By Ben Schott 316 pp. Little, Brown. $27.

headline: Kansas Recalls License Plates Offensive to Japanese-Americans
keywords: ['Automobile Registration and License Plates', 'Japanese-Americans', 'Discrimination', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: After a yearlong campaign by activists, the letter combination “JAP” will no longer be issued by the state.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the first laws requiring license plates were approved in the early 1900s, states have been vigilant over what they say.

headline: You Can’t Turn Away From Politics
abstract: A reader writes that democracy demands our engagement.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Final for All Time, Sacrificed on the Altar of the Modern Game
abstract: The decision to move the Copa Libertadores final to Spain is a failure of leadership, organization and governance. But it also is a precedent teams and fans may come to regret.
lead_paragraph: At the end of it all is a game. In Madrid next Sunday, barring legal maneuvering or an indignation-driven boycott, Boca Juniors and River Plate will finally settle the second leg of the final of the 2018 Copa Libertadores. The match will take place 6,000 miles away and two weeks after it was all meant to be over.

headline: How the Democrats Can Win in 2020
abstract: A reader offers a list of policy prescriptions that he believes most can agree on.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Is Chess a Sport? A New Book Says Yes
abstract: In “The Grandmaster,” Brin-Jonathan Butler covers the 2016 World Chess Championship, which pit Norway’s Magnus Carlsen against Russia’s Sergey Karjakin.
lead_paragraph: THE GRANDMASTER Magnus Carlsen and the Match That Made Chess Great Again By Brin-Jonathan Butler 211 pp. Simon & Schuster. $26.

headline: How a Times Court Decision Revolutionized Libel Law
abstract: In Times v. Sullivan, the Supreme Court ruled that public officials had to show not just that a story was inaccurate and hurt their reputation, but also that the publisher acted with “actual malice” — with reckless disregard for the truth.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to shed more light on how we work, The Times is running a series of short posts explaining some of our journalistic practices. Read more of this series here.

headline: Interior Secretary Unleashes Extraordinary Attack on Democratic Lawmaker
abstract: Ryan Zinke took to Twitter to accuse Representative Raúl Grijalva of being a drunk. The lawmaker had earlier called for Mr. Zinke’s resignation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In one corner was Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke, a swaggering cowboy type who once rode to work on a horse named Tonto and has faced at least a dozen ethics investigations.

headline: U.S. Asks, Are You a Terrorist? Scottish Grandfather Gives Wrong Answer
keywords: ['Visas', 'Terrorism', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Travel and Vacations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: John Stevenson, 70, and his wife may have to cancel their New York holiday because of a mistake he made on an online form.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — He could have misspelled his address, or entered an incorrect age — something fairly harmless — but no, the error John Stevenson made in an online form for the United States Department of Homeland Security was clicking on the wrong answer to a question.

headline: The ‘Stranger Things’ Book Brims With Easter Eggs — Just Like the Show Itself
abstract: Fans of Netflix’s hit supernatural mystery will find all kinds of clues to the show’s third season in a new companion book.
lead_paragraph: The third season of Netflix’s beloved supernatural mystery “Stranger Things” — which The Times once called “a scavenged-together pastiche of Spielbergian sci-fi laced with 1980s horror themes” — won’t appear until mid-2019. But the show’s passionate fans have something to tide them over: an official companion book called “Stranger Things: Worlds Turned Upside Down,” which debuts on the nonfiction list this week at No. 14.

headline: ‘Mowgli’: A Gloomier ‘Jungle Book’ Finally Sees the Light of Day
abstract: Undercut by Disney. Delayed for years. Dropped by Warner Bros. Andy Serkis’s big-budget adaptation had a long and difficult journey to Netflix.
lead_paragraph: Finding a preteen lead who can carry a big-budget, effects-heavy movie doesn’t sound like a simple feat. But casting Rohan Chand might have been the easiest part of completing Netflix’s new “Jungle Book” adaptation, “Mowgli: Legend of the Jungle.”

headline: ‘Love Is Love’ Comic Raises $51,000 for the Trevor Project
keywords: ['Comic Books and Strips', 'Philanthropy', 'Art', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)']
abstract: The anthology comic book, first created to aid those affected by the June 2016 attack at the Pulse nightclub, is now benefiting the Trevor Project.
lead_paragraph: “Love Is Love,” a 144-page benefit comic book that was originally published in 2016, has become a force in charitable giving.

headline: Wall Street Titan to Get a Refund Over Fake Art
abstract: A federal jury in New Hampshire ordered a former professor and her son to repay Andrew J. Hall for selling him fake paintings attributed to the artist Leon Golub.
lead_paragraph: A federal jury in New Hampshire said a former college professor and her son defrauded a Wall Street titan by selling him a series of fake paintings they claimed were by the modern artist Leon Golub.

headline: Review: In ‘A Christmas Carol in Harlem,’ Scrooge Wants to Make You Laugh
abstract: Classical Theater of Harlem reimagines the Charles Dickens tale with the holiday curmudgeon as a real estate predator in need of reclamation.
lead_paragraph: A gentle snow is falling as a child sings a holiday song on a city street, her small metal crutch laid on the ground beside the plastic cup she’s brought for donations.

headline: California’s Immigrant Workers Are Suffering
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Wildfires']
abstract: An advocacy group says the workers are not getting the medical care they need after exposure to wildfire pollution.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Talking About the 10 Best Books of 2018
abstract: On a special episode of the podcast, taped live, editors from The New York Times Book Review discuss this year’s outstanding fiction and nonfiction.
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: Earthquake Shreds Highways and Sows Panic in South Central Alaska
abstract: The earthquake damaged buildings and roads and briefly stoked fears of a tsunami throughout the region.
lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — It lasted just 30 seconds. But that was enough on Friday morning for a magnitude-7 earthquake to rip open roads, send streetlights crashing to the ground and leave Alaska’s quake-hardened residents panicked and reeling.

headline: We Went to a Steak Dinner Annuity Pitch. The Salesman Wasn’t Pleased.
abstract: Free meals have long been a tool that investment professionals use to reel in clients. Sometimes, the seminars could use a lot more context.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The pitch arrived in my aunt’s mailbox, just after her 80th birthday and in the wake of a few frightening weeks for retirement investors.

headline: Review: The Footwear Follies of ‘Zapatografía/Shoegraphy’
abstract: The cast of Larissa Velez-Jackson’s curious, charming, and category-defying show includes seniors from a neighborhood center.
lead_paragraph: Few dancers can sustain a career in New York without a second — or third or fourth or fifth — job. For more than a decade, the performer and choreographer Larissa Velez-Jackson has made a living teaching fitness classes to older adults. But in the past few years, she has begun letting her worlds mingle, bringing her students and members of local senior centers into her playful and strange works for the stage.

headline: There Will Be Blood-Red Trees
abstract: First Lady Melania Trump has defended this year’s White House stark tidings.

headline: Road Crumbles After 7.0-Magnitude Earthquake in Alaska
abstract: The powerful earthquake caused damage to roads and buildings in Anchorage and nearby areas. The National Weather Service issued a tsunami warning for parts of Alaska, but later canceled it.
lead_paragraph: The powerful earthquake caused damage to roads and buildings in Anchorage and nearby areas. The National Weather Service issued a tsunami warning for parts of Alaska, but later canceled it.

headline: The Many Times Trump Denied Ties to Russia
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: During the 2016 presidential campaign, Donald Trump repeatedly denied having business ties to Russia. Now that the president’s former lawyer has confessed to lying to Congress about a plan to build a tower in Russia, Trump’s story has changed.
lead_paragraph: During the 2016 presidential campaign, Donald Trump repeatedly denied having business ties to Russia. Now that the president’s former lawyer has confessed to lying to Congress about a plan to build a tower in Russia, Trump’s story has changed.

headline: N.F.C. East Struggles to Produce a Clear Front-Runner
abstract: For the second time in four years, the N.F.C. East is making a strong case for being the worst division in the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: Geoff Schwartz knows what it was like to play in the N.F.C. East before the division inexplicably collapsed into a jumbled heap.

headline: Harry Leslie Smith, ‘World’s Oldest Rebel,’ Is Dead at 95
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Politics and Government', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: He survived the Great Depression. He fought the Nazis in World War II. And at 87 he turned to writing and agitating, and acquired a loyal following.
lead_paragraph: He called himself “the world’s oldest rebel.” And when he railed against the system, he came across as the voice of experience, even as he deftly managed the young media environments of Twitter and podcasts.

headline: The Rangers’ Other No. 11 Gets His Day of Honor
abstract: Vic Hadfield was a dominant force with Jean Ratelle and Rod Gilbert in the 1960s and ’70s, long before Mark Messier came along.
lead_paragraph: Vic Hadfield made No. 11 fashionable at Madison Square Garden decades before another Ranger made it eternal.

headline: Yes, the Octopus Is Smart as Heck. But Why?
abstract: It has eight arms, three hearts — and a plan. Scientists aren’t sure how the cephalopods got to be so intelligent.
lead_paragraph: To demonstrate how smart an octopus can be, Piero Amodio points to a YouTube video. It shows an octopus pulling two halves of a coconut shell together to hide inside. Later the animal stacks the shells together like nesting bowls — and carts them away.

headline: John Chau Aced Missionary Boot Camp. Reality Proved a Harsher Test.
abstract: Before being killed on a remote island in the Andaman Sea, Mr. Chau attended a missionary training camp in Kansas.
lead_paragraph: Just months before undertaking the most forbidding journey in his life as a young missionary to a remote Indian Ocean island, John Allen Chau was blindfolded and dropped off on a dirt road in a remote part of Kansas.

headline: 3 Killed After Pickup Truck Fleeing Border Patrol Hits Tire Spikes and Crashes
abstract: A pickup truck with nine people in its bed crashed and flipped over in Southern California after driving over tire spikes placed by the Border Patrol.
lead_paragraph: Three people in a packed pickup truck were killed on Thursday afternoon after the driver ran over tire spikes and crashed on a Southern California highway while trying to flee Border Patrol officers, the authorities said.

headline: Who’s Next? Roger Daltrey
abstract: The parade of rock memoirs continues, but “Thanks a Lot, Mr. Kibblewhite” is a really good one.
lead_paragraph: THANKS A LOT, MR. KIBBLEWHITE My Story By Roger Daltrey Illustrated. 259 pp. Henry Holt & Company. $30.

headline: ‘Head Full of Honey’ Review: Alzheimer’s Gets the Wacky Grandpa Treatment
abstract: Nick Nolte, Matt Dillon and Emily Mortimer star in this tonally disheveled, occasionally offensive movie.
lead_paragraph: The subject of Alzheimer’s gets a tonally disheveled, occasionally offensive treatment in the disastrous “Head Full of Honey,” about a family dealing with (or failing to deal with) the rapidly escalating dementia of the widower Amadeus (Nick Nolte). The warning signs of his condition first appear when, speaking at his wife’s funeral, he goes on a bizarre tangent about pie, praises her breasts, forgets she’s dead and doesn’t seem to have any idea where he is.

headline: A Capacious New History of the Beastie Boys by the Two Who Remain
abstract: In “Beastie Boys Book,” Mike Diamond and Adam Horovitz gather their memories, mementos and a lot more to offer a celebration of their band.
lead_paragraph: BEASTIE BOYS BOOK By Michael Diamond and Adam Horovitz Illustrated. 571 pp. Spiegel & Grau. $50.

headline: Trump Claims Nafta Victory but Deal Faces Long Odds in U.S.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'International Trade and World Market', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The president said gaining congressional approval would not be much of a problem. Democrats disagree.
lead_paragraph: President Trump declared victory on Friday at a ceremonial signing of the new North American Free Trade Agreement in Buenos Aires, predicting that gaining congressional approval needed to enact the pact with Mexico and Canada would not be “very much of a problem.”

headline: I Didn’t Become a Stay-at-Home Mother for My Kids. I Did It for Me.
abstract: I was miserable. But sometimes misery can make you a better person.
lead_paragraph: For the longest time, my parents had begged me for grandchildren. The first one pleased them greatly, but the announcement nine months later that a second one was on its way made my mother blanch.

headline: North Carolina Election That Looked to Be Republican Victory Now in Limbo
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Absentee Voting']
abstract: The state elections board said it would not certify the results in the Ninth Congressional District and instead would hold a December hearing to explore claims of fraudulent absentee ballots.
lead_paragraph: A North Carolina congressional election that a Republican appeared to have narrowly won is now in limbo as state elections officials investigate voting irregularities and questions about the handling of absentee ballots.

headline: 15 Books to Read by Black Female American Writers
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Nelson George, Samuel R. Delany, Major Jackson and others tell us about some of their favorite works of literature.
lead_paragraph: For our 2018 Holiday issue, out Dec. 2, T assembled 32 black male writers, who, with their peers, are producing literature that is essential to how we understand our country and its place in the world right now. “When I was asked to consider the particularities of the current landscape, I wondered if a focus on male achievement might obscure the equally unprecedented successes of African-American women,” writes Ayana Mathis in her accompanying essay. “And does that question undermine this extraordinary moment for black male writers?” She admits she hasn’t found a sufficient answer to this question, “but I do know that the work of black women writers presents a ferocious challenge to old sexist perceptions; as [the author and scholar Farah] Griffin says, ‘the difference between this moment and others is that, in the past, to be a black writer was to be a man.’” Here, Nelson George, Samuel R. Delany, Major Jackson and more of the men featured in our pages tell us about their favorite works of literature by black female Americans.

headline: Carlos Ghosn Can Remain in Tokyo Jail for 10 More Days
abstract: A Tokyo court gave prosecutors an extension as they investigate allegations of financial misconduct by Mr. Ghosn, the head of the Renault-Nissan alliance.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A Tokyo court approved a 10-day extension of jail time for Carlos Ghosn, the head of the Renault-Nissan alliance, on Friday as prosecutors assess allegations of financial misconduct. An ocean away, the corporate titan’s problems were on show at the Group of 20 summit meeting: President Emmanuel Macron of France, where Renault is based, met with Japan’s prime minister to discuss the alliance.

headline: Nina Beilina, Soviet Violinist and Festival Founder, Dies at 81
abstract: Concerned about diminishing opportunities for Jews in her homeland, she emigrated to the United States and started over.
lead_paragraph: Nina Beilina, who emigrated from the Soviet Union in midlife when she was one of that country’s premier violinists and built a whole new following in the United States, playing top halls and founding her own ensemble, died on Nov. 25 in Manhattan. She was 81.

headline: Ariana Grande’s ‘Thank U, Next’ Video and More: 8 Things to Know From the Week in Pop Culture
abstract: What you need to know from this week’s TV, music and movie news.
lead_paragraph: What would you like to see here? Email us at popculture@nytimes.com.

headline: Manafort’s Fate Is Open-Ended. On This, Trump and the Mueller Team Agree.
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: President Trump did not rule out a pardon for his former campaign chairman, while prosecutors say he violated a plea agreement and could face additional charges.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The special counsel’s office and President Trump found themselves in rare agreement on Friday over Mr. Trump’s former campaign chairman Paul Manafort: Nothing is off the table.

headline: Lawyer Accused of Using Fake Facebook Pages to Sway Elections in Staten Island
abstract: Richard A. Luthmann, an eccentric lawyer already under federal indictment, has been accused of creating fake social media profiles for local politicians.
lead_paragraph: The political scandal is on a much smaller scale than Russia’s interference with the 2016 presidential election, but Staten Island has its own fake news controversy.

headline: Former Dallas Officer Amber Guyger Charged With Murder for Shooting Man in His Apartment
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Amber R. Guyger said that she mistook Botham Jean’s apartment for her own, and opened fire. On Friday, she was indicted on a murder charge.
lead_paragraph: A former Dallas police officer was indicted on a murder charge on Friday for shooting an unarmed, 26-year-old African-American accountant who was watching TV in his apartment, a home that the officer says she mistook as her own.

headline: Driver Who Ran Over Mother of Girl Killed by MS-13 Is Charged With Negligent Homicide
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The Suffolk County prosecutor, Timothy D. Sini, announced the indictment of a woman who first dismantled a memorial for Evelyn Rodriguez’s daughter, who was killed by a gang.
lead_paragraph: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y. — In September, at the Long Island cul-de-sac where two years ago her teenage daughter was found murdered by the transnational gang MS-13, Evelyn Rodriguez saw that the memorial she had placed there that day was gone.

headline: 600 Million Years Ago, the First Scavengers Lurked in Dark Ocean Gardens
abstract: The bizarre organisms of the Ediacaran Period have long puzzled researchers. Fossil discoveries suggest these ecosystems may have been more complicated than once thought.
lead_paragraph: Some 635 million years ago, as the Earth shook off massive shrouds of glacial ice, an alien world blossomed on the ocean floors.

headline: A Marine's Reaction to a Children's Book Prompts an Apology From the Publisher
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: In an article for the Times, a former Marine criticized a “choose your own adventure” children’s book set in Afghanistan. A week later, the book’s publisher wrote to him with an apology.
lead_paragraph: At War is a newsletter about the experiences and costs of war with stories from Times reporters and outside voices.

headline: Dodging Friends, Chased by Legal Troubles, Trump Navigates G-20
abstract: At the Group of 20 gathering in Buenos Aires, President Trump declined to meet with his two favorite strongmen, postponed meeting an ally and was preoccupied with the Russia investigation.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — He didn’t sit down with two of his favorite strongmen. He downgraded a meeting with one ally and postponed one with another. He exchanged icy smiles with the prime minister of Canada, who had threatened to skip the signing of a new trade agreement with the United States and Mexico because of lingering bitterness over steel tariffs.

headline: Yankees Court Patrick Corbin, but Keep Their Options Open
abstract: Corbin, the jewel of the free-agent pitching market, spent this week on a tour of teams he is considering: the Nationals, the Phillies and the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: STAMFORD, Conn. — When Patrick Corbin, the jewel of the free-agent pitching market, was married two weeks ago, his younger brother Kevin stood to give a toast to the newlyweds. As it concluded, according to one report, Kevin put on a Yankees cap and — to great applause — told the room that he was hoping the couple would soon be moving closer to their upstate New York home.

headline: T Suggests: Fashion by Gilbert & George, an Irish Designer to Know and More
abstract: A roundup of things our editors — and a few contributors — are excited about in a given week.
lead_paragraph: The Irish designer Jonathan Anderson has deep roots in East London: He has called it home since 2005, when he moved there at age 21 to study at the London College of Fashion. The studio for his brand, J.W. Anderson, is also based in East London, in Dalston — a former slum once tormented by Jack the Ripper that is now undergoing huge gentrification. “It still holds this authenticity and cultural clash of everything London is about,” says Anderson. “I realized as a student that this was where my place was.”

headline: Missionary’s Killing Reignites Debate About Isolated Tribes: Contact, Support or Stay Away?
abstract: There are dozens of communities that continue to live completely off the grid, mostly in the Amazon, where drug traffickers, miners and ranchers threaten them.
lead_paragraph: The recent killing of an American missionary by members of an isolated tribe on a small island in the Indian Ocean has reignited questions about the fate of the last few groups of people living off the grid.

Whitaker: He had been named chief of staff to Attorney General Jeff Sessions.

headline: Aaron Klug, 92, Dies; His 3-D Images of Bodily Molecules Won a Nobel
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Proteins', 'Nobel Prizes', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Biology and Biochemistry', '3-D Devices and Effects']
abstract: Born in Lithuania, raised in South Africa and working in Britain, he made large strides in understanding the structure of proteins, DNA and more.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Klug, who won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1982 for devising ways to create three-dimensional images of biological molecules like proteins and DNA, died on Nov. 20. He was 92.

headline: A Famous Alpha Wolf’s Daughter, Spitfire, Is Killed by a Hunter
keywords: ['Wolves', 'Hunting and Trapping', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: The shooting of another Lamar Canyon pack member has renewed calls for a buffer between Yellowstone and nearby lands, to protect roaming wolves.
lead_paragraph: HELENA, Mont. — A wild wolf known as 926F, dear to the hearts of wolf watchers who visit Yellowstone, was killed by a hunter as it wandered just outside the park last weekend.

headline: Scenes From the Alaska Earthquake
abstract: A magnitude 7 earthquake hit Anchorage, causing widespread damage to roads and buildings in the region, and led the governor to issue a declaration of disaster.
lead_paragraph: A magnitude 7 earthquake hit Anchorage, causing widespread damage to roads and buildings in the region, and led the governor to issue a declaration of disaster.

headline: The Best TV Shows and Movies New to Netflix Canada in December
abstract: Every month, Netflix Canada adds a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are the titles we think are most interesting for December.
lead_paragraph: Every month, Netflix Canada adds a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are the titles we think are most interesting for December, broken down by release date. Netflix occasionally changes schedules without giving notice.

headline: Doctors Said Hockey Enforcer Todd Ewen Did Not Have C.T.E. But He Did.
abstract: A new analysis of Ewen’s brain tissue confirms he had the degenerative brain disease, despite what a Canadian doctor initially found. That doctor went on to work for the N.H.L.
lead_paragraph: WILDWOOD, Mo. — The news at first seemed to shock the medical world studying the relationship between hard hits to the head in sports and a degenerative neurological disease called C.T.E.

headline: A Close Race, a Mysterious Ballot and Control of Alaska’s House at Stake
abstract: A race for the Alaska House has resulted in a tie, prompting a recount. “I hope we don’t have a coin toss,” one of the candidates said.
lead_paragraph: With a crucial legislative seat in Alaska teetering toward a tie earlier this month, lawmakers in Juneau braced for the possibility of a coin toss deciding control of the state’s House of Representatives. Then a mysterious extra ballot emerged that threw the process into further disarray.

headline: John Chau Wanted to Change Life on North Sentinel Island. Was He Wrong?
keywords: ['Missionaries', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY']
abstract: The death of a young American missionary on a tropical island at the hands of an indigenous group has left us to wonder: Are they better off with us or without us?
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago a young American made a doomed mission to North Sentinel Island, a speck in the Bay of Bengal and home to perhaps the most isolated people on earth — all 50 or so of them.

headline: Homeland Security Dept. Request Would Keep Troops on Border Through January
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Posse Comitatus Act (1878)', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: A Pentagon official said Defense Secretary Jim Mattis was expected to approve the request, which would keep at least some of the military forces on the border for the Christmas holidays.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Department of Homeland Security formally asked the Pentagon on Friday to extend the mission of active-duty troops on the southwest border through the end of January.
